---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Twitter&#8217;s ecosystem streamlining, and what it means for webOS devs"
url_title: twitters-ecosystem-streamlining-and-what-it-means-for-webos-devs
permalink: twitters-ecosystem-streamlining-and-what-it-means-for-webos-devs.html
tags: "twitter, api, developers, community, webos, palm, hp, ideasofmarch"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Mobile
- Spaz
- webOS
date: 2011-03-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2473
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/wilderdom/266650346/lightbox/" title="'Fear' by Jimee, Jackie, Tom &amp; Asha"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/84/266650346_5556348960.jpg" alt="&quot;'Fear' by Jimee, Jackie, Tom &amp; Asha&quot;" /></a></p>

<p>I had a really fun time the other night on the <a href="http://www.webosroundup.com/">webOSRoundup</a> live podcast recording. We do it over Skype + UStream, so folks in the chat can watch us while we dick around and try to fix technical issues. I love doing stuff like this because I get to act like I know what I&#8217;m talking about &#8211;&#160;it&#8217;s a lot like this blog in that respect.</p>

<p>One of the major topics of discussion was <a href="https://groups.google.com/d/topic/twitter-development-talk/yCzVnHqHIWo/discussion">a recent announcement</a> to the Twitter developer community about the way users interact with Twitter, and where developers should focus their efforts. There were also updates to the API TOS, but that really didn&#8217;t change much. The &#8220;money quote&#8221; was in the letter, signed by Ryan Sarver, that went out:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>&#8230;developers ask us if they should build client apps that mimic or reproduce the mainstream Twitter consumer client experience. &#160;The answer is no.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>While follow-up discussion has basically been Twitter employees saying &#8220;oh, we didn&#8217;t mean that you can&#8217;t, just that you probably won&#8217;t make money doing it.&#8221; While the folks posting this probably believe that, I think the folks who actually control what Twitter does meant what was said. And what was said was &#8220;you should not make client apps,&#8221; and not &#8220;you probably won&#8217;t make money making client apps.&#8221;</p>

<p>A lot of people have asked if this means 3rd party client apps are <em>banned</em>. No, not at the moment. But Twitter&#8217;s overriding purpose is to make their investors money, and if it becomes more lucrative to ban 3rd party clients outright, or restrict API access to blessed or paying developers, I have no doubt the company will do so. People have short attention spans, and if Twitter is still around in 2 years, things may have changed enough where they don&#8217;t care so much that they can&#8217;t use Tweetdeck.</p>

<p>The second point that came up in this discussion was how this affects webOS. There is no official client on webOS, but there is a very active set of 3rd-party devs who work on clients, including myself with Spaz. Right now, I believe there&#8217;s no official client simply because Twitter doesn&#8217;t care about webOS. At the moment, webOS market share is too low to matter to them. When that changes, they will be more interested in it.</p>

<p>And rest assured, HP Palm wants an official client. It&#8217;s in a list of apps they want, like Netflix and Skype. If HP/P has to build it themselves and just have the approval of Twitter (Twitter certainly doesn&#8217;t build all their official clients in-house), they will &#8211;&#160;like they did with FaceBook.</p>

<p>What does that mean for the various independently-developed Twitter clients? Probably that they will need to be accept that their products will be niche. I&#8217;m speculating, but I suspect HP/P will not put much effort into promoting 3rd party clients. There&#8217;s a good chance an official Twitter app will be pre-installed as well, which means many (most?) users won&#8217;t bother looking in the App Catalog for another option.</p>

<p>Does that mean you&#8217;re screwed? No. But it means you&#8217;re gonna have to accept a role as a &#8220;hobbyist&#8221; rather than trying to make this your day job. <a href="http://al3x.net/2010/09/15/last-thing-about-twitter.html">As Alex Payne said</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Get cozy with [Twitter], or work at arm&#8217;s length. Operating in between the hobbyist and professional roles could be difficult, and developers may be understandably frustrated as they&#8217;re forced to rethink their projects and products</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I suppose it&#8217;s possible that HP/P might pluck some lucky indie developer out of obscurity and bring them on to develop the official client. More power to that person if it happens. I hope you&#8217;ll enjoy removing features from your client and making space for ads.</p>

<p>Me, I&#8217;ll keep making Spaz, and improving its interoperability with other microblogging systems like the StatusNet-based Identi.ca. I&#8217;ve never made money on Spaz, and I like it that way &#8212; it keeps me focused on doing the right thing, not what will improve my financial position.</p>

<p>Luckily I can do that, but not everyone can, and those webOS developers who rely on their Twitter apps for income would be well-advised to consider whether their want to tie their success to a single company anymore &#8212; a company with which they have no financial relationship, and one that has clearly stated their intent to control the end-user market.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Why You Would Be a Jackass to Miss the Php Community Conference"
url_title: why-you-would-be-a-jackass-to-miss-to-the-php-community-conference
permalink: why-you-would-be-a-jackass-to-miss-to-the-php-community-conference.html
tags: "php, community, conference, phpcomcon, nashville"
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2011-03-10
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2472
---
<p><a href="http://phpcon.org/" title="PHP Community Conference - April 21-22 - Nashville, TN"><img src="http://funkatron.com/images/phpcomcon.png" alt="PHP Community Conference" /></a></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve been doing conferences since July of 2006, when I attended <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/muntoh/207352244/">OSCON in Portland, OR</a>. Since then I&#8217;ve been to 4 or 5 a year, mostly as a speaker (#humblebrag) but sometimes as an attendee plebian as well.  They have included joints like:</p>

<ul>
<li>OSCON</li>
<li><a href="http://opensourcebridge.org">Open Source Bridge</a></li>
<li>SXSWi</li>
<li>php|tek &amp; works</li>
<li><a href="http://BrooklynBeta.org">Brooklyn Beta</a></li>
</ul>

<p>So I&#8217;ve gotten to see quite a range of conferences, from 10,000 people at SXSW, to 150 people at Brooklyn Beta. And after several years of this, I&#8217;ve come to the conclusion that the best conferences are:</p>

<ul>
<li>Intimate</li>
<li>Intelligent</li>
<li>Welcoming</li>
<li>Focus on sharing and learning from one another</li>
</ul>

<p>With conferences like this, there&#8217;s a lot less separation between speaker and attendee, which I like a lot. I personally LOVE jabbering with anyone who wants to hear me, so I love it when attendees come up and ask questions or share their own experiences with me. And this is a LOT easier at smaller conferences that actively encourage this kind of atmosphere.</p>

<p>Last year, I attended two conferences that met those criteria for me: Open Source Bridge and Brooklyn Beta. Both of them were small, volunteer-driven, not profit-motivated, and intimate. The people who attended were across the board there because they love what they do. They love making great things,  sharing what they create, and sharing <em>how</em> they create. And that&#8217;s why everyone was there.</p>

<p>So I am <em>very</em> excited that some dedicated folks are trying to bring this kind of experience to the PHP community. <strong><a href="http://phpcon.org/">The PHP Community Conference</a> on April 21-22 in Nashville, TN</strong> is going to be an intimate, friendly, intelligent conference for folks who use PHP. You&#8217;ll learn new stuff about a variety of topics, from technical PHP issues to open source community building.</p>

<p>Plus, how often do <a href="http://phpcon.org/speakers">speakers</a> like Rasmus Lerdorf, Andrei Zmievski, Lorna Mitchell and Terry Chay come to Nashville? For once you can attend a top-notch PHP conference that isn&#8217;t on the west coast or Chicago.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m speaking as well, but what I&#8217;m most excited about is being able to learn and share with other folks who love building things with PHP. <strong>I&#8217;m confident that this will be the best PHP conference of 2011</strong>. And I hope you&#8217;ll be there so I can meet you and talk about the awesome stuff <em>you&#8217;re</em> doing.</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz webOS Special Edition Plans"
url_title: spaz-webos-special-edition-plans
permalink: spaz-webos-special-edition-plans.html
tags: "hp, palm, webos, themes, spaz, css"
published: true
category:
- Design
- Spaz
- webOS
date: 2011-02-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2471
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/5438859669/" title="Spaz webOS themes"><img src="http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4073/5438859669_025c84cd93.jpg" alt="Spaz webOS themes" /></a></p>

<p>This year, while doing taxes, I put together numbers on the <a href="http://twitter.com/spaz/status/27732358526402560">out-of-pocket costs for maintaining Spaz</a>. These include VPSes on <a href="http://www.linode.com/?r=8e904a2b6e8cf17be5654da4d81432ddf0cd82d6">Linode</a> and Rackspace, and paid accounts on <a href="http://lighthouseapp.com">lighthouseapp.com</a>. As I posted on Twitter:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Since folks were asking, I received $353.84 in donations in 2010 vs the ~$1700.00 expenses.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I&#8217;ve never deluded myself into thinking the Spaz Project was even a break-even proposition: I make enough money in my day job to put some into Spaz, and I never expected to get it back.  It&#8217;s fulfilling for me and worth the investment to provide a transparent, open option for microblogging users.</p>

<p>Still, many folks in the webOS community have encouraged me to consider putting out a pay-for version of Spaz that people can purchase as a way to support the project. I wasn&#8217;t really comfortable with just putting out an identical product like that, but I think I came up with a reasonable value-add: additional themes.</p>

<p>Most users don&#8217;t really care about additional themes in an app, but some people LOVE them. I&#8217;m one of those people. I&#8217;ve always intended to put out Spaz with multiple themes, but work on adding features and improving performance have had higher priority, so I never got around to implementing it.</p>

<p>Recently I finally finished up the theme switching code, and was able to create a new theme. I informally put out a beta with this theme, called &#8220;Clean.&#8221; I also received a theme from Spaz contributor <a href="http://twitter.com/tibfib">Will Honey</a> and <a href="http://twitter.com/techjunky79">Bee Rad</a> that mirrors the look of his awesome new audio app <a href="http://kotoplayer.com/">Koto Player</a>.</p>

<p>So, my idea is to release a Spaz webOS &#8220;Special Edition&#8221; with at least 5 new themes (so 6 total, including the default &#8220;Dreadnaught&#8221; theme). This would be a pay-for download in the app catalog, probably for $2-3. Note that motivated individuals <em>would</em> be able to download and integrate themes themselves if they so desire, and all contributed themes in the Special Edition would be under a liberal license that&#8217;s compatible with Spaz&#8217;s &#8220;New BSD&#8221; license.</p>

<p>In addition, I will donate 50% of the revenue from the Spaz webOS Special Edition to <a href="http://twitter.com/webosinternals">@webosinternals</a>. Their tireless work has made the webOS developer community the most open, transparent, and <em>fun</em> in mobile dev. We need to support them so they can continue to be awesome.</p>

<p>One issue that will come up with having multiple versions of Spaz is cross-app launching integration. Apps in the catalog must have unique IDs, so the Special Edition will have a different appid than the &#8220;regular&#8221; Spaz. I&#8217;ll probably put out a simple code snippet that checks for each one, so app devs don&#8217;t have to manually try to support all three &#8212; that would suck.</p>

<p>If you&#8217;re interested in making a theme, all the info is available at <a href="http://help.getspaz.com/kb/mobile/creating-your-own-theme-for-spaz-webos">help.getspaz.com</a>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Thoughts on the HP &#8220;Think Beyond&#8221; webOS event"
url_title: thoughts-on-the-hp-think-beyond-webos-event
permalink: thoughts-on-the-hp-think-beyond-webos-event.html
tags: "palm, HP, webOS"
published: true
category:
- Development
- Hardware
- webOS
date: 2011-02-10
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2470
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/devicer/42499708/" title="Caution - The Clueless Will Be Impaled"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/32/42499708_c7ca79ec64.jpg" alt="Caution - The Clueless Will Be Impaled" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/devicer/42499708/">Photo by Wheezy Jefferson</a></div>

<p>So I&#8217;ll admit I sat through the entire event on two liveblogs. I&#8217;ve invested a bunch of time in webOS dev, and I really, really like the platform. This event would say a lot about the future direction of webOS. Hitting a home-run with the press would go a long way to ensuring the platform is around for a long time. So I was pretty interested.</p>

<p>My reaction, after chewing on it for an evening, is mixed at best. Some stuff was really encouraging, but vague information and poor, confusing messages continue to plague HP/Palm.</p>

<h3>New Hardware demos: (B)</h3>

<p>All the tech looks solid. The interaction between devices is impressive. The tablet looks great, the Pre 3 and Veer hit their markets solidly, and all 3 look powerful enough to run webOS properly.</p>

<p>This would be a slam-dunk A if we didn&#8217;t get the vague release timeframes that have plagued Palm in the past. &#8220;Summer&#8221; (in the northern hemisphere) gives us a timeframe between 3-7 months from now. And if we learned anything from the Pre launch, people forget quickly how awesome your stuff looked in a press event a couple months ago. Even on the short end, this seems contrary to HP&#8217;s proclamations that <a href="http://www.webosroundup.com/2011/01/hp-ceo-new-products-will-ship-a-few-weeks-after-feb-9-announcement/">&#8220;when HP makes announcements, it will be getting ready to ship&#8221;</a>. Based on past experience, it&#8217;s hard to believe HP/Palm will ship these devices in short order. I&#8217;d love to be wrong, though.</p>

<p>Also, no carriers were announced. That&#8217;s disappointing, and may indicate problems HP is having getting interest after the poor performance of the Pre and Pixi.</p>

<h3>New Software Partnerships: (B)</h3>

<p>Solid stuff. Skype is a big one, as is Kindle. Both are key apps that webOS has suffered without. The publisher partnerships are interesting, but it remains to be seen whether the concept apps turn into long-term publishing relationships. If Enyo comes through with its potential to be a <em>cross-platform</em> development framework, targeting an app for webOS will likely make more sense for big name third parties.</p>

<h3>Support for older devices: (F)</h3>

<p>HP really dropped the ball here. Not only did they go back on a promise to bring webOS 2.0 to the Pre and Pixi, they seemed unprepared with the news. It seems clear that not everyone was on the same page, and some Palm/HP employees weren&#8217;t even aware of this. In addition, no clear plan to make it up to loyal webOS users was presented.</p>

<p>This would be less of an issue if carriers had been announced. Folks stuck with a Sprint Pre would at least have a clear upgrade path that gets them on the 2.0 train. For now, it&#8217;s hard for them to be optimistic.</p>

<p>My personal experience (which might get me in trouble for saying, but c&#8217;est la vie): webOS 2.x runs pretty well on the Pre Plus. In some ways, the apparent performance is superior to 1.4.5. I&#8217;ve heard it runs poorly on the original Pre, though.</p>

<h3>Developer Info: (D)</h3>

<p>I was surprised at how short the developer presentation was last night. Enyo is exciting, no doubt &#8211;&#160;it&#8217;s a very solid framework that is far more flexible than Mojo, and allows for much better development workflows &amp; utilization of superior dev tools.</p>

<p>So that&#8217;s awesome, but it also means that if you&#8217;ve invested a lot of time in Mojo dev (like me), you can just toss that out. There is no upgrade or conversion path. It&#8217;s completely different, and you&#8217;ll be writing your app from scratch. And whether Enyo can run on 1.4.5 devices (packaged with the app itself) is up in the air, so if you want to support the users you have now, you now have two codebases to maintain.</p>

<p><a href="http://twitter.com/webosinternals">@webosinternals on Twitter</a> asked a lot of questions last night about dev topics that remain unanswered. I&#8217;ll c+p here:</p>

<ul>
<li>&#8220;No word on app catalog going global at the developer event?&#8221;</li>
<li>&#8220;No word on allowing hybrid apps into the app catalog at the developer event?&#8221; (was <a href="http://twitter.com/unwiredben/status/35591859564707840">answered via Twitter by @unwiredben</a>)</li>
<li>&#8220;No word from the PR folks about the 2.0 OTA broken promise at the developer event?&#8221;</li>
<li>&#8220;No word on how the palm profile works on multiple devices and the effect of that on app sales at the developer event?&#8221;</li>
<li>&#8220;No word on the fate of the mojo push messaging service at the developer event?&#8221;</li>
<li>&#8220;No word on whether HP is going to sell these new devices in other countries, or whether the release date hinges on US carrier acceptance?&#8221;</li>
</ul>

<p>Even worse, devs I&#8217;ve spoken with <em>expect to be let down by HP/Palm</em> &#8211; they expect to get unclear, vague answers. Or silence.</p>

<p>Fundamentally, I have to wonder how much effort HP is putting into webOS dev relations. I&#8217;ve dealt with the folks there and they&#8217;re stand-up people, but my general impression is that they&#8217;re hamstrung and unable to communicate clearly to webOS devs. This is the time dev relations needs to be at its strongest, most forward, and clearest. <strong>Making folks rely on casual Q&amp;A at social events, or catching Twitter posts is <em>not</em> how it should be done</strong>. If HP really wants a top notch dev program, they need to step up and fix this ASAP, or risk alienating their dev core.</p>

<p>If HP can get their communication problems sorted out and start being what I&#8217;d call &#8220;aggressively transparent&#8221; with its development community, I think we&#8217;ll get back on the right track. Here&#8217;s hoping.</p>

<p>We are hardcore Sprint tenants and Hardcore (with a capitol H) webOS users, but to be told &#8220;the coming months&#8221; for an indefinite amount of &#8220;coming months&#8221;, only to be told my day-one (6/6/09) Palm Pre is dead to HP is completly and utterly disheartening - at best.</p>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>Lisa,</p>

<p>There are several things that should have been handled better last night.</p>

<p>1) When the afternoon announcement of devices happened, the devices went up on the Palm web site during the presentation.  It was there <em>then</em>.  When Matt said &#8220;Enyo development is available now.&#8221; It should have been available &#8220;now.&#8221;  Someone should have been sitting at the web site ready to press the button and drop the forum posts and the links.  That was a mistake.</p>

<p>2) The legacy hardware support needed to be in an official release, not an interview, not a twitter feed, not something.  Again, the forum post should have gone out -then-</p>

<p>3) The legacy hardware support should NOT LIE.  You know and I know that a Pre+ runs 2.1 just fine.  You know we&#8217;ve done it, you&#8217;ve seen them and we&#8217;ve laughed about it.  &#8220;The hardware isn&#8217;t good enough&#8221; needs a far more detailed explanation.  Transparency and truth matters here.</p>

<p>4) If a company needs to break a promise to its customers, they need to apologize and to say that there will be SOMETHING done about it.  Again, a formal announcement needed to be made.  This should have been PRIORITIZED so that the answers WERE found prior to Feb 9.  As it is, it sounded like the decision was made in some back room that morning.  Transparency is important.</p>

<p>5) The enyo presentation needed to address if enyo is being back-ported to 1.4.5.  That missing from the presentation and from any followup is huge.  The answer to it is critical.  Since we KNOW that enyo was originally developed on Pre-1&#8217;s we know what the answer SHOULD be&#8230;.  but whatever it is, we need to know</p>

<p>6) The availability of hybrid apps ever on 1.4.5 is critical.</p>

<p>7) Enyo on the desktop.  Matt talked about it, but we don&#8217;t have the vision.</p>

<p>8) Carriers, I know every one else said it too, but carriers NEEDED to be addressed yesterday.  Huge fail.</p>

<p>9) Two tiers of developers.  It&#8217;s really an issue that three-to-six-months before releasing the tablet, you have Amazon and Time as &#8220;tier one&#8221; developers who sign real nda&#8217;s and who get to find out about unreleased products and work on alpha level software so that they can do forward looking stuff, and then there are us &#8220;tier two&#8221; developers who can&#8217;t be trusted.  It would be really NICE if there was a way for developers who have proven their mettle to be promoted into tier one, sign paper nda&#8217;s and have access to nightly os builds and hardware specs for unreleased hardware even tho we&#8217;re NOT part of a giant company like Amazon.  I admit there has to be a means test, but shouldn&#8217;t those who HAVE DONE be those who CAN DO?</p>

<p>&#8212;- now, outside the numbered list &#8212;&#8212;</p>

<p>The morning session made it clear that HP plans on creating an ecology of webOS running on a variety of devices which inherently and almost magically share data and information and which allow seamless access to your life.  It&#8217;s very cool and allows me to start to have a vision of how webOS could penetrate the minds of millions of consumers and create a very exciting</p>

<p>The idea that webOS will be embedded on the desktop of two laptops a second, plus a gazillion printers, and that people will want software to run in that environment and sync to their phones and tablets is very exciting&#8230;  but the question of profiles on multiple devices, and how developers will be paid etc are all open questions that I suspect HP hasn&#8217;t addressed yet.</p>

<p>ADMITTING that they haven&#8217;t been addressed, and again being transparent will help us with that.</p>

<p>(Note also that questions like hybrid apps on multiple devices and PDK apps on multiple devices when the devices have different underlying hardware like dual core tablets and phones and intel/amd laptops are questions that need to be addressed too.)</p>

THERE WILL BE PROGRAMS TO GET PEOPLE INTO NEW DEVICES, we just don&#8217;t have the details worked out yet.  Worst.  Timing.  Ever.</p>

<p>If you have an existing Mojo app, continue to maintain it and optimize it for Pre3&#8217;s screensize (we&#8217;ll have details on how to do this). Remember, this is exactly what Enyo was designed for.</p>

<p>The next few months are gonna be rough while we work through this Mojo / Enyo transition phase, but it’ll still be way easier than going down the path of forcing Mojo to support larger screen sizes.  After we get through it, the future market that we hope will be available to you will more than make up for temporarily duplicated efforts.</p></li>

<p>This is outside my area of expertise, but yeah&#8230;would be nice to know.  =]</p></li>

I mean, you&#8217;re sitting here on Twitter saying there will be an upgrade while Engadget&#8217;s posting an interview with Ruby saying there isn&#8217;t. It means the people above you knew they were throwing developers under the bus and didn&#8217;t want to hear about until the last possible second. I&#8217;m sure you realize what a terrible position this puts you in more than anyone, but I feel compelled to point this out.</p>

<p>But more importantly, why were the issues not considered during development? It&#8217;s like no one cared that you had a base, like you could just start over and everyone would forget the time and money they&#8217;ve invested in the app ecosystem. I look at the reasons people say updating to 2.0 would be difficult and I wonder: why didn&#8217;t Palm plan for this? Profile incompatibility?! Having to run apps in the emulator on a Touchpad because you dropped the gesture area? The return of back and forward? Pray tell, are devlopers now going to have to launch interfaces for both gesture area devices and those without them? Or are we now abandoning that completely? I mean just&#8230;so many things.</p>

<p>If I had to offer my suggestions, it would been to hold this event later or to not have wasted your time with the developer event in November, and instead have had one almost immediately following what transpired yesterday. It&#8217;s been months for us, we expected something more concrete.</p>

<p>It&#8217;s a shame for this mark to be on the event as I definitely dug the new hardware, too. I want a Pre 3&#8230;not so much now with the developer issues. I&#8217;m not sure whether the support webOS needs will be there.</p>
</div>
	</li>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>HP&#8217;s problem is a problem of <a href="http://www.ericmackonline.com/ICA/blogs/emonline.nsf/dx/ethics-are-the-foundation-of-effective-knowledge-management">ethics in business</a>. My friend Eric Mack states the problem as as it pertains to Knowledge Management:</p>

<p>&gt; Here&#8217;s how I currently define the argument for Ethics in KM</p>

<p>&gt; 1. Knowledge Management is about sharing of knowledge, information, and experiences - an exchange of information and ideas . (We often call this learning.)</p>

<p>&gt; 2. This exchange cannot occur without effective communication.</p>

<p>&gt; 3. For communication to be truly effective, transparency must exist. Transparent communication is built on trust.</p>

<p>&gt; 4. Any unethical behavior undermines trust which ultimately impairs communication which leads to the loss of sharing and the loss (or distortion) of information and knowledge.</p>

<p>&gt; The bottom line is that ethics is important to KM because of trust.</p>

<p>I believe this old adage applies, &#8220;it takes 20 good deeds to make up for one bad deed.&#8221;</p>

<li>It is not enough to listen, it&#8217;s much more important to listen AND change (for the better).</li>
</ul>
</div>
	</li>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Notes on &#8220;Shortchanging Your Business with User-Hostile Platforms&#8221;"
url_title: notes-on-shortchanging-your-business-with-user-hostile-platforms
permalink: notes-on-shortchanging-your-business-with-user-hostile-platforms.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2011-01-17
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2469
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/alphadesigner/212917484/" title="The Girl with the Make Up 1"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/70/212917484_c28857509f.jpg" alt="The Girl with the Make Up 1" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/alphadesigner/212917484/">Photo by alphadesigner</a></div>

<p>Please read <a href="http://al3x.net/2011/01/15/user-hostile-platforms.html">Alex&#8217;s original post</a>, if you haven&#8217;t. What follows are some thoughts in response to his post.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>These are all native OS X apps:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/dress-assistant/id412648913?mt=12">Dress Assistant</a></li>
<li><a href="http://easeintotheswitch.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/mac-os-x-leopard-time-machine2-1024x640.png">Time Machine</a></li>
<li><a href="http://images.ientrymail.com/webpronews/article_pics/twitter-for-mac.jpg">Twitter for Mac</a></li>
</ul>

<p>I also think they all fly in the face of UX consistency within a system GUI, which I think is one of the things people bitch about with non-native apps.</p></li>
<li><p>The definition of &#8220;native&#8221; is really fuzzy here. it seems like you mean &#8220;uses the GUI toolkit that ships with the OS.&#8221; By this definition, though, I&#8217;d argue that many popular OS X apps are not &#8220;native,&#8221; even though they&#8217;re Cocoa apps. On Linux, Gnome and KDE apps are both &#8220;native,&#8221; but they certainly don&#8217;t look the same.</p></li>
<li><p>Some of your examples of people wanting native apps are people simply liking an app better because it&#8217;s designed better, and provides a consistent aesthetic with the rest of their desktop. That can and is often accomplished independent of the SDK you use. &#8220;Native&#8221; is not in any way synonymous with &#8220;better,&#8221; but lots of people toss it out there as if the argument is so obvious, it needs not be explained. It&#8217;s a lot like saying &#8220;it scales.&#8221;</p></li>
<li><p>Cross platform and &#8220;native&#8221; aren&#8217;t necessarily mutually exclusive. It&#8217;s harder, yes, but not impossible. there are tons of variables involved, and I think you&#8217;re oversimplifying a pretty complex problem.</p></li>
<li><p>Cross platform is not, by definition, user-hostile. It <em>can</em> be harder to file off the rough edges, depending on the dev platform and the application, but I think that&#8217;s a matter of UX effort.</p></li>
<li><p>IME, &#8220;Native&#8221; UIs matter way less to users on mobile. Like, unless it looks like a fucking turd and totally nonfunctional, most users don&#8217;t care. Is it relatively smooth to navigate? Bonus. Spaz webOS is, from what I can tell, probably the most popular Twitter client on webOS. Why? Because it&#8217;s free. You know how many of my users have praised it for using &#8220;native&#8221; widgets, for the most part? Like 4, and they are all ultranerds.</p></li>
<li><p>Many (most?) of the AIR apps I&#8217;ve seen really should just be web apps, because there&#8217;s no great benefit to them being desktop apps.</p></li>
<li><p>Why are we okay with using some web apps if it&#8217;s such a huge issue? I prefer to use Gmail&#8217;s web interface, for example, and I prefer to use Google Reader in a SSB &#8212; although with a custom theme. Is it just that my expectations are different?</p></li>
<li><p>I think for many teams, like the one you mention, the choices are probably these (pick one):</p>

<ol>
<li>a really strong web app (that might not support some browsers)</li>
<li>a cross-platform app based on web tech (devs can use existing skills)</li>
<li>a native app for a single platform &#8212; probably not OS X.</li>
</ol>

<p>Which do you choose? I guarantee you that for a company like Pandora, it does not make financial sense to do native Windows and OS X clients. Folks who 1. care and 2. would pay are grey-bearded unicorns in the grand scheme of things.</p></li>
<li><p>So why don&#8217;t devs want to do native apps? I&#8217;d argue it&#8217;s because <em>it&#8217;s too hard</em>, especially when you need to support multiple platforms with widely varying capabilities. If you want better integration with the rest of the devices, make it easier for the people driving new app dev to do so. Asking them to jump from JavaScript to ObjC is not something most will swallow, and the trend is not going to reverse back to devs doing lower-level coding. Some types of applications will always require it, but many (most!) won&#8217;t. A high-level language like JavaScript (especially with the work that&#8217;s been done to speed it up) with hooks into a fast GUI toolkit (not the DOM) is, I believe, where we should be headed.</p></li>
</ul>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2469" data-url-title="notes-on-shortchanging-your-business-with-user-hostile-platforms">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7474" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">JulesLt</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>
		<div class="comment-date">01/17/2011 11:50:09 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>I think you’re right that ‘native’ is a slightly over-rated term, but there’s definitely something in Alex’s post.</p>

<p>Huawei could definitely have done better than the appalling client they rebadged for telcos, considering the millions of units sold. (At the most trivial level, the version I have was shipped with log4j debug settings left on, let alone the higher level problems). I don’t think Java was to blame, so much as a symptom - of aiming low - and achieving your goal.</p>

<p>The other problem is when developers clearly just don’t get that there are standard keyboard shortcuts people expect to use. I can’t recall what it is, but there is one program I have that doesn’t offer a keyboard shortcut for quit. That’s ‘user-hostile’ in my book, but I don’t think it’s intentional, so much as born out of ignorance. And that’s as true for Windows native applications as anything else – in the 2 decades I’ve been doing commercial development, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a company give any formal training in those aspects of development, or into a test plan.</p>

<p>You are probably right that on mobile this may not be an issue - but I think that’s largely because there isn’t yet a consistent vocabulary that users are used to.</p>

<p>(Although I can think of one example - someone developing x-platform native clients for iOS and Android, but who only understands iOS, may miss the possibilities of the application-as-a-service architecture in Android, being used to application-as-a-silo).</p>

<p>It’s certainly an issue with web apps – I completely surprised a colleague of mine by dragging-and-dropping within a Flex application, because he didn’t know you could do it, and he’d ‘trained’ himself not to drag’n’drop inside the browser window. People don’t expect keyboard shortcuts in web apps either, especially where the logical key has a browser level meaning. How should CTRL-A work?</p>

<p>Of course that is irrelevant to the 95% of users who never use any shortcuts at all &#8230; but it feels like a step backwards at times.</p>

<p>A good x-platform GUI toolkit won&#8217;t give you any of that -
it&#8217;s about understanding the platforms you are working with, and expectations of users. Which I OK, because most of them have low expectations!</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7476" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Nick Carter</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://thynctank.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">01/18/2011 12:46:40 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Finally got around to reading both of these posts. Or at least Alex&#8217;s edited post. Parts of his post speaks to the UX snob in me, and this post mostly to the pragmatist, both from a dev and a user perspective. I think overall performance and those consistent keyboard shortcuts are super-important, way moreso than consistent-looking widgets. But that&#8217;s just me.</p>

<p>I do think AIR in particular has its annoyances, particularly the two-step install and confusingly separate runtime. Most users won&#8217;t understand or care about this space/bandwidth-saving maneuver at all, they just know it&#8217;s odd. Likewise, the need to sign apps with expensive certs or face warning dialogs presented to your users is a real shame, particularly when OSS could (did?) have so much to do with the uptake of AIR in the first place.</p>

<p>Titanium is a step in the right direction, with the ability to package the runtime with the app, greater entrenchment in terms of system access, and on mobile, those native widgets (dubious though their importance may be).</p>

<p>So long as developers can present the important bits of an application in such a way as to please their most important/abundant consumers, everything else - consistent UI, toolchains and languages all - is absolutely unimportant.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>
</div>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Choosing a Framework for Cross-platform Mobile App Development"
url_title: building-cross-platform-mobile-apps
permalink: building-cross-platform-mobile-apps.html
tags: "javascript, mobile, apps, cross-platform"
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2011-01-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2467
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/carnero/4728435040/" title="Five Mobile Systems"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1394/4728435040_3ca0669ec2.jpg" alt="Five Mobile Systems" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/carnero/4728435040/">Photo by carnero</a></div>

<p>A friend of mine asked me today:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>I have my own idea for a mobile and desktop app.</p>
  
  <p>Would you have any recommendation on what SDKs to use? I&#8217;d like to use as few as possible and get cross platform as possible. The app is simple, it basically connects to a web service, gets data, and makes charts.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I get this kind of question a lot, so I thought I&#8217;d share what I wrote to him:</p>

<p>There are a couple options for app frameworks, and on one framework there are a bunch of options for UI/DOM frameworks.</p>

<p>First off, the cross-platform mobile frameworks I know about are JavaScript-based. I know at least one which is game-oriented and uses Lua, but it doesn&#8217;t sound like you&#8217;re doing game dev.  So, you&#8217;ll need to be doing your work in JS at least, and possibly JS/HTML/CSS.</p>

<p>There are really two solid options I see for locally-installed apps:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><a href="http://www.appcelerator.com/products/titanium-mobile-application-development/">Appcelerator Titanium Mobile</a>: focuses on native-looking apps; essentially a JavaScript bridge to the native platform on iOS and Android. They&#8217;re close to having Blackberry available too. This works well if you really need to use truly native UI widgets and only need those top 2-3 platforms, and/or need deeper integration into native APIs.</p></li>
<li><p><a href="http://www.phonegap.com/">PhoneGap</a>: Basically a packager that takes a webkit browser app and encapsulates it into a package to install locally on your device. Has <a href="http://www.phonegap.com/about">much wider support for different platforms</a>, but only hooks into the most common native APIs. Also doesn&#8217;t provide any kind of UI toolkit &#8212; it&#8217;s all Webkit, so you make your own choices for a DOM framework. Mobile web frameworks to look at include <a href="http://joapp.com/">Jo</a>, <a href="http://xuijs.com/">xui</a>, <a href="http://www.sencha.com/products/touch/">Sencha Touch</a>, <a href="http://jquerymobile.com/">jQuery Mobile</a>, <a href="http://www.jqtouch.com/">jQTouch</a>, and others.  Or, you just build it yourself with custom HTML/CSS/JS.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Hope that helps!</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Contribute to Spaz webOS, Get a Free Palm Pre Plus"
url_title: contribute-to-spaz-webos-get-a-free-palm-pre-plus
permalink: contribute-to-spaz-webos-get-a-free-palm-pre-plus.html
tags: "spaz, webos, palm, pre, javascript"
published: true
category:
- AIR
- My Projects
- JavaScript
- jQuery
- Spaz
- webOS
date: 2010-06-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2465
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mbiebusch/4733437831/" title="Palm Pre"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1341/4733437831_ee8d50131c.jpg" alt="Palm Pre" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mbiebusch/4733437831/">Photo by mbiebusch</a></div>

<p>Our move to using oAuth for authentication in Spaz is going well. Many people have stepped up to help get the <a href="http://github.com/funkatron/spazcore">SpazCore</a> libraries working, and <a href="http://github.com/funkatron/spaz-desktop-air">Spaz Desktop</a> has been updated to use the new authentication methods, both in the 0.8 branch and master.</p>

<p>However, <a href="http://github.com/funkatron/spaz-webos">Spaz webOS</a> still hasn&#8217;t had work done on it to get oAuth working. July 16th is the Twitter Basic Auth cutoff, so we don&#8217;t have much time.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s the big news: <strong>Palm has donated Palm Pre Plus phones for AT&amp;T for me to GIVE AWAY to the top 3 contributors to Spaz webOS from now until July 12</strong>. That&#8217;s the day (I believe) we <em>need</em> to submit Spaz webOS to Palm for review, so it can be ready by the 16th.</p>

<p>So, you want a free phone? Get your ass in gear. Download the SDK now: 
<a href="http://bit.ly/duAHNg">http://bit.ly/duAHNg</a></p>

<p>To get through Palm&#8217;s review process, I believe we need to submit by July 12th. So before then, two things need to happen in Spaz webOS:</p>

<ul>
<li>Twitter accounts need to use oAuth to authenticate, using xAuth to exchange username/password for auth keys initially </li>
<li>Image uploaders need to use oAuth Echo to post </li>
</ul>

<p>We&#8217;ve already accomplished this in the Spaz Desktop 0.8 branch, so doing it in webOS is very doable. Whether it gets done in time is up to you. I am <a href="http://twitter.com/funkatron">on Twitter</a>, available via email, and in #spaz on irc.freenode.net regularly to answer any questions.</p>

<p>Palm has been a major supporter of open source, and Spaz is (AFAICT)  the only open source microblogging client available on the platform. Help me keep it going, please.</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Building the Future of Spaz"
url_title: building-the-future-of-spaz
permalink: building-the-future-of-spaz.html
tags: "spaz, javascript, foss, open source, roadmap, planning, twitter, statusnet"
published: true
category:
- AIR
- My Projects
- JavaScript
- Mobile
- The Web Problem
- Spaz
- webOS
date: 2010-04-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2464
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/bostworld/2152048526/" title="1975: And the Changes To Come"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2130/2152048526_0e810f6cc1.jpg" alt="1975: And the Changes To Come" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/bostworld/2152048526/">Photo by dbostrom</a></div>

<p>Spaz has been around a long time: since early 2007, which I think makes it 77 in Internet Years.  It&#8217;s been a while since I started playing with the Twitter API in RealBasic, and later under AIR after I saw the Pownce desktop client and wanted to make my app look cool like it.</p>

<p>A lot has happened since then. A lot of cool stuff with Spaz, and lot of cool stuff for me, and a lot of sometimes cool and sometimes not so cool stuff with Twitter. Now we have a desktop client, still on AIR, and a native mobile client for webOS. Spaz isn&#8217;t SUPAR POPULAR, and it&#8217;s not proved to be anything but a giant time and money sinkhole, but it&#8217;s been a very fun ride.</p>

<p>Through all of this, Spaz has stuck with open technologies: JavaScript, HTML and CSS. We&#8217;ve done so because we&#8217;re dedicated to true openness and transparency. The Spaz Statement of Purpose spells out the project&#8217;s reason for being. And in the light of Twitter&#8217;s moves to make the microblogging client scene more of a closed monoculture<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" rel="footnote">1</a></sup>, the significance of Spaz as a counter to closed technologies is greater than ever.</p>

<p>After some recent events &#8211; a big career move for me, some horseshit policy changes by Apple, and some disappointing moves by Twitter &#8211;&#160;I decided we needed to assess where Spaz is headed. So, like any good open source project guy, I went to IRC: I called a meeting on Freenode in #spaz. Turnout was encouraging, and we made some important decisions.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s what&#8217;s going to happen:</p>

<h3>Most urgent: implementation of OAuth/xAuth by June 1</h3>

<p>In June, Twitter is shutting off HTTP Basic Auth support. For client apps to function, they <em>must</em> start using OAuth or xAuth. Spaz Desktop has been approved to use xAuth, an OAuth variant where the user enters their username and password, and the server exchanges these for an OAuth access token. This means we can support a more typical user experience, but don&#8217;t have to store credentials anywhere &#8212; we just store the access token.</p>

<p>Earlier this week I added support in the SpazCore Twitter library to authenticate with an OAuth access token instead of Basic Auth. This should allow apps using SpazCore to use either Basic Auth (for systems that still support it, like StatusNet) or OAuth/xAuth. Much more needs to be done, though, to get Spaz Desktop and Mobile ready.</p>

<h3>Short term: get Spaz Desktop 0.10 out the door in June</h3>

<p>The Spaz 0.9 branch, which is the development branch for 0.10, has been stuck in dev for far too long. The codebase has been refactored considerably, and a number of cool features either have been implemented or are planned, but it needs to actually get ready and usable. We need a push, and assistance from a number of motivated folks who are willing to put the time in. Our <a href="https://spaz.lighthouseapp.com/projects/32566-spaz/milestones/current">0.10 milestone entry on spaz.lighthouseapp.com</a> outlines the various tasks that need to be completed.</p>

<h3>Longer term:</h3>

<h4>1. Move Spaz Desktop from AIR to Titanium Desktop by October 2010</h4>

<p>I&#8217;ve been a big fan of Appcelerator&#8217;s Titanium for a long time, and their Desktop product offers a compelling alternative to AIR for these reasons:</p>

<ul>
<li>Titanium is a true open platform: open source with a liberal license</li>
<li>JavaScript is fully a first-class citizen in terms of language support<sup id="fnref:2"><a href="#fn:2" rel="footnote">2</a></sup></li>
<li>Titanium allows leveraging Ruby, Python or PHP</li>
<li>Better Linux support</li>
<li>Web Worker support</li>
<li>Full interaction with external processes</li>
<li>Native installers for each supported platform that includes the runtime</li>
</ul>

<p>The big knock I see against Titanium is poor documentation, and that&#8217;s something I really hope Appcelerator works to rectify.</p>

<p>All in all, though, Titanium is a better fit for us, technology and philosophy-wise. Porting to Titanium is probably about 20 hours of work as it stands now.</p>

<h4>2. Start development of web-based mobile/tablet client</h4>

<p>I really like powerful mobile devices, and I really like multitouch tablet devices like the iPad. What I don&#8217;t like are the restrictions being placed on developers by companies that refuse to be transparent about their policies. I think the way around that is to make a great mobile/multitouch web app.</p>

<p>A web app will also make Spaz available to all devices with mobile webkit browsers. It would run on Android, Palm webOS, and likely BlackBerry and Nokia devices (I&#8217;m not super familiar with those, but I believe they have webkit browsers now or will soon).</p>

<p>While Spaz will be a hosted web application, it will still be FOSS, and anyone would be able to get the source and set up their own install. In this sense, it would be an interesting complement to StatusNet.</p>

<p>If folks are motivated to create native clients for their preferred devices, that&#8217;s definitely a possibility &#8212; either with a wrapper system like PhoneGap, or a native UI system like Titanium Mobile. It just would not be, at least initially, a primary goal.</p>

<p>What about webOS? Not sure right now. It requires dedicated folks who will keep up with it. Nick Carter has helped a lot, but we need more help, and/or we need to leverage the stuff we do in the web-based mobile client. That may necessitate moving away from Mojo as a framework, though. Palm&#8217;s dev relations team has indicated that they are interested in making web apps first class on their system, though, and I suspect they&#8217;ll have some interesting stuff to make that possible.</p>

<h4>3. Target StatusNet as a top-tier service</h4>

<p>StatusNet has always been a favorite service of mine. They match our principles, and I think Spaz as a FOSS client and StatusNet as a FOSS service complement each other well. StatusNet needs better clients, and I think Spaz is decently positioned to be a part of that. So, I think we should create a StatusNet API library to support any StatusNet-specific features available, and implement support for this in Spaz.</p>

<p>We should also consider other services, like Facebook and RSS feeds. The first step would be developing SpazCore libraries for these.</p>

<h3>How to help</h3>

<p>If you&#8217;re interested in helping with Spaz, here&#8217;s what you can do:</p>

<ul>
<li>Read our <a href="http://help.getspaz.com/faqs/general-25/statement-of-purpose">Statement of Purpose</a> and <a href="http://help.getspaz.com/faqs/general-25/diversity">Diversity Statement</a></li>
<li>Read <a href="http://help.getspaz.com/faqs/general-25/contribute">&#8220;How Can I Participate in the Spaz Project?&#8221;</a></li>
<li>Talk to us about what you&#8217;re interested in doing</li>
<li>Make a commitment to putting in a certain amount of time every week. Even a half-hour a week helping with user support is a <em>big</em> help.</li>
</ul>

<p>You don&#8217;t have to be a programmer. We will work with you to learn new skills. All you have to be is interested in building something cool with us.</p>

<div class="footnotes">
<hr />
<ol>

<li id="fn:1">
<p>Reducing choice is one of the reasons (maybe the primary reason) for Twitter&#8217;s purchase and repackaging of Tweetie as The Official iPhone Client. As Tweetie&#8217;s source is unlikely to be released, it does seem that we&#8217;re reducing choice and becoming less open/more closed. That isn&#8217;t necessarily their goal, but it&#8217;s a consequence.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

<li id="fn:2">
<p>Adobe has, as an organization, not demonstrated that they consider JavaScript as important as Flash within AIR. Feel free to search this blog to find more on the subject.&#160;<a href="#fnref:2" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

</ol>
</div>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "My Friend Twitter"
url_title: my-friend-twitter
permalink: my-friend-twitter.html
tags: "twitter, personal, developer, community"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Development
date: 2010-04-10
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2463
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/magisterludi/405224443/" title="Molly: A Dog With A Lot On Her Mind"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/160/405224443_0603b19d78.jpg" alt="Molly: A Dog With A Lot On Her Mind" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/magisterludi/405224443/">Photo by Miscpix</a></div>

<p>This is going to make two blog posts in a row that are &#8220;off the cuff&#8221; for me. This one particularly so, because it involves a lot of emotion, and not a lot of certainty. There are some arguments to be made, but most of it is about how I feel. That&#8217;s something that&#8217;s hard to justify logically; it just is.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve been frustrated with Twitter regarding how it relates to its developer community for several months now. My perspective might be different from some folks, I think, because I&#8217;ve been a part of that community for a long time. The Twitter Dev Talk Google Group <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/twitter-development-talk/members?start=0&amp;sort=type">shows me</a> as joining on March 15, 2007. I remember being proud that I was asked to be a moderator for the group; it felt good to be both friends with some folks at Twitter, and a &#8220;Friend of Twitter&#8221; as someone from the company referred to me and a few others once.</p>

<p>It felt good because Twitter really seemed to make an effort to be open and transparent with their development community. We were part of what helped them get off the ground &#8212; not the biggest part by any means, but a part. At the time, the vibe I got from Twitter was that they were a group of people trying to build Cool Stuff. I liked that because I like building Cool Stuff too, for the sake of building it. It felt like it was being built by guys who had the same passion for making things that I do. I would hear that they really liked what I was doing in creating an open source, multi-platform client for Twitter; that it was important to have options like that.</p>

<p>Over the years I often found myself defending Twitter&#8217;s API team when folks would air their own frustrations. Some of those frustrations were valid, and some of them were based on really unrealistic expectations. I often said that it was foolish to build a business on top of Twitter, because (except in very rare circumstances) there was no guarantee of any service level of API feature permanence. Things were often pretty spotty back then in terms of uptime and performance; that frustrated a lot of people. But I had their back, ya know? I was a Friend.</p>

<p>Things grew, and things changed. That&#8217;s not really surprising at all. I&#8217;m happily naive of most things related to VC investment, but I suppose to keep up with all the traffic Twitter got as it became more popular, they needed money to pay for services and hire people. If you aren&#8217;t making any money, you need to ask people to give it to you. And now you have to worry about what they want, too.</p>

<p>In the past year or so, it felt like I was seeing a shift in how Twitter related to its developers. People move around in a big company, and that was surely part of it &#8211; I didn&#8217;t know all the New Dudes. And I had really withdrawn from the dev mailing list, because I was tired of dealing with spam and talking about uptime and downtime and social graphs and pagination limits.</p>

<p>But it got weirder when they announced <a href="chirp.twitter.com/">Chirp</a>, their &#8220;official developer conference.&#8221; Doing this event made sense, but I felt like some of their choices about who was speaking didn&#8217;t. I didn&#8217;t see guys like <a href="http://twitter.com/doctorlinguist">Cameron Kaiser</a>, <a href="http://twitter.com/abraham">Abraham Williams</a>, <a href="http://twitter.com/marco">Marco Kaiser</a>, <a href="http://twitter.com/jazzychad">JazzyChad</a>, or <a href="http://twitter.com/dacort">Damon Cortesi</a> listed as speakers. Instead, I saw execs, pundits, and VC investors.</p>

<p>Now I&#8217;ve been to a lot of developer conferences, both as an attendee and a speaker. And I&#8217;ve never seen a speaker lineup so devoid of actual developers. Anyone who knows me, knows that I generally believe pundits and VC investors (and execs to some extent) to be moronic at best, and pure evil at worst &#8212; corrupting the purity and passion for Making Cool Stuff.</p>

<p>Then there was how some stuff was handled. When Chirp was first announced in late January, before the speaker lineup was finalized, I inquired about speaking there myself. A friend suggested I talk about my experiences as an open source dev, and this seemed like a pretty darn good idea &#8211;&#160;I wanted to talk about <a href="http://opensourcebridge.org/proposals/293">what I&#8217;d learned, what motivates us as developers, and how we define success</a>. So I made an official inquiry, and was told by a Twitter employee that they&#8217;d look into it and get back to me soon. I didn&#8217;t hear anything for a couple weeks, so I sent a follow-up, and was told that things were filling up on the main day (well, that&#8217;s why I asked early!) but that there might be an unconference opportunity. There&#8217;d be a public announcement about it in March.</p>

<p>Well, the conference is on April 15th. Not knowing until March what might happen is just not enough time to plan. And to buy a $450 ticket, and then hotel in SF, and then airfare; I just couldn&#8217;t afford that. Of course, it turns out that cheaper, hackday-only tickets would be made available, but these weren&#8217;t released until March 30, 15 days before the conference<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" rel="footnote">1</a></sup>. Far too short notice, and by this time the speaker lineup described above was set, which indicated to me that this wasn&#8217;t a conference for developers like me.</p>

<p>So in this, I saw a pretty big chasm between where I was, and where Twitter was. Before then I hadn&#8217;t quite realized what it was like, but this kinda dumped on me like a ton of bricks.  Getting a bit of the runaround hurt my ego, for sure, and that&#8217;s part of it. I don&#8217;t really think that&#8217;s a good reason to get upset, but I did feel like I had a longstanding relationship with Twitter, and through this, and the way Chirp was being presented, I didn&#8217;t feel like this was the same organization I&#8217;d interacted with for the past three years.</p>

<p>And, well, it wasn&#8217;t. They used to have 6 employees, and now they&#8217;re over 140. Duh.</p>

<p>So with all that, then we have Twitter dropping an enormous bombshell yesterday on their dev community, by creating official clients for both BlackBerry and iPhone. Twitter had done a few things before to add services that had previously been handled by third parties, but in general they&#8217;d had a very hands-off approach with the dev community, sticking with their core features and letting developers handle stuff like url shortening, photo uploading, and &#8212; most significantly &#8212; all non-web clients.  Twitter has enjoyed a very diverse, very organic community of applications and services. Client apps that serve as primary user tools for interacting with Twitter are a very large part of that community. Twitter&#8217;s moves in that space have suddenly and dramatically changed the playing field for all of them.<sup id="fnref:2"><a href="#fn:2" rel="footnote">2</a></sup></p>

<p>There was no warning, and there were no apologies. No statements made to developers that Twitter knew this was going to impact a lot of them; no attempt to unruffle feathers or explain how this was what Twitter needed to do as a company. We did get a couple notes on the dev list, but they could be summed up as follows: <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/twitter-development-talk/browse_thread/thread/191bd3c3725de321">&#8220;it happened, now find other things to do.&#8221;</a>  That&#8217;s what angered me more than anything last night.</p>

<p>This really isn&#8217;t about my own client, Spaz. Spaz is <em>not</em> popular, and I doubt even having a directly-competing Official Client on desktop or webOS would impact its numbers &#8211;&#160;folks choose Spaz because they like it, and if they don&#8217;t that&#8217;s fine with me.  Spaz exists as an alternative to closed source, commercial apps, and it&#8217;s even MORE important now that it exists, I think.</p>

<p>I guess it&#8217;s about respect. It&#8217;s about a relationship I had, and I think many of us had, with Twitter, that doesn&#8217;t seem to be there anymore. And that&#8217;s frustrating, and disappointing. But mostly I guess it&#8217;s just sad.</p>

<div class="footnotes">
<hr />
<ol>

<li id="fn:1">
<p>Curiously, this wasn&#8217;t announced on the API announcement mailing list or the twitter dev mailing list; in fact, there was very little information about Chirp posted there. Far more information was available on sites like TechCrunch. This made me wonder further at whom this conference was aimed.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

<li id="fn:2">
<p>It would be naive to expect Twitter to not move into other platforms it decides are key to its experience. Or in any other services it decides to do internally. This is a very big reminder that we can only count on something for the term of the contract, and few of us have a contract with Twitter.&#160;<a href="#fnref:2" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

</ol>
</div>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "We&#8217;re the Stupid Ones: Facebook, Google, and Our Failure as Developers"
url_title: were-the-stupid-ones-facebook-google-and-our-failure-as-developers
permalink: were-the-stupid-ones-facebook-google-and-our-failure-as-developers.html
tags: "hci, ux, ui, faceboo, google, readwriteweb, stupid"
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
- Design
date: 2010-02-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2462
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/michiel/4348942883/" title="Be Stupid"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2680/4348942883_4e50fcb522.jpg" alt="Be Stupid" title="Be Stupid" /></a></p>

<div class="photo-credit"><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/michiel/4348942883/">Photo by michiel </a></div>

<p><em>Normally I try to chew on an idea for a post for a few days; it lets me sort out my thoughts and form some kind of thesis. I&#8217;m totally not doing this here, though, so I should preface this with a note that I could be completely off-base. But I don&#8217;t think so.</em></p>

<p><a href="http://speirs.org/blog/2010/1/29/future-shock.html">Discussion about how we interact with computers</a> heated up recently with the introduction of the iPad. Lots of nerdy types (myself included) were frustrated that Apple had introduced not a tablet &#8220;computer,&#8221; but a big iPod Touch. They&#8217;re both computers, of course, but the way we interact with them is different: the modern computer interface uses a multitasking windowing motif, and the iPod/iPad interface is fullscreen and single-task focused.</p>

<p>As a Nerdy Power User, I am well-versed in how to navigate a multitasking interface, and for the most part I understand how and why it works the way it does. I, in fact, enjoy learning about the intricacies of these kinds of systems.  So when I use a single-task interface like that of the iPod Touch, I frequently bash my noggin against the barriers it imposes. Copying a URL from the web browser to my Twitter client takes orders of magnitude longer than it would on OS X or Windows, for example.</p>

<p>What I&#8217;ve learned from interacting with most computer users, though, is that they do not give a rat&#8217;s ass about how computers work. They want to accomplish certain tasks, and will do this in the way that is most sensible and direct for them. And the way they end up accomplishing these tasks within the multitasking window motif is typically not the way <em>I</em> would do it.</p>

<p>The recent fiasco on ReadWriteWeb, where <a href="http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/facebook_wants_to_be_your_one_true_login.php">a RWW article</a> became the first Google result for &#8220;facebook login,&#8221; is a classic example of this. And, unfortunately, so is <a href="http://mattstratton.com/hilarity/hundreds-of-facebook-users-are-apparently-really-dumb">the reaction of most Learned Computer Fellows</a>: one of mockery and derision, admonishing the confused users for being stupid, incompetent, or lazy.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ll admit that I took some glee when I first saw the numerous comments on the article; I love a humorous clusterfuck as much as the next guy. But seeing some of the reactions by the Very Smart Computer People, I began to realize that <strong>We Are Not Getting It</strong>. Consider:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Isn&#8217;t this really a failure of Google? How did it become so easy to game search engine results that an article about Facebook and AOL became the first result for &#8216;facebook login,&#8217; instead of the obvious thing people are actually looking for?</p></li>
<li><p>How is it the fault of the users when we present them with multiple, barely-differentiated text fields within the same window. Is it really surprising that they don&#8217;t understand the differences between each? And is it surprising that they choose to use the one which works with more natural language, rather than entering syntactically-unnatural domain names?</p></li>
<li><p>There is LOADS of anecdotal evidence that most users simply use search engines as a sort of natural language CLI. Shouldn&#8217;t we be designing interfaces that work in the way most natural for the majority of users?</p></li>
</ul>

<p>These people have better things to do with their days than tweaking out the spacing in their browser toolbars. A computer for them is a <em>utility</em>. One that is increasingly complex, and one that is used because it&#8217;s the <strong>only</strong> option for accomplishing certain things &#8211; not because it&#8217;s a good option.</p>

<p>It&#8217;s kind of like the Photoshop Problem: when people want to crop a picture, we give them Photoshop.  Photoshop is a behemoth application with nearly every image editing and touchup function imaginable, and it is <em>terribly</em> complex. Now Photoshop is an impressive tool, but only a very tiny percentage people need the power it offers. The vast majority just want to crop their ex-husband from the photo and let their friends look at it.  But even iPhoto, the poster child for Apps So Easy Your Grandparents Can Use Them, continues to pile on features and complexity.</p>

<p>When folks need an elevator, we should give them an elevator, not an airplane. We&#8217;ve been giving them airplanes for 30 years, and then laughing at them for being too stupid to fly them right.</p>

<p>I think we&#8217;re the stupid ones.</p>

<h3>Update</h3>

<p>As I said at the start, I wrote this piece a bit off the cuff, so upon further review I think I could have made it a bit clearer. First, a couple great rebuttals I read:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://blog.cursingnerds.com/2010/02/reply-to-funkatrons-analysis-of.html">Reply to Funkatron&#8217;s Analysis of the RWW/Facebook Debacle of 2010</a></li>
<li><a href="http://philcrissman.com/2010/02/16/no-were-not-the-stupid-ones">No, We&#8217;re Not The Stupid Ones</a></li>
</ul>

<p>I posted a comment on Phil Crissman&#8217;s blog, which I think explains a bit further what I&#8217;m thinking, and addresses the notion that some learning may still be required. To copy and paste myself:</p>

<p>I certainly don&#8217;t think that the computer can become (anytime soon) a magic box that determines our whims, nor do I think that people shouldn&#8217;t have to learn some things.</p>

<p>What I do think is that the current interface modern OSes on computers provide is simply overwhelming for most users, to the point that it&#8217;s very challenging to learn how to accomplish tasks without a very significant investment of time. Driving would be a good example of a task that does require investment of time, but is not so overwhelming that the vast majority of people fundamentally get it wrong: you don&#8217;t see people steering with their feet, or accelerating and braking with the radio. I&#8217;d argue that modern computer interfaces, in a rush to offer flexibility and capability, make it possible to steer with your hands, feet, teeth, and knees &#8212; and don&#8217;t make it particularly clear which one is best.</p>

<h3>Update 2</h3>

<p>Some more responses:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.wolerized.com/blog/remi-woler/really-are-we-idiots">Really? Are we the idiots?</a></li>
<li><a href="http://jonoscript.wordpress.com/2010/02/18/some-people-cant-read-urls/">Some People Can&#8217;t Read URLs</a></li>
</ul>

<p>Feel free to forward me others; I think I&#8217;ve given up trying to track them down for now.</p>

<p>Your point is well taken. Power features for power users.</p>

<p>The problem is, how to tell which a particular user will be? Kids in particular should have the ability to &#8220;dig deeper.&#8221;  What concerns me isn&#8217;t that the ipod  or the ipad is too simple, it&#8217;s that if it&#8217;s the only computing device that someone grows up WITH how do they learn to manipulate the cybersphere from a position of control AT ALL?</p>

	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7125" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Rich Rosen</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://www.neurozen.com/website/</div>
		<div class="comment-date">02/15/2010 10:42:19 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>You have a divide in the software development world as entrenched as the current divisions in the political world. There is the &#8220;make it as flexible as possible&#8221; camp and the &#8220;keep it simple&#8221; camp. The former is represented by the open source development community, cramming as much functionality into what they build as inhumanly impossible, giving developers more  options than they could ever possibly use in a lifetime, making it just as difficult to do something commonplace as it would be to do something complex. The  latter camp is represented by commercial software vendors like Microsoft who push componentized solutions that offer supposed out-of-the-box simplicity but make anything beyond the simplistic nearly impossible to achieve. Ideally, we could build software development platforms that still make simple things simple but simultaneously enable more sophisticated tasks in a methodical way. But we don&#8217;t do that. Instead we have as our alternatives either overly complex open source APIs with steep learning curves or simplistic componentized platforms not capable of much beyond the trivial.</p>

<p>The point being: if we as software developers can&#8217;t find the happy medium between &#8220;keeping the simple things simple&#8221; and &#8220;enabling the complex in a methodical way&#8221; for ourselves, how can we expect to write programs, webapps, and user interfaces that achieve that happy medium for end-users?</p>
</div>
	</li>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>I recently read an editorial on Engadget (http://www.engadget.com/2010/01/27/editorial-engadget-on-the-ipad/) where a dozen or so of their staff - &#8216;journalist&#8217; would be too kind a term - gleefully explain how the iPod is not for them.</p>

<p>Of course it&#8217;s not for them. It&#8217;s for everyone in the known universe who doesn&#8217;t read or care about Engadget, its readers and the products it follows. It&#8217;s for all the people out there who want less computing in their lives and not more.</p>

The billions of people who just want to share pictures of their grandchildren and book tickets for a movie.</p>

<p>In short it&#8217;s for normal people, and they&#8217;re in the majority. We, the developers, designers, content creators and enthusiasts have to understand that we are not normal computer users. We&#8217;re the modern-day equivalent of the auto mechanic, the kit-car fan, or the tuning enthusiast and we&#8217;re sorely outnumbered, by both the young and the old who just want computing to be easier. <p>I can&#8217;t see why the computer industry has such a hard time understanding this.</p>

	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7155" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Mark Hernandez</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>
		<div class="comment-date">02/16/2010 09:06:09 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Excellent observations Ed!  This web-wide discussion really reveals people&#8217;s critical thinking skills, or the lack thereof.  It&#8217;s fascinating.  I love it.</p>

<p>But get this&#8230; I&#8217;ve been thinking about the old-school premise that it&#8217;s the Marketing Department that should determine what a product should or shouldn&#8217;t do related to optimizing sales.  Stop and think about coming at it from that angle and this discussion gets even more interesting.  AMD (Apple&#8217;s Marketing Department, uh, Steve Jobs?) sees a vast sea of untapped customers -&gt; the non-geeks and tinkerers we&#8217;re talking about here.  They want to optimize for that market.</p>

<p>The iPhone has multitasked from day one, but only under Apple&#8217;s control.  People usually cite the desire to play Pandora in the background while doing something else.  But the AMD says no, we want you to play our iTunes content in the background.</p>

<p>Push Notifications is a brilliant device to delay the need for free-for-all app multitasking and retain control of the interface.  Apple also made it so you don&#8217;t have to leave an app by providing developers with access to the camera, music, photos, contacts, email, maps, the web, etc, delaying the need for multitasking further still.</p>

<p>And is the iPad&#8217;s lovely design faithful and true to the ideal of human-computer interaction, or is it also meeting the goals of the AMD as well?</p>

<p>We have a choice, and the half-dozen existing free-for-all mobile interfaces give the tinkerers what they want, at a cost (e.g. app store spam).  But I&#8217;m glad there&#8217;s at least one company that&#8217;s being a butthole about NOT putting out just another free-for-all environment, whether it&#8217;s for an ideal or for a dollar, or both.</p>

<p>And now everyone&#8217;s all ooh-ahh about Windows Phone 7 Series (gotta stop and chuckle for a minute) but in the coming months it&#8217;s fundamental flaws will be revealed and it will, again, be another interface for young people, I suspect.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7156" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Jubal</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>
		<div class="comment-date">02/16/2010 09:52:00 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>I&#8217;ve been nerding around computers for most of my life, and I&#8217;ve started using Google as my URL bar. Why? It requires less thought. And that is precisely all the reason I need.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m ready for my flying cars and personal jetpacks and computing interfaces as simple as toasters. I just don&#8217;t want to bust out the CLI  when I&#8217;m questing for information.</p>

<p>Please, make it simpler for the average Joe to find what he&#8217;s looking for. That does mean writing software to the lowest common denominator&#8212; but it doesn&#8217;t mean the audience is necessarily as stupid as a sack of hammers. Would you ask your local baker or carpenter to put up with virus- and adware-infested cheap-ass Windows machines, and still mock them for trying a notional shortcut of using a browser&#8217;s search bar to get to the Google home page?</p>

<p>Hell, I&#8217;ve done that too.</p>

<p>Designing computing interfaces is <em>hard</em>, and especially when the target is inching toward simplicity but still requires a silly amount of use cases behind the curtain. But that&#8217;s where we&#8217;re headed&#8230;. no two ways about it. So let&#8217;s live up to the challenge.</p>
</div>

	<li class="comment">
		<a name="7157" class="comment-id anchor"></a>

		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>It is valuable for readers to be able to choose their level of engagement &#8212; with a book or article, with software.</p>

<p>With a book, this means formatting it so it can be easily skimmed.</p>

<p>With software, this means being able to find the most common operations easily and choose whether (and when) to move to the more complex operations. Photoshop Elements is a good compromise between power and simplicity.</p>

<p>Microsoft&#8217;s approach using customizable tool bars, however, strikes me as awkward &#8212; replacing flexibility with a  confusing interface where changes have mainly eccentric significance. It is a difficult thing, offering both stability and flexibility.</p>

<p>One of the needs of users is to have commands stay in place (Stay!) and not appear and disappear or move around in different documents.</p>

<p>This is as it should be. You&#8217;re the one with a job in the industry. They&#8217;re the end users who pay for your expertise. If someone&#8217;s got to find computers and software interesting for their own sake, better it should be you.</p>

Lit. and Cinema majors who keep a professional eye on your entertainment don&#8217;t forget that you want a decent, fast-moving story and some good lines of dialogue, and that the cook at your local restaurant doesn&#8217;t go hog-wild with organ meats and obscure vegetables.</p>
