---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Change is coming to Spaz"
url_title: change-is-coming-to-spaz
permalink: change-is-coming-to-spaz.html
tags: "spaz, AIR, titanium, appcelerator, mobile, twitter, css"
published: true
category:
- AIR
- My Projects
- JavaScript
- Spaz
date: 2009-02-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2442
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/gregmelia/2277690112/"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2380/2277690112_5590cf2923.jpg" alt="&quot;Change is coming&quot;" /></a></p>

<p>As I&#8217;ve mentioned in the past, I&#8217;m currently working on a new project that&#8217;s been taking my time away from <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a>. While most details are still under wraps, I can say now that the new project is a version of Spaz for mobile devices. Rather than a port, this is a whole new codebase that takes advantage of all the stuff I&#8217;ve learned writing Spaz for AIR.</p>

<p>While I will still be working hard on the mobile app for at least another month, I have been thinking a lot about where the desktop app should be going. Here&#8217;s the plan:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Version 0.8 will be the last version of Spaz using the current codebase. We are currently being held back by the design decisions I made, and they need to be tossed. Versions 0.9 and later will be based on a complete rewrite of the codebase. It will use an MVC-style pattern, and will be powered by the SpazCore component library. SpazCore being worked on now, and is hosted on GitHub at <a href="http://github.com/funkatron/spazcore/">http://github.com/funkatron/spazcore/</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>I may switch from the AIR platform to Titanium for the new Spaz codebase. I am still weighing this decision, but I&#8217;m very interested in TI, especially after having the opportunity to meet the development team last week. They have a very strong platform, and their approach is very much in line with the &#8220;Spaz philosophy.&#8221; <a href="http://titaniumapp.com">http://titaniumapp.com</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>Feature-wise, I&#8217;m targeting all<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" rel="footnote">1</a></sup> existing features, plus:</p>

<ul>
<li>multiple instances of the &#8220;main&#8221; windows (basically the current Spaz window, multiple times for multiple accounts)</li>
<li>multiple search windows with auto-updating results</li>
<li>less reliance on the web site for user and message details</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>Spaz should still be very suitable for average Twitter users (under 100 friends), but will also offer powerful search features for folks who need them. And of course, Spaz will still be completely open-source under a New BSD-style license.</p>

<p>Questions? Comments? Post them in <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/spaz-users/browse_thread/thread/51cdd1accb94b6a2">the Google Groups thread</a></p>

<div class="footnotes">
<hr />
<ol>

<li id="fn:1">
<p>Actually, one feature of Spaz that may see a reduction in functionality is theming. Supporting multiple themes in the main release is an <em>enormous</em> pain whenever I need to make an interface change. While I expect it will still be possible to override most or all of the interface with CSS, I will likely shoot for a single good theme to ship with Spaz, and leave modifications as an exercise for the motivated user.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

</ol>
</div>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHP Advent 2008 Post: JSON is Everybody&#8217;s Friend"
url_title: php-advent-2008-post-json-is-everybodys-friend
permalink: php-advent-2008-post-json-is-everybodys-friend.html
tags: "json, php, javascript, ajax, advent"

- JavaScript
- jQuery
- PHP

<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/thomashawk/268524287/" title="Security"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/113/268524287_6d0b9122f7.jpg" alt="Security" /></a></p>

<p><em>Reposting something you wrote is a lot easier than coming up with original content. This article was <a href="http://phpadvent.org/2008/json-is-everybodys-friend-by-ed-finkler">originally posted</a> as part of the <a href="http://phpadvent.org/2008/">2008 PHP Advent Calendar</a></em></p>

<p>Last year I wrote some kind of feel-good, hippie crap for the PHP Advent
Calendar. This year I got a haircut, took a shower, and am ready to tell you
about something practical: working with <a href="http://json.org/">JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)</a>
in PHP.</p>

<p>&#8220;JSON?!&#8221; you cry. &#8220;But that&#8217;s for JavaScript fruitcakes!&#8221; And you&#8217;d be right.
But JSON, while valid JavaScript code, is actually a very effective serialized
data format for exchanging data between applications written in a variety of
languages. And as of PHP 5.2, we have <a href="http://php.net/json"><em>native</em> support for JSON encoding and
decoding</a>.</p>

<h3>But I Love XML!</h3>

<p>Who doesn&#8217;t? The thing is, for moving data around&#8212;not documents, but data&#8212;I
think JSON is superior to XML. This is mainly because JSON tends to map better
to the data models in most programming languages&#8212;arrays, objects, etc. JSON
<em>is</em> serialized JavaScript, so it&#8217;s easy peasy representing these kinds of
things. Moving between JSON and your language&#8217;s internal data models is
usually just a single function call. Smarter people than me can debate the
pros and cons of XML and JSON in various scenarios, but for a lot of what I
do, JSON does the same thing and requires less work.</p>

<h3>Get Your PHP Objects On</h3>

<p>In PHP 5.2+, there are two functions that handle JSON: <a href="http://us2.php.net/manual/en/function.json-encode.php"><code>json_encode()</code></a>,
which takes a PHP data structure and returns a JSON string, and
<a href="http://php.net/manual/en/function.json-decode.php"><code>json_decode()</code></a>, which takes a JSON string and converts it into a PHP
data structure. Let&#8217;s take a look at <code>json_encode()</code> and how it handles
converting a PHP object into JSON:</p>

<pre><code>&amp;lt;?php
// make a simple object
$obj-&gt;body           = 'another post';
$obj-&gt;id             = 21;
$obj-&gt;approved       = true;
$obj-&gt;favorite_count = 1;
$obj-&gt;status         = NULL;

// convert into JSON
$json_obj = json_encode($obj);
echo $json_obj;
</code></pre>

<p>This will output the following JSON string:</p>

<pre><code>{"body":"another post","id":21,"approved":true,"favorite_count":1,"status":null}
</code></pre>

<p>Now, let&#8217;s take that JSON and turn it back into PHP:</p>

<pre><code>// convert back into PHP
$new_obj = json_decode($json_obj);
var_dump($new_obj);
</code></pre>

<p>And we&#8217;ll have the following PHP object:</p>

<pre><code>object(stdClass)#2 (5) {
  ["body"]=&gt;
  string(12) "another post"
  ["id"]=&gt;
  int(21)
  ["approved"]=&gt;
  bool(true)
  ["favorite_count"]=&gt;
  int(1)
  ["status"]=&gt;
  NULL
}
</code></pre>

<p>Notice that the data types are retained in the process. JSON supports strings,
numbers, objects, arrays (kinda), booleans and <code>NULL</code>. Things like methods,
constants, and non-public properties are dropped in the encoding process, as
shown in the example below:</p>

<pre><code>&amp;lt;?php
class Foo {
  const     ERROR_CODE = '404';
  public    $public_ex = 'this is public';
  private   $private_ex = 'this is private!';
  protected $protected_ex = 'this should be protected';

  public function getErrorCode() {
    return self::ERROR_CODE;
  }
}

$foo = new Foo
$foo_json = json_encode($foo
echo $foo_json
</code></pre>

<p>This outputs the following JSON:</p>

<pre><code>{"public_ex":"this is public"}
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that when you decode JSON into a PHP object, the object type is
always <code>stdClass</code>. If we use <code>$foo_json</code> from above&#8230;</p>

<pre><code>$foo_new = json_decode($foo_json);
var_dump($foo_new);
</code></pre>

<p>&#8230;we&#8217;ll get back the following object:</p>

<pre><code>object(stdClass)#4 (1) {
 ["public_ex"]=&gt;
 string(14) "this is public"
}
</code></pre>

<h3>Arrays, Indexed &amp; Associative</h3>

<p>Array support in JSON is limited to <em>indexed</em> arrays&#8212;those with sequential,
numeric keys. Associative arrays are converted into an object with
corresponding properties.</p>

<pre><code>&amp;lt;?php
// here's an indexed array. JSON natively handles these
$arr = array('orange', 'yellow', 'green', 122);
$json_arr = json_encode($arr);
echo $json_arr."\n";
</code></pre>

<p>That gives us this JSON:</p>

<pre><code>["orange","yellow","green",122]
</code></pre>

<p>And we can convert it back into PHP&#8230;</p>

<pre><code>$new_arr = json_decode($json_arr);
var_dump($new_arr);
</code></pre>

<p>&#8230;without losing anything in the process.</p>

<pre><code>array(4) {
  [0]=&gt;
  string(6) "orange"
  [1]=&gt;
  string(6) "yellow"
  [2]=&gt;
  string(5) "green"
  [3]=&gt;
  int(122)
}
</code></pre>

<p>With associative arrays, the array is converted to an object. Also note that
all associative keys are converted into strings in the process:</p>

<pre><code>// associative PHP arrays are converted into objects
$assoc = array('orange'=&gt;'yellow', 'green'=&gt;122, 9=&gt;122);
$json_assoc = json_encode($assoc);
</code></pre>

<p>The encoded JSON will be <code>{"orange":"yellow","green":122,"9":122}</code>. Decoding
<em>that</em> gives us this PHP object:</p>

<pre><code>object(stdClass)#5 (3) {
  ["orange"]=&gt;
  string(6) "yellow"
  ["green"]=&gt;
  int(122)
  ["9"]=&gt;
  int(122)
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can, however, convert the JSON object back into a PHP associative array by passing <code>TRUE</code> as the second param to <code>json_decode()</code> (thanks Richard Orelup).</p>

<h3>Playing Well with Others</h3>

<p>That&#8217;s all fine and good, but it might help to actually do something useful
with all this encodin&#8217; and decodin&#8217;. JSON is a really good choice for moving
data between client-side JavaScript applications and server-side applications,
because JSON <em>is</em> JavaScript code, and maps perfectly onto JavaScript&#8217;s data
structures.</p>

<p>So, let&#8217;s contrive a simple application that passes a &#8220;counter&#8221; object back
and forth between the client and server. The counter object stores information
on how often the PHP server application and the JavaScript client application
&#8220;touch&#8221; it. First, we&#8217;ll make a PHP script to serve up some JSON code to our
JavaScript client. It will look for an <code>action</code> parameter in <code>$_GET</code>, perform
the requested action, and serve up some JSON in return.</p>

<pre><code>&amp;lt;?php
if ($_GET['action'] === "getinit") {

  // make the PHP object and add a PHP touch
  $counter-&gt;php_touches    = 1;
  $counter-&gt;js_touches    = 0;
  send_as_json($counter);

} elseif ($_GET['action'] === "updatedata") {
  // decode JSON
  $counter = json_decode($_POST['counter']);

  // increment php touch counter
  $counter-&gt;php_touches++;

  // serve up as JSON
  send_as_json($counter);

} else {
  send_as_json(false);
}


function send_as_json($obj) {

  // convert object to JSON
  $json = json_encode($obj);

  // set appropriate headers
  header('Content-Type: application/json');

  // output JSON string as body
  echo $json;
}
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>getinit</code> action will create a <code>$counter</code> object, initialize it with a
couple of variables to track &#8220;touches&#8221; by PHP and JSON, and serve up the
object as JSON via the <code>send_as_json()</code> function. The <code>updatedata</code> action will
take JSON from the <code>$_POST</code> array, decode it into the <code>$counter</code> object,
increment the <code>php_touches</code> property, and serve up the modified object as
JSON.</p>

<p>In the <code>send_as_json()</code> function, note the <code>header()</code> call that sets the
<code>Content-Type</code> to <code>application/json</code>. Setting the content type correctly is
good practice, and will sometimes avoid <a href="http://jibbering.com/blog/?p=514">unexpected security issues</a>.</p>

<p>On the client side, we&#8217;ll make a short HTML page with some embedded JavaScript
to interact with our PHP service.</p>

<pre><code>&lt;!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN"
  "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"&gt;
&lt;html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en" lang="en"&gt;
&lt;head&gt;
  &lt;meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"/&gt;
  &lt;title&gt;JSON PHP Example&lt;/title&gt;
  &lt;!-- Load the Google JS libs hosting API --&gt;
  &lt;script src="http://www.google.com/jsapi"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
  &lt;!-- Load the newest jquery major version 1 from Google --&gt;
  &lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8"&gt;
    google.load("jquery", "1");
  &lt;/script&gt;
  &lt;!-- load the JSON2.js parser --&gt;
  &lt;script src="JSON2.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;

  &lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8"&gt;
    var counter;

    function processData(data, textStatus) {
      counter = JSON.parse(data);
      counter.js_touches++;
      $('#js-count').val( parseInt(counter.js_touches));
      $('#php-count').val( parseInt(counter.php_touches));
    }

    // when the DOM is ready, do this stuff
    $(document).ready( function() {
      $.get('jsonphp.php?action=getinit', processData, 'text');
      $('#increment-button').click( function() {
        counter.js_touches = parseInt( $('#js-count').val() );
        counter.php_touches = parseInt( $('#php-count').val() );
        var json = JSON.stringify(counter);
        $.post('jsonphp.php?action=updatedata', { 'counter':json }, processData, 'text');
      });
    });
  &lt;/script&gt;

  &lt;style type="text/css" media="screen"&gt;
    body, input {
      font-family: Baskerville, Georgia, "Times New Roman", serif;
    }
    table {
      border:1px solid #CCC;
      padding:.2em;
      margin: .2em;
    }
    td.label {
      text-align:right;
      font-weight:bold;
    }
  &lt;/style&gt;
&lt;/head&gt;
&lt;body&gt;
  &lt;table&gt;
    &lt;tr&gt;
      &lt;td class="label"&gt;JavaScript Touches:&lt;/td&gt;
      &lt;td&gt;&lt;input type="text" id="js-count" value="0" /&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
    &lt;/tr&gt;
    &lt;tr&gt;
      &lt;td class="label"&gt;PHP Touches:&lt;/td&gt;
      &lt;td&gt;&lt;input type="text" id="php-count" value="0" /&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
    &lt;/tr&gt;
  &lt;/table&gt;
  &lt;form&gt;
    &lt;input type="button" name="increment" value="Increment!" id="increment-button" /&gt;
  &lt;/form&gt;
&lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Rendered in the browser, the page will look something like this:</p>

<p><img src="http://funkatron.com/content/jsonphp.html-screenshot.png" alt="Screenshot" /></p>

<p>Note that we&#8217;re using the jQuery library (loaded from the Google JavaScript
Libraries API) to handle DOM manipulation and Ajax calls. We&#8217;re also using the
JSON2.js parser, available at <a href="http://json.org/json2.js">JSON.org</a>, to safely parse and create JSON.
The default method for decoding JSON into a JavaScript object or array is
<code>eval()</code>, but that leaves us open to <a href="http://funkatron.com/site/comments/safely-parsing-json-in-javascript/">all sorts of code injection issues</a>.</p>

<p>Jumping into our JavaScript code, the <code>$().ready()</code> is the most interesting
portion. The <code>ready()</code> method called on <code>$(document)</code> takes the anonymous
function passed into it, and executes the function as soon as the document is
&#8220;ready&#8221;&#8212;that is, when the DOM is completed and can be safely messed with. So,
when the DOM is ready, two things will happen:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>A <code>GET</code> request is made to <code>jsonphp.php?action=getinit</code>, and the results
are passed as text to the <code>processData()</code> function</p></li>
<li><p>An event listener is assigned to the click event for the button with the
<code>id</code> of <code>increment-button</code>. This listener will fire a function that:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>Grabs the values for the touch counts out of the form fields</p></li>
<li><p>Assigns them to the <code>counter</code> object</p></li>
<li><p>Encodes the <code>counter</code> object as JSON</p></li>
<li><p><code>POST</code>s <code>counter</code> to the server</p></li>
</ol></li>
</ul>

<p>So, each time we click the &#8220;Increment!&#8221; button, the object is sent from the
JavaScript application to the PHP application as JSON. Each side will
increment its own counter in the object, and the JavaScript application will
display those values to us in the page. If we want, we can even change the
values, and the JavaScript application will bind the new values to the object
before sending it to the server.</p>

<h3>What&#8217;s It All Mean, Dave?</h3>

<p>Metaphysically, I have no idea. But practically, JSON support in PHP means
that our favorite server-side language is an even <em>better</em> glue language&#8212;
something it&#8217;s been good at for a long time. Now, go forth and make the next
mega-ajax-crowdsourced-mashup masterpiece.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Safely parsing JSON in JavaScript"
url_title: safely-parsing-json-in-javascript
permalink: safely-parsing-json-in-javascript.html
tags: "json, php, python, parser, eval, codeinjection, security, jquery, ajax, ruby"
published: true
category:
- AIR
- JavaScript
- jQuery
- InfoSec
date: 2008-10-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2439
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/slambo_42/1092945151/" title="Wear safety shoes"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1342/1092945151_8e1d2f6677.jpg" alt="Wear safety shoes" title="Wear safety shoes" /></a></p>

<p>I love me some <a href="http://json.org">JSON</a>. It saves me tons of parsing headaches when exchanging data between web services because it maps so well to concepts shared among most common programming languages. It&#8217;s super easy to take a PHP object, convert it to JSON, and then push it to a Javascript (or a Ruby, or a Python) app.</p>

<p>Because JSON is valid JavaScript code, the most common method for converting it into native JS objects is to just <code>eval</code> the JSON. This is an extremely bad idea, because it opens your app up to all sorts of code injection attacks. Even with &#8220;trusted&#8221; sources, a security failure on your source&#8217;s end, or just a disgruntled employee, could wreak havoc on your apps and your users. I&#8217;d recommend reading <a href="http://yuiblog.com/blog/2007/04/10/json-and-browser-security/">Douglas Crockford&#8217;s &#8220;JSON and Browser Security&#8221;</a>. Go ahead; I&#8217;ll wait. <img src="http://funkatron.com/content/rockanim.gif" alt="Rockford is impatient" /></p>

<p><a href="http://jquery.com">jQuery</a>, which we&#8217;ll use for all our examples because it&#8217;s awesome, will in many cases automatically parse JSON responses for you. This, as we learned above, is a Bad Thing. The following <a href="http://docs.jquery.com/Ajax">Ajax methods</a> will automatically parse JSON in jQ (as of 1.2):</p>

<ul>
<li><code>jQuery.getJSON()</code> &#8211; <em>always</em></li>
<li><code>jQuery.ajax()</code> &#8211; <em>if <code>type</code> is &#8216;json&#8217;</em></li>
<li><code>jQuery.get()</code> &#8211; <em>if <code>type</code> is &#8216;json&#8217;</em></li>
<li><code>jQuery.post()</code> &#8211; <em>if <code>type</code> is &#8216;json&#8217;</em></li>
</ul>

<p>So my rules of thumbs are:</p>

<ol>
<li>never, ever use <code>$.getJSON()</code></li>
<li>never, ever set the <code>type</code> option to &#8216;json.&#8217;</li>
</ol>

<p>To force the issue, I set my type to &#8216;text&#8217; in my ajax calls. For example:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8" src="/js/jquery.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
&lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8"&gt;
    $.ajax('http://twitter.com/statuses/public_timeline.json', function(data, textStatus) {
        alert('Status is '+textStatus);
        alert('JSON data string is: '+data);
    }, 'text');     
&lt;/script&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>In the example above, we&#8217;re including the jquery library with the first <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tag, and then calling the <code>jQuery.ajax()</code> method in the second. We&#8217;re passing three parameters:</p>

<ol>
<li>the URL we&#8217;re pulling the JSON string from. In this case, it&#8217;s the Twitter public timeline</li>
<li>an anonymous function that&#8217;s called when the request is successful</li>
<li>the type of data we&#8217;re getting, as a string. Using &#8216;text&#8217; ensures no extra processing is done on the response string</li>
</ol>

<p>So this is great, but all we&#8217;ve got is a string of serialized data, which isn&#8217;t terribly useful. Thankfully, there&#8217;s <a href="http://json.org/json2.js">a handy library</a> at <a href="http://json.org">JSON.org</a> that takes care of parsing JSON <strike>without using <code>eval</code></strike> without using <code>eval</code> on non-JSON code<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" rel="footnote">1</a></sup>. The library gives us two methods: <code>JSON.parse()</code> for turning a JSON string into a JS object, and <code>JSON.stringify()</code> for turning a JS object into a JSON string. So let&#8217;s utilize JSON.parse() in our code, and actually do something with that data:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8" src="/js/jquery.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
&lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8" src="/js/JSON2.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
&lt;script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8"&gt;
    $.get('http://twitter.com/statuses/public_timeline.json', function(data, textStatus) {
        alert('Status is '+textStatus);
        alert('JSON data string is: '+data);

        // this will give us an array of objects
        var public_tweets = JSON.parse(data);

        // iterate over public_tweets
        for(var x=0; x &lt; public_tweets.length; x++) {
            var twt = public_tweets[x];
            var elm = '&lt;div class="tweet" id="'+twt.id+'"&gt; \
                &lt;a href="'+twt.user.url+'"&gt;&lt;img src="'+twt.user.profile_image_url+'" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt; \
                    &lt;div class="tweet-text"&gt;'+twt.text+'&lt;/div&gt; \
                &lt;/div&gt;';
            $('BODY').prepend(elm);
        }
    }, 'text');
&lt;/script&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>In the modified example above, the second script tag loads the JSON2 library. We then use the <code>JSON.parse()</code> method to turn the data string into a JavaScript object &#8211; in this case, and array of Twitter message objects. Then we iterate over the array, building a string of HTML for each entry and prepending it to the <code>&lt;body&gt;</code> tag (so the newest item is on top).</p>

<p><strong>Note:</strong> If you&#8217;re using this code on a remotely-hosted html page (or loading it as a local file under Firefox 3), it won&#8217;t work, and if you check in your error console you&#8217;ll probably see a security warning. That&#8217;s because our <code>$.get()</code> call directly accesses the Twitter API hosted on Twitter.com, which is almost certainly not the domain your files are hosted on. When we try to do so, it violates the same-origin policy enforced by browsers. The only workaround that I think is safe is to set up some sort of proxy on <em>your</em> domain to pass requests &#8211; other approaches like JSONP rely on <code>eval()</code>ing the result, which is what we&#8217;re trying to avoid here. I&#8217;ll try to cover setting up a local domain proxy in a future post.</p>

<p>By handling JSON with a parser rather than just using <code>eval()</code>, we mitigate the risk of code injection. This helps us protect both our application <em>and</em> our users.</p>

<div class="footnotes">
<hr />
<ol>

<li id="fn:1">
<p>Basically, JSON.parse() runs a regex search for code that appears to be defining a function or redefining prototypes or other kinds of stuff beyond simple data transmission, and guts those parts.&#160;<a href="#fnref:1" rev="footnote">&#8617;</a></p>
</li>

</ol>
</div>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>You can use the flXHRproxy jQuery plugin which adapts flXHR for use with jQuery&#8217;s various Ajax methods. flXHR is a completely API compatible replacement for native XHR but allows cross-domain Ajax. It does so by using an invisible flash file to bridge the domains (if the target server authorizes such with a simple policy file).</p>

<p><a href="http://flxhr.flensed.com/jquery.php">flXHRproxy jQuery plugin</a></p>

<p>The key is that flXHR wraps the invisible flash file in smart Javascript that exactly mimics the XHR API so that flXHR acts a drop-in replacement, so the flXHRproxy jQuery plugin simply registers flXHR as the alternate XHR object and the rest of the Ajax mechanisms work as normal without being any the wiser.</p>
</div>

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2870404641/in/photostream/"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2312/2870404641_4a1004f6ce.jpg?v=1221858855" alt="The Doom Beer" /></a></p>

<p><strong>Update:</strong> <a href="http://funkatron.com/content/desktop-air-php.mp3">Audio</a> is now available, thanks to <a href="http://blog.kevinhoyt.org/2008/09/22/adobe-zend-and-ed-finkler/" title="Adobe, Zend and Ed Finkler">Kevin Hoyt</a>.</p>

<p>ZendCon was pretty fun, although I was feeling under the weather most of the time. Still, I was able to offend lots of folks with my <a href="http://dearzend.com">DearZend</a> project, which was also the source for one of my three examples in my talk. You can get the code for my examples, and the slides in PDF, from here or from <a href="http://www.slideshare.net/funkatron/building-desktop-rias-with-php-html-javascript-in-air-presentation">SlideShare</a>:</p>

</ul>

For those curious, I wrote the server app in <a href="http://codeigniter.com">CodeIgniter</a>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The ugly side of developing AIR HTML apps"
url_title: the-ugly-side-of-developing-air-html-apps
permalink: the-ugly-side-of-developing-air-html-apps.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- AIR
- Development
- JavaScript
- OS X
- Spaz
- XULRunner
date: 2008-08-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2436
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/ashleyrosex/2371956135/" title="i will take over the world."><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2396/2371956135_2b1bb98f24.jpg" alt="i will take over the world." title="i will take over the world." /></a></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve been developing with AIR for over a year now. It&#8217;s all been HTML/JavaScript apps, but the complexity of most of them has been pretty low. <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz, the Twitter client I created</a>, definitely isn&#8217;t simple, though &#8211; mostly because I&#8217;m kind of a crappy coder, but also because it just does a <em>lot</em> of stuff.</p>

<p>Lately I&#8217;ve been getting a little bummed about AIR, because I&#8217;m starting to bump into limitations of the platform more and more. What&#8217;s particularly frustrating is that some of these limitations are specific to HTML AIR app dev. So what follows is a couple of issues that have been particularly troublesome when developing Spaz and other HTML/JS AIR apps.</p>

<h3>AIR gets greedy under OS X</h3>

<p>Julien Viet, who has contributed significantly to <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a>, made <a href="http://blog.julienviet.com/2008/08/21/air-ajax-runtime-footprint/">a post recently about the base resources used by the AIR runtime</a>. In it he finds that the basic &#8220;Hello World&#8221; sample app provided by Adobe used about 20MB of RAM, and hovered at about 2% CPU usage even when idling. I replicated these tests on my Macbook (2.2Ghz, 4GB) under OS X 10.5.4 and WinXP SP2, and had similar results:</p>

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2786328117/" title="AIR HTML app - Base CPU and memory usage (WinXP SP2) by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3101/2786328117_1e05b1fc9c_s.jpg" width="75" height="75" alt="AIR HTML app - Base CPU and memory usage (WinXP SP2)" /></a> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2786274247/" title="AIR HTML app - Base CPU and memory usage by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3294/2786274247_8d861eba94_s.jpg" width="75" height="75" alt="AIR HTML app - Base CPU and memory usage" /></a></p>

<p>I also created <a href="http://funkatron.com/content/HelloWorld-Flex-AIR.zip" title="Zip archive">a Flex-based &#8220;Hello World&#8221; application</a> to compare base usage if the Webkit renderer isn&#8217;t being used. Memory usage was slightly lower, but otherwise it was comparable to the HTML app.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2786341667/" title="AIR Flex app - Base CPU and memory usage (WinXP) by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3270/2786341667_76e8da9cee_s.jpg" width="75" height="75" alt="AIR Flex app - Base CPU and memory usage (WinXP)" /></a> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2786295423/" title="AIR Flex app - Base CPU and memory usage by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3149/2786295423_46092b58c9_s.jpg" width="75" height="75" alt="AIR Flex app - Base CPU and memory usage" /></a></p>

<p>The constant CPU usage seems to be specific to OS X: WinXP will jump back and forth between 0% and 2%. This is consistent with my observations of CPU usage in Spaz as well: in OS X, we get 10-15% CPU usage constantly, but under XP and Vista, CPU usage is 0% while idling.  Initial memory usage is also about 30% higher with Spaz under OS X than it is under Windows. Something is goofy with AIR on OS X.</p>

<p>That aside, I don&#8217;t think the memory and CPU usage of AIR are surprising, considering the technology. AIR is a full Flash runtime, and HTML apps add a Webkit renderer on top of that. The memory and CPU usage is in line &#8212; or a bit lower &#8212; than most <a href="http://fluidapp.com/">SSBs</a>. Using traditional browser tech to build a desktop app is going to be a tradeoff in terms of memory and CPU usage, just like many other technologies that make development easier.  But for one reason or another, the expectation seems to be that AIR is a lightweight technology, and it&#8217;s really not.</p>

<h3>AIR HTML apps are leaky</h3>

<p>What is particularly problematic is that there seem to be memory leaks within the Webkit engine as used in AIR &#8211; or at very least, it&#8217;s pretty easy to leak memory. Apps like Spaz run into this problem because it&#8217;s constantly pulling in large amounts of new data and images, and is often left running for hours or days on end.</p>

<p>Some of this is almost certainly because you can get away with that kind of thing on a web site, where users are unlikely to leave a single page open for days on end. Even if a web site does causes a big leakage, the browser almost always gets blamed. The libraries and tools available for HTML/JS devs, being browser-focused, typically don&#8217;t pay much attention to long-term performance issues.</p>

<h3>Essential tools, like profilers and step debuggers, are non-existent</h3>

<p>But memory leaks are a problem for most desktop app developers. That&#8217;s why memory profiling tools are common in desktop frameworks. And Adobe certainly understands this to be the case with Flex, as it&#8217;s FlexBuilder 3 IDE ships with memory and peformance profiling tools, as well as a full-featured debugger with breakpoints et al. That&#8217;s perfect if I was writing something in Flex, but <strong>it is completely useless for HTML/JavaScript AIR apps</strong>.  I was able to get Spaz to run from within Flex Builder with <a href="http://www.stratulat.com/blog/use-flex-builder-3-to-create-a-javascript-air-application" title="Use Flex Builder 3 to create a JavaScript AIR application">a tiny bit of hackery</a>, but the profiler gets no information about what&#8217;s going on within Webkit.</p>

<p>Other common choices for debugging web apps aren&#8217;t available either: Firebug is Mozilla-specifc, and the <a href="http://trac.webkit.org/wiki/Drosera">Drosera</a> debugger and Web Inspector tools can&#8217;t hook into AIR&#8217;s Webkit instances.  The information on Drosera does say:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>In WebKit there is a WebScriptDebugServer which is started when WebKit starts and listens for a DCOM connection. Once a connection is made it will begin to interact with Drosera via Drosera&#8217;s ServerConnection class. WebScriptDebugServer informs Drosera about every line of JavaScript executed.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I would assume that WebScriptDebugServer exists inside AIR&#8217;s Webkit, but AFAIK this has not been utilized in any way.  Adobe does have a nice AIR-specific tool called the AIR Introspector in the SDK, and it does offer some very useful functionality, but it too lacks step debugging and profiling capabilities.</p>

<p>That leaves us with good old console logging as our <em>only</em> option for debugging AIR HTML apps.  That&#8217;s okay for simpler stuff, but tracking down execution bugs in more complex applications becomes extremely tedious. And console logging is basically useless for memory profiling, as there&#8217;s no insight into the underlying operations of Webkit.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m proud of the work I&#8217;ve done on Spaz, but as the application has grown in complexity, I&#8217;ve found the limitations of HTML app dev in AIR more and more problematic. Adobe has consistently stated that the HTML dev side of AIR is as important as the Flash/Flex side. To quote Mike Chambers:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Adobe AIR is as much about JavaScript, HTML, CSS, etc&#8230; as it is about Flash / Flex. <a href="http://www.mikechambers.com/blog/2007/10/25/mozilla-prism-and-the-disingenuous-web/#comment-9529">#</a></p>
</blockquote>

<p>If that truly is the case, Adobe needs to commit to providing a toolset for HTML/JS developers comparable to what Flex developers have.  Until that&#8217;s changes, Mozilla&#8217;s <a href="http://developer.mozilla.org/En/XULRunner">XULRunner</a> and <a href="http://developer.mozilla.org/En/Prism">Prism</a> platforms are looking more and more appealing.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2436" data-url-title="the-ugly-side-of-developing-air-html-apps">

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Let&#8217;s make SXSWi 2009 suck less!"
url_title: lets-make-sxswi-2009-suck-less
permalink: lets-make-sxswi-2009-suck-less.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- JavaScript
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2008-08-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2434
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/delta407/268859813/" title="VISI Hat Back"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/79/268859813_45697e2911.jpg" alt="We Suck Less &quot;VISI Hat Back&quot;" title="VISI Hat Back" /></a></p>

<p>Remember when you went to <a href="http://www.sxsw.com/interactive/">SXSWi</a> <a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/">last year</a>, and you said &#8220;I love the parts where I meet cool people and eat free food and drink free booze and throw up, but I wish the presentations and panels weren&#8217;t so goddamn fluffy?&#8221; Me too. That&#8217;s why <a href="http://al3x.net">Alex Payne</a> (aka &#8220;The Guy Who Has Actual Name Recognition&#8221;) and myself submitted the talk &#8220;<strong><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/2065?return=/ideas/index/3/q:security">Security for the Social Set</a></strong>.&#8221;</p>

<p>The idea is that we give some solid, useful information about the security problems social networking apps have to deal with, and how to deal with them. While we can&#8217;t get too focused on specific languages and frameworks, client-side defense with JavaScript will certainly be demonstrated, and I intend to show examples in PHP and probably a couple other platforms (<em>cough</em>Rails<em>cough</em>). It will be hard to get into heavy detail within the alloted time, but it&#8217;s my hope that we can kickstart awareness and understanding of fundamental secure web app programming techniques.</p>

<p>Plus, I need a justification for dropping the coin for hotel and air fare on this boozefest, so please, <a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/2065?return=/ideas/index/3/q:security">vote for us</a>.</p>

<ul>
<li><strong><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/2065">Security for the Social Set</a></strong> (SXSW 2009)</li>
</ul>

<p>Oh, and a few other meaty talks you should consider include:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/1864">Practical JavaScript Development</a></li>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/1863">More Secrets of JavaScript Libraries</a> (this was packed last year)</li>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/1071">200s, 304s, HTTP Compression, and You</a></li>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/1517">Hackproofing Ruby-on-Rails Web Applications</a></li>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/1146">Functional Programming Without A (Strictly) Functional Language</a></li>
<li><a href="http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/ideas/view/773">Unit Testing Back to Front: Prove it Works!</a></li>
</ul>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz gets Twitpic, Ping.fm, Identi.ca support"
url_title: spaz-gets-twitpic-pingfm-identica-support
permalink: spaz-gets-twitpic-pingfm-identica-support.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- AIR
- My Projects
- Development
- JavaScript
- jQuery
- Spaz
date: 2008-08-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2435
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/lulutoo/2067787407/" title="PUREX ! NEW STREAMLINED BOTTLE"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2381/2067787407_9699204071.jpg" alt="PUREX ! NEW STREAMLINED BOTTLE &quot;PUREX ! NEW STREAMLINED BOTTLE&quot;" title="PUREX ! NEW STREAMLINED BOTTLE" /></a></p>

<p>It&#8217;s been many months since I&#8217;ve posted about <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a> here, but I&#8217;ve actually still been working on it quite a bit. Spaz recently had its 1 year anniversary, which is a pretty good milestone for one of my projects &#8211;&#160;I usually lose interest well before this. Not only is Spaz one of the oldest <a href="http://twitter.com">Twitter</a> desktop clients still under development, but it&#8217;s also one of the few FOSS clients.  I also believe Spaz is one of the most sophisticated <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/air/develop/ajax/">AIR HTML</a> apps out there, and is a good example of what can be done with HTML and JavaScript on the desktop.</p>

<p>The newest release of Spaz, which came out a couple days ago, adds some significant new features:</p>

<ul>
<li>Image uploading via <a href="http://twitpic.com/" title="Twitpic.com">Twitpic.com</a></li>
<li>Crossposting support via <a href="http://ping.fm">Ping.fm</a>. Try beta code &#8220;vivalaping&#8221;</li>
<li>Support for microblogging services with Twitter-compatible APIs, including <a href="http://Identi.ca">Identi.ca</a></li>
<li>A Dock icon badge with the unread message count. This is probably less significant if you are not running OS X.</li>
</ul>

<p>You can read <a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/whatsnew.html">the whole fat list of what&#8217;s new</a>. Also, if you want to talk to other users or <strong>help with development</strong>, here are some resources:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/spaziki">Spaziki &#8211;&#160;The Spaz Wiki and FAQ</a></li>
<li><a href="http://groups.google.com/group/spaz-users">Spaz-users Google Group</a></li>
<li><a href="http://groups.google.com/group/spaz-svn">Spaz-SVN Google Group</a></li>
<li>IRC: #spaz on <a href="http://freenode.net">irc.freenode.net</a></li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/smithco/23139437/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/19/23139437_a45ca5fe79_d.jpg" alt="Gopher Robbery" /></a></p>

<p>I have these five promo codes from Dreamhost. They expire in three days. Apparently you get super-hot deals with them, like:</p>

<ul>
<li>Four times the normal disk and bandwidth</li>
<li>$150 off a 5-year plan</li>
<li>$200 off a 10-year plan</li>
</ul>

<p>I would not sign up for 5 years with any shared host. However, I do think DH is pretty decent for small-ish sites that can work with shared hosting. I&#8217;m well aware that they&#8217;ve had a couple embarrassing public flubs in the past couple years, but I generally think they&#8217;re good folks who try to do right by their customers. Some will certainly disagree, of course. 8)</p>

<p>I still maintain my old account there for low-cpu, high-bandwidth/storage stuff. They do quite well with PHP hosting, and can handle Ruby and Python setups with a little effort. They&#8217;ll let you do crazy stuff like compile your own PHP if you are fine with using FastCGI, and have a nice GUI to setup SVN repos. Not many shared hosts will do the same at a similar price point.</p>

<p>Anyway, here are the codes. They&#8217;re first come, first serve. Yes, I make money if you sign up with one of them. I will not be hurt if you don&#8217;t use them.</p>

<ul>
<li>998942362256</li>
<li>916860787004</li>
<li>591140700044</li>
<li>047271781406</li>
<li>160643597831</li>
</ul>

title: "PHP Job Opening at Purdue"

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/29965134@N00/421693494/in/photostream/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/132/421693494_87bc32c4a6.jpg" alt="Ross-Ade Stadium at Purdue University" /></a></p>

<ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Google App Engine from a PHP developer&#8217;s perspective"
url_title: google-app-engine-from-a-php-developers-perspective
permalink: google-app-engine-from-a-php-developers-perspective.html
tags: "php, python, google app engine, django, datastore, symfony"
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
- Python
- PHP
date: 2008-06-03
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2429
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/zinka/300709246/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/119/300709246_d1864882bd.jpg" alt="My cheatin' heart" /></a></p>

<p>When Google AppEngine was announced, a lot of sturm und drang went through the PHP community because it only supported Python. Of course, the same thing went through the Ruby community. The Perl community, not so much, because they&#8217;re used to getting ignored.</p>

<p>Anyway, I didn&#8217;t really give a crap, because Python is a cool language, and I&#8217;ve been interested in learning new languages and frameworks lately. PHP is cool and all, but having done it for 9 years, you kinda look for new challenges. Plus, getting hung up on one language is a sure way to be a boring dude who gets caught up in lame religious language wars.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve actually toyed a little with Python here and there, but never dove in on a significant project. I&#8217;m someone who really <em>likes</em> whitespace and indenting rules and such, so those aspects of the language never bothered me. Otherwise, Python is a good fit for me philosophy-wise, because it&#8217;s totally the anti-Perl, lacking goofy magic characters and 1000 ways of doing the same thing. I can&#8217;t stand languages where &#8220;<code>~^s</code>&#8221; means &#8220;find all numbers that start with the letter &#8216;s&#8217;, add them, multiply them by 75, and then post the result to Twitter&#8221;. I&#8217;m not freakin&#8217; R2D2 here.</p>

<p>So anyway, I started working on a little side project with <a href="http://al3x.net">Alex Payne</a> on GAE. It&#8217;s been an enjoyable experience to work with a new language and framework, and there&#8217;s a lot to like about what GAE offers. It also has some rough edges, though, in some areas you&#8217;d be surprised by.</p>

<h3>The good</h3>

<h4>The webapp framework</h4>

<p>The built-in framework for handling requests is <a href="http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/webapp/"><strong>webapp</strong></a>, a nicely straightforward system for mapping requests to handlers.</p>

<pre><code>class MainPage(webapp.RequestHandler):
    def get(self):
        self.response.out.write('Sup dogg?')

class FooPage(webapp.RequestHandler)
    def get(self):
        self.response.out.write('This is the foo page')

def main():
    wapp = webapp.WSGIApplication([
                                    ('/', MainPage),
                                    ('/foo', FooPage)
                                  ],
                                  debug=True)

    wsgiref.handlers.CGIHandler().run(wapp)
</code></pre>

<p>So we define a class to handle a specific URL request, and define methods for <code>GET</code> or <code>POST</code> or whatever HTTP commands inside those classes. Then in the main function we map URLs to those handler classes in the <code>webapp.WSGIApplication</code> constructor, and then start it up.</p>

<p>I like this because it&#8217;s <em>simple</em> and easy to follow. I could read the code before I&#8217;d written any myself and get what&#8217;s going on. There&#8217;s no magic happening here; no auth-mapped stuff or relationships established because I happened to name something the right way and put it in the right directory. Convention is good, and we have conventions here, but the conventions are clear and obvious.</p>

<h4>Django templating</h4>

<p>Django has a really nice templating system. GAE lets you <a href="http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/gettingstarted/templates.html">use it</a> outside of the whole Django stack. This is cool. For example:</p>

<pre><code># define some values to plug into the template
tpl_data = {
    'page_title':"This is an awesome page",
    'body':"Here's the page body, sucker"
    }

# get the template path
path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'index.html')

#render and output the template
self.response.out.write(template.render(path, tpl_data))
</code></pre>

<p>Here&#8217;s a super simple <code>index.html</code> template:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;html&gt;
    &lt;head&gt;
        &lt;title&gt;{{ page_title.striptags }}&lt;/title&gt;
    &lt;/head&gt;
    &lt;body&gt;
        {{ body }}
    &lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;
</code></pre>

<h4>Google User Auth</h4>

<p>Writing a user system is a pain. Making people set up new accounts to use your site is yet another barrier to experiencing your amazing new <strike>Google sellout project</strike> site. You could presumably do these things if you want in GAE, but most of the time that seems kinda stupid. GAE offers you <a href="http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/users/">very easy integration with Google user accounts</a>, so you can use <em>that</em> as your authentication system. Since everyone and their mom has a Gmail account, it&#8217;s a pretty good bet many or most of your users will be able to skip account setup.</p>

<h4>Pricing</h4>

<p>GAE is free for your first 500MB of storage and &#8220;around&#8221; 5 million pageviews. That&#8217;s plenty to host a smallish app or do initial testing on something you want to get big (because big == profit, right?). If you push past that, the pricing is in-line with <a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/browse.html?node=201590011">similar services from Amazon</a>. That means it&#8217;s totally reasonable to set up an app just for goofing around and learning.</p>

<h4>Python</h4>

<p>Python is a cool language: easy to pick up and quite powerful. It doesn&#8217;t fit some tasks as well as PHP IMHO, but it does a ton of stuff well, and its large community means there is lots of support and library development. Some stuff it does really well includes:</p>

<ul>
<li>Network programming (<a href="http://showmedo.com/videos/video?name=1080010&amp;fromSeriesID=108">example</a>)</li>
<li>Parsing HTML</li>
<li>Email parsing and manipulation</li>
<li><a href="http://docs.python.org/mac/mac.html">OS X scripting</a></li>
<li>String manipulation</li>
<li>Unit testing</li>
<li>Other stuff I probably don&#8217;t know about</li>
</ul>

<h4>AppEngineLauncher</h4>

<p>Recently the GAE team released the <a href="http://googleappengine.blogspot.com/2008/05/app-engine-launcher-for-mac-os-x.html">Google App Engine Launcher</a>, an app for OS X that handles launching the development server and deploying your app to Google&#8217;s servers. You can of course script all this stuff yourself on the command line, but for folks less comfortable with that, this is a godsend. I actually did use the CLI before, but I don&#8217;t touch it now because the GAEL is just <a href="http://dudafly.ytmnd.com/">so fly</a>. Single-click deployment is especially awesome.</p>

<h4>Leveraging Google&#8217;s Infrastructure</h4>

<p>They gots some big computers, rite? You&#8217;d certainly think so, and they probably have better uptime than your $5 shared hosting account.  We hope.</p>

<h3>The lame</h3>

<h4>Datastore query limitations &amp; primitive text search</h4>

<p>The Datastore API is GAE&#8217;s database system. It has some similarities to traditional relational DBs like MySQL and PostgreSQL, but it is <em>fundamentally different</em>. It stores data objects as <em>entities</em> instead of rows, and properties instead of columns. Objects are described by <em>model</em> classes, defined in Python:</p>

<pre><code>class Page(db.Model):
    title = db.StringProperty(required=True)
    keywords = db.StringProperty()
    date_added = db.DateProperty(required=True)
    date_updated = db.DateProperty(required=True)
    body = db.StringProperty()
</code></pre>

<p>Models are to entities as classes are to objects, then (I think).</p>

<p>The object approach has some cool flexibility, like <em>expando</em> models that let you add arbitrary properties to entities (very <em>unlike</em> rows in a relational database).</p>

<p>You can do SQL-like queries against the Datastore with GQL. It&#8217;s a lot like SQL, but a lot more basic. In fact, this is a summary of the <em>entire</em> language:</p>

<pre><code>SELECT * FROM &lt;kind&gt;
[WHERE &lt;condition&gt; [AND &lt;condition&gt; ...]]
[ORDER BY &lt;property&gt; [ASC | DESC] [, &lt;property&gt; [ASC | DESC] ...]]
[LIMIT [&lt;offset&gt;,]&lt;count&gt;]
[OFFSET &lt;offset&gt;]

&lt;condition&gt; := &lt;property&gt; {&lt; | &lt;= | &gt; | &gt;= | = | != } &lt;value&gt;
&lt;condition&gt; := &lt;property&gt; IN &lt;list&gt;
&lt;condition&gt; := ANCESTOR IS &lt;entity or key&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>This lets you do basic queries, but it&#8217;s missing a lot of powerful stuff present in SQL. Most notably there is no equivalent to the <code>LIKE</code> comparison operator. That means <strong>there is no way to do partial string matches!</strong></p>

<p>Okay, so you can do <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/google-appengine/browse_thread/thread/b99bb87d9a3d05ab/8ca66b9241ccf73f?lnk=gst&amp;q=string+prefix+match#8ca66b9241ccf73f">kludgy prefix matching</a>, and there is an as-of-yet undocumented whole word search using <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/google-appengine/browse_thread/thread/f64eacbd31629668/8dac5499bd58a6b7?lnk=gst&amp;q=searchablemodel#8dac5499bd58a6b7">the SearchableModel class</a>, but those are primitive compared to the string matching capabilities in MySQL. Personally  I would&#8217;ve thought that <em>the</em> search company would have given GAE really awesome text search capabilities out of the box, but for now folks have to roll their own hacks.</p>

<p>I guess now I have an idea of why Gmail&#8217;s search can&#8217;t match partial strings.</p>

<h4>No &#8220;beginner&#8221; docs</h4>

<p>GAE&#8217;s docs are aimed at experienced developers who have already built web apps. Most of it is reference, and it&#8217;s a little light on examples. If you&#8217;ve not used Python before, here&#8217;s the entire introduction form the GAE docs:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>For more information about Python, see <a href="http://www.google.com/url?sa=D&amp;q=http://python.org/">the Python website</a> and <a href="http://www.google.com/url?sa=D&amp;q=http://docs.python.org/">the Python documentation</a>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I think Python is easy to pick up, but GAE doesn&#8217;t even bother pointing out some good tutorials for beginners.  Compare this to <em><a href="http://djangobook.com/">The Django Book</a></em> or <em><a href="http://www.symfony-project.org/book/">The Definitive Guide to Symfony</a></em>, both of which aren&#8217;t really for beginners, but do a good job of helping them get up to speed.</p>

<hr />

<p>I&#8217;m early in my development experience with GAE, so this is by no means comprehensive. Google has already demonstrated that the GAE feature set will be growing, having introduced memcache and image manipulation APIs just a week ago. I&#8217;m sure the documentation will be improved and supplemented by third parties in short order, and the issues with text search will almost certainly be addressed soon &#8211; it&#8217;s an obvious deficiency.</p>

<p>For now, I&#8217;m having a lot of fun working with GAE. It&#8217;s a solid platform with a lot of promise, and it offers a lot of learning opportunities for folks who want to explore web app dev with Python.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Encouraging steps towards security in Wordpress 2.5"
url_title: encouraging-steps-towards-security-in-wordpress-25
permalink: encouraging-steps-towards-security-in-wordpress-25.html
tags: "wordpress, wpids, salting, passwords, cookies, security, infosec"
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2008-04-01
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2424
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/parl/3594329/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/2/3594329_f3e39a44ed.jpg?v=0" alt="Table Salt" title="Table Salt" /></a></p>

<p>Anyone who gets me liquored up knows that I&#8217;m not a fan of Wordpress. I think it&#8217;s <em>great</em> from a user (that is, the person writing the content) standpoint, but it has lagged behind severely in terms of security, and I don&#8217;t believe its popularity is the sole reason WP has been the subject of dozens of vulnerability reports every year. That being said, the WP 2.5 release appears to offer significant improvements in a couple areas: password hashes and cookie data encryption. From <a href="http://wordpress.org/development/2008/03/wordpress-25-brecker/" title="the WP blog">the WP blog</a>:</p>

<blockquote>

<p>Salted passwords &#8212; we now use the <a href="http://www.openwall.com/phpass/">phpass</a> library to stretch and salt all passwords stored in the database, which makes brute-forcing them impractical. If you use something like mod_auth_mysql we&#8217;ve created a plugin that will allow you to use legacy MD5 hashing. (The hashing is completely pluggable.) Users will automatically switch to the more secure passwords next time they log in.</p>

<p>Secure cookies &#8212; cookies are now encrypted based on the protocol described in <a href="http://www.cse.msu.edu/~alexliu/publications/Cookie/cookie.pdf">this PDF paper</a>. which is something like <code>user name|expiration time|HMAC( user name|expiration time, k)</code> where <code>k = HMAC(user name|expiration time, sk)</code> and where <code>sk</code> is a secret key, which you can define in your config.</p>

</blockquote>

<p>These are good steps, and while I think they took way too long to happen, I&#8217;m glad they finally did. I do still feel that WP suffers from an architecture that makes it too easy to make input filtering mistakes, and I would strongly recommend a tool like <a href="http://php-ids.org/2008/02/21/wpids-version-012-released/">WPIDS</a> for all self-hosting Wordpress users.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Zend Studio for Eclipse and SFTPDrive not on speaking terms"
url_title: zend-studio-for-eclipse-and-sftpdrive-not-on-speaking-terms
permalink: zend-studio-for-eclipse-and-sftpdrive-not-on-speaking-terms.html
tags: "php, zend, zend studio for eclipse, eclipse, sftp, sftpdrive"
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2008-03-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2423
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2345662532/" title="ZendStudio for Eclipe can't see SFTPDrive mounts by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2028/2345662532_52398c22b3.jpg" width="500" height="415" alt="ZendStudio for Eclipe can't see SFTPDrive mounts" /></a></p>

<p><strong>Update</strong>: This seems to have fixed itself one night. Maybe I rebooted? Who knows. Anyway, all seems good now.</p>

<hr />

<p>So I use <a href="http://www.sftpdrive.com/">SFTPDrive</a> on my Vista workstation at work to mount remote filesystems. It generally works pretty well, and I&#8217;ve never had an issue where a program didn&#8217;t treat my mount as a local drive &#8212; until I decided to give upgrading to <a href="http://www.zend.com/en/products/studio/">Zend Studio for Eclipse</a> a go (licenses for which were generously donated to <a href="http://cerias.purdue.edu">CERIAS</a> by <a href="http://zend.com">Zend</a>). For some reason, ZSfE just doesn&#8217;t show me my &#8220;k:&#8221; drive (the SFTP mount) when browsing for a project directory. This throws a real wrench in my usual workflow &#8212; ZS 5.5 had built-in SFTP support, and I could also use the local mount if I wanted.</p>

<p>I did look in Zend&#8217;s Support KB and the forums, but did not come across anything like this. Have you? Any alternatives for directly connecting and editing over SFTP?</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2423" data-url-title="zend-studio-for-eclipse-and-sftpdrive-not-on-speaking-terms">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6390" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Sean Coates</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://blog.phpdoc.info/</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/19/2008 01:01:16 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>It&#8217;s been a long time since I&#8217;ve used Eclipse (in any form other than FlexBuilder) for day-to-day work, but I do seem to recall it having reasonable sftp support by plugin.</p>

<p>This came up on a search: http://www.jcraft.com/eclipse-sftp/</p>

<p>Odd that it doesn&#8217;t see your drive, though.</p>

<p>S</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6391" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Josh Johnston</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/19/2008 02:55:42 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Create a new PHP Project. Don&#8217;t add any content to it initially. In the left hand side PHP Explorer, right click on the project and choose New &gt; Remote Folder.</p>

<p>This lets you link a remote folder to a local project. There is a big push to &#8216;fix&#8217; remote editing in ZSfE. 5.5 had awesome remote file support, 6.0 is mediocre at best. If you check the Zend Neon Group mailing list on Yahoo you can track its status.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6392" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Ed Finkler</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://funkatron.com/public-uploads/spaziki</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/19/2008 03:56:46 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>@Josh: very helpful, thanks. I eventually ended up doing the same thing in a slightly different way, but it looks like were good. Initially I had experimented with the Remote Systems stuff and making a &#8220;Remote Project,&#8221; but that didn&#8217;t appear to support any kind of &#8220;code insight&#8221;-type stuff, which is really the main reason I use an IDE.</p>

<p>I was also frustrated to find that the info on creating SFTP connections in the Help info is just plain <em>wrong</em>. It puts FTP and SFTP in the same boat, but the directions actually only work for plain FTP connections.  This kind of documentation goofiness seems to have plagued Zend for quite a while now.</p>
</div>
	</li>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Notes on SXSW2008"
url_title: notes-on-sxsw2008
permalink: notes-on-sxsw2008.html
tags: "expressionengine, codeigniter, sxsw2008, sxsw08, sxsw, austin, clint ecker, jason perkins, rails, pixish, mark zuckerberg, punk, CMS, lolcats, halcyon, violet blue, alex payne, jonathan snook, Ken Fisher, ars, thomas Myer, C. Eric Smith, Obie Fernandez, Frank Warren, postsecret"
published: true
category:
- Development
- InfoSec
- Design
- PHP
date: 2008-03-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2422
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/2328083460/" title="Passive-aggressive by funkatron, on Flickr"><img src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3164/2328083460_6fae4a10ae.jpg" width="500" height="375" alt="Passive-aggressive" /></a></p>

<h3>The experience of SXSW</h3>

<ul>
<li>Unlike other conferences I&#8217;ve been to, which were mostly tech confs SXSWi is not about nuts and bolts &#8212; it&#8217;s about higher level issues of people using technology

<ul>
<li>A couple exceptions, like the <a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/interactive/programming/panels_schedule/?action=show&amp;id=IAP060469">Secrets of JavaScript Libraries</a>. This was good, and I&#8217;d like to see more like this. I don&#8217;t expect hardcore advanced code talks, but good intro-level stuff would go a long way, I think.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>At most confs I attend, I&#8217;m the &#8220;weird&#8221; dude, with my earrings and black t-shirts. At SXSW I&#8217;m another asshole with a fauxhawk.</li>
<li>Way, way, way more women at SXSWi than any tech conf. Someone on a panel I attended complained that the % of females has been going down at SXSWi, and I&#8217;d guess it&#8217;s maybe 35-40% female. At most of the tech conferences I go, it&#8217;s 5-10% female, tops.</li>
<li>Despite the fact that web apps are one of the primary points of attacks for malicious users, security was really not talked about much at SXSW (although I heard there was some in the <a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/interactive/programming/panels_schedule/?action=show&amp;id=IAP060295">OpenID panel</a>). This was disappointing. People running web apps are the stewards of their users security and privacy, a responsibility not to be taken likely. I&#8217;d wager under 20% of attendees and panelists could describe basic techniques for architecting software with security in mind (but I hope it&#8217;s higher). Definitely need to propose a panel for 2009.</li>
</ul>

<h3>The culture of Austin</h3>

<ul>
<li>People really do seem more hospitable. Locals will ask a stranger how there night&#8217;s going. This is pleasant, but a little weird for a yanqui when it happens in the men&#8217;s room.</li>
<li>Austin embraces being different. They <em>like</em> it, from the top down. This is so unlike most other communities.</li>
<li>Austin doesn&#8217;t feel like a big city. It has some big, cool buildings, but you&#8217;ll see flop houses a couple blocks away. </li>
<li>Closest thing I&#8217;ve experienced to Austin is Portland. I think PDX has better public transportation. Austin&#8217;s weather doesn&#8217;t cause city-wide suicide watches, though.</li>
</ul>

<h3>Other tidbits</h3>

<p>Introduced <a href="http://clintecker.com/">Clint Ecker</a> to <a href="http://sneer.org/">Jason Perkins</a>, both Chicago-based web devs. They discover that they work literally next door from one another.</p>

<hr />

<p>Had lunch with Jason Perkins and the rest of the <a href="http://pixish.com">Pixish</a> crew. Surprisingly was not mocked incessantly for not using Rails. They&#8217;re good peeps, and Pixish is a cool site.</p>

<hr />

<p>I wonder how far <a href="http://www.viddler.com/explore/allfacebook/videos/13/">the Zuckerberg &#8220;keynote&#8221;</a> set back female journalism. That&#8217;s a hari-kari situation right there.</p>

<hr />

<p>If you are unwilling to say to someone&#8217;s face what you say in your little gadget (or otherwise) blog, you need to shut up. Stop being a punk.</p>

<hr />

<p>I was really happy to see <a href="http://ExpressionEngine.com">ExpressionEngine</a> and <a href="http://codeigniter.com">CodeIgniter</a> represented as strongly as they were at SXSW. I still feel strongly that EE is the strongest CMS product in its market (which includes Drupal, Joomla, Wordpress and the like), and the improvements in EE2.0&#8217;s administration system will increase productivity considerably.</p>

<hr />

<p>Holy shit, I have never seen as many iPhones as I did there. And it&#8217;s taking some effort on my part to not go get one now. I could have left my laptop in the hotel room if I&#8217;d had one, which would have reduced my fatigue considerably. Since I am doing about 4 conferences a year, it&#8217;s starting to make more sense. I&#8217;m making myself wait for a new hardware revision, though (and I really can&#8217;t afford one atm).</p>

<hr />

<p>The panel on the success of <a href="http://icanhascheezburger.com/">icanhascheezburger.com</a> was interesting, and I think underlines that <em>luck</em> is a (the?) key component for almost all of these rags-to-riches stories</p>

<hr />

<p>Being <em>with</em> someone &#8212; or a small group &#8212; seems key to me. I think I would have enjoyed SXSWi a lot less if I was not able to always count on the two friends I was with.</p>

<hr />

<p>Do not be afraid to come up and talk to people. It&#8217;s hard for me to do, but I was always glad I did. I got to meet old internet-only friends like <a href="http://tinynibbles.com">Violet Blue</a> because of this (so glad I did!). I also got a hug from <a href="http://www.lifestudent.com/">Halcyon</a>, which was awesome &#8212; more dudes should be down with hugs.</p>

<hr />

<p>Meeting <a href="http://al3x.net">Alex Payne</a> was another highlight of SXSW for me. What a great guy; I wish we&#8217;d had more time to hang and talk. And there were so many others, like <a href="http://www.derekallard.com/">Derek Allard</a>, <a href="http://snook.ca">Jonathan Snook</a>, <a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/interactive/programming/panels_schedule/?action=bio&amp;id=171397">Ken Fisher</a> (thanks again for dinner Monday night), <a href="http://www.tripledogdaremedia.com/">Thomas Myer</a>, <a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/interactive/programming/panels_schedule/?action=bio&amp;id=139146">C. Eric Smith</a>, <a href="http://obiefernandez.com/">Obie Fernandez</a> (I wish he&#8217;d written Rails), <a href="http://climbtothestars.org/">Stephanie Booth</a>, and many others whom I&#8217;m too forgetful to remember at the moment.</p>

<hr />

<p><a href="http://2008.sxsw.com/interactive/programming/panels_schedule/?action=bio&amp;id=174538">Frank Warren</a>&#8217;s keynote on his <a href="http://postsecret.blogspot.com/">PostSecret</a> project was the highlight of SXSW for me. It was funny, tragic, inspiring, and compelling. One could not help but be inspired, as exemplified by the man who asked his love to marry him in front of the entire audience. Technology empowering us to express ourselves, communicate, and aid one another is so much of what the last few years in web dev has been about, and we would do well to follow the example set by Frank Warren.</p>

<hr />

<p>Oh hell yes I&#8217;m coming back next year</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Notes on ExpressionEngine 2.0 Preview at SXSW"
url_title: notes-on-expressionengine-20-preview-at-sxsw
permalink: notes-on-expressionengine-20-preview-at-sxsw.html
tags: "php, expressionengine, codeigniter"
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2008-03-08
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2421
---
<h3><a href="http://expressionengine.com">ExpressionEngine</a> 2.0 will be powered by <a href="http://codeigniter.com">CodeIgniter</a></h3>

<ul>
<li>CI gains abstracted querying</li>
<li>New CI libs like the <a href="http://codeigniter.com/user_guide/database/forge.html">DBForge</a> built to support EE 2.0</li>
<li>EE Session library more powerful</li>
<li>EE Form gen and HTML gen</li>
<li><p><a href="http://jquery.com">jQuery</a> built into EE now</p></li>
<li><p>Basically, if EE needs something, CI gets new feature</p></li>
<li>Performance and simplicity still top priority</li>
</ul>

<h3>Changes coming in EE 2.0</h3>

<ul>
<li>new CP theme designed from scratch</li>
<li>CP uses MVC pattern (CP has always been decoupled from EE&#8217;s frontend stuff)</li>
<li>CP has nice DHTML stuff driven by jquery - sortable tables, dynamic search results/filtering, ajax paging (retains sorting settings), pretty animations</li>
<li>New CP is very task-oriented: Create, Modify, View are primary sections, all available from opening</li>
<li>Top Bar: Content, Design, Add-Ons, Members, Admin, Tools</li>
<li>Nice little footer tabs called Accessories. Default are Learning EE stuff, EE News and site stats

<ul>
<li>Accessories can be added much like modules or plugins</li>
<li>Accessory creation doesn&#8217;t require PHP knowledge (but it helps to do more awesome stuff)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Admin area no longer has Utilities

<ul>
<li>Content Admin and System Admin</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Members have own section</li>
<li>Edit form shows nice dhtml tabs;

<ul>
<li>can create custom tabs from edit form</li>
<li>can add/edit custom fields from edit form</li>
<li>fields are resortable by dragging</li>
<li>full-page write mode for any field</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>




<!-- end of post -->

<p>I use a service called <a href="http://103bees.com">103bees</a> to track what search terms and questions are directing people to Funkatron.com. Here&#8217;s this week&#8217;s selections:</p>

<h2>Search terms</h2>

<ul>
<li><p><code>lil wyte photo</code></p>

<p>I have no idea.</p></li>
<li><p><code>download hardly wait juliette lewis</code></p>

<p>I really like that version of <a href="http://www.pjharvey.net/lyrics/demos_hardly.html">the PJ Harvey song</a>, as sung by Juliette Lewis in the film <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0114558/combined">Strange Days</a></p></li>
<li><p><code>free .mac account mail only</code></p>

<p>Not here!</p></li>
<li><p><code>funkatron twitter air</code></p>

<p>Presumably someone who heard <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a> mentioned on <a href="http://www.twit.tv/mbw77">MacBreak Weekly</a></p></li>
<li><p><code>visualize kcachegrind os x</code></p>

<p>I think I <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/kcachegrind_equivalent_for_os_x/">posted</a> about how much of a gigantic pain in the ass this was to get running on OS X.</p></li>
<li><p><code>ghetto fackin</code></p>

<p>mmmmm no.</p></li>
<li><p><code>spry click tab reload data</code></p>

<p>I have talked about <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/spry/">Spry</a> a fair bit here, so I guess that makes sense.</p></li>
<li><p><code>matt sink</code></p>

<p>No idea</p></li>
<li><p><code>debian parallels tools</code></p>

<p>Ah, I did make a post about getting Debian running on Parallels. Or more accurately, the fact that <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/installing_a_debian_vm_using_parallels/">I got it running</a></p></li>
<li><p><code>spaz app</code></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve heard of this</p></li>
</ul>

<h2>Questions</h2>

<ul>
<li><p><code>how to use monospace fonts in illustrator cs2</code></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve posted a tip about <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/rounding_corners_in_illustrator/">rounded rect corners in Illustrator</a>, and monospaced <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/fonts_for_programming/">fonts for programming</a></p></li>
<li><p><code>what are the things on my penis</code></p>

<p>Can&#8217;t help you, bro. I did write once that <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/im_scared_to_put_things_in_my_penis/">I&#8217;m scared to put things <em>in</em> my penis</a>, tho.</p></li>
<li><p><code>php 6 when is coming out</code></p>

<p>I don&#8217;t know when, but I know why I&#8217;m looking forward to it!</p></li>
<li><p><code>what are the chances of getting tax audited</code></p>

<p>I <a href="http://funkatron.com/index.php/site/comments/what_are_your_chances_of_getting_audited_by_the_irs/">reposted something about this</a>.</p></li>
<li><p><code>there was an error: typeerror: undefined value flickr mac os x</code></p>

<p>Pretty much every app I&#8217;ve ever written has tons of errors in it, so this could be anything.</p></li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "What I&#8217;m looking forward to in PHP6"
url_title: what-im-looking-forward-to-in-php6
permalink: what-im-looking-forward-to-in-php6.html
tags: "php6"
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2008-02-05
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2418
---
<ol>
<li>Punctuation-only variable names</li>
<li>&#8220;Safe mode&#8221; that disables all output</li>
<li>HDMI outputs</li>
<li>ASCII-art generators added to core (once CLAs are signed)</li>
<li>The quad-colon operator (::::)</li>
<li>All superglobals reduced to single array: <code>$_FUCKO</code></li>
<li>Improved <em>elegance</em></li>
</ol>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Inspekt 0.3 now available"
url_title: inspekt-03-now-available
permalink: inspekt-03-now-available.html
tags: "inspekt, php, filtering, validation, library, php4, php5, owasp"
published: true
category:
- Inspekt
- My Projects
- Development
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2008-01-21
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2417
---
<p><a href="http://inspekt.org"><img src="/content/inspekt_logo_v1.png" alt="Inspekt" /></a></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve uploaded the 0.3 release of <a href="http://inspekt.org" title="the input filtering and validation library for PHP4 and 5">Inspekt</a>, the input filtering and validation library for PHP4 and 5. With this release, Inspekt completes the goals of the original specification for the <a href="https://www.owasp.org/">OWASP</a> <a href="http://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Spring_Of_Code_2007_Applications#EdFinkler_-_A_comprehensive_input_retrieval.2Ffiltering_system_for_PHP" title="OWASP Spring Of Code 2007 Applications - OWASP">SpoC007 project
</a>. I believe it is ready for &#8220;real-world&#8221; use.</p>

<p>Along with this release, there are new support and install options:</p>

<ul>
<li>Brand new <a href="http://funkatron.com/inspekt/user_docs" title="Inspekt User Docs">user documentation</a> - written by an actual human (well, me, so close enough)</li>
<li>Updated <a href="http://funkatron.com/inspekt/api_docs/" title="Inspekt API Docs">API documentation</a> generated with <a href="http://www.phpdoc.org/" title="phpDocumentor: The complete documentation solution for PHP">phpDocumentor</a></li>
<li>A PEAR channel (<a href="http://pear.funkatron.com" title="pear.funkatron.com">pear.funkatron.com</a>) for quick packaged installs</li>
<li>A <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/inspekt" title="inspekt | Google Groups">discussion group/mailing list</a> for support, suggestions and discussion</li>
</ul>

<p>What&#8217;s new in this release:</p>

<ul>
<li>Automated filtered via external config files</li>
<li>Cleanup and fixes to docblocks</li>
<li>More example code</li>
<li><a href="http://groups.google.com/group/inspekt/web/inspekt_logo_v1.png" title="Fruity">A fruity logo</a></li>
</ul>

<p>What&#8217;s in the future:</p>

<ul>
<li>Interact with developers to get feedback and implement suggestions</li>
<li>Add new options for URI, email, phone # validators</li>
<li>Work with framework developers to integrate Inspekt with their platforms</li>
<li>Better support the special requirements of session data</li>
<li>Integration with PHP5&#8217;s filtering API when available</li>
<li>Integration with other filtering and escaping systems like <a href="http://php-ids.org/" title="PHPIDS &raquo; Web Application Security 2.0 &raquo; Index">PHPIDS</a> and <a href="http://htmlpurifier.org/" title="HTML Purifier - Filter your HTML the standards-compliant way!">HTML Purifier</a></li>
</ul>

<p>If you are interested in contributing to Inspekt in <em>any</em> way, I highly encourage you to <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/inspekt" title="inspekt | Google Groups">join the mailing list</a>.  I&#8217;m especially looking for development assistance and &#8220;real-world&#8221; feedback.</p>
