---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Assumptions and Mac browser share"
url_title: assumptions-and-mac-browser-share
permalink: assumptions-and-mac-browser-share.html
tags: "browsers, market, share, mac, osx, logic, assumption, fallacy"
published: true
category:
- General
- The Web Problem
- OS X
date: 2007-12-28
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2415
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/prawnwarp/1719247500/"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2394/1719247500_f927858b56.jpg?v=0" alt="Logic Lane" /></a></p>

<p>If there&#8217;s one thing I&#8217;ve learned in my years as a grown-up, it&#8217;s this: Don&#8217;t make assumptions.  All too often, things I&#8217;ve thought were no-brainers turned out to be <a href="http://www.nizkor.org/features/fallacies/appeal-to-belief.html">questionable at best</a>, like:</p>

<ul>
<li>John Romero will make <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daikatana">an awesome game</a> on his own</li>
<li>Sony and Microsoft have made Nintendo <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2007/12/14/business/20071214_WII_GRAPHIC.html">irrelevant</a></li>
<li>Women will find my company tolerable</li>
</ul>

<p>I often see techie types making <a href="http://www.logicalfallacies.info/hastygeneralisation.html">assumptions based on their experience</a>, like &#8220;program A is unusable&#8221; (because on his rather oddly set-up system, it crashed on install) or &#8220;no real programmers write in Ruby&#8221; (because he doesn&#8217;t know anyone personally who do) or &#8220;only a tiny fraction of Mac users browse with Firefox&#8221; (because it&#8217;s the default browser out of the box, and average users always use the default, right?).</p>

<p>It was this last assertion, and the accompanying statement &#8220;<a href="http://www.nizkor.org/features/fallacies/begging-the-question.html">I don&#8217;t have to prove something so obvious</a>&#8221; that inspired this article. I wouldn&#8217;t have been particularly surprised if Safari had a majority of the Mac browser market, but my personal experience had been that a fair number of non-techie Mac folks use Firefox. Beyond that, I wanted to get some <em>real data</em>, and not make assumptions. If you can&#8217;t provide some basis for your assertions, they&#8217;re not worth much. It&#8217;s a clear sign of a bad <a href="http://www.fallacyfiles.org/glossary.html#Argument">argument</a>, and little gets me more worked up than weak logic.</p>

<p>The audience for a web site has a pretty significant impact on what browsers we see visitors using. Tech-oriented sites tend to have a higher percentage of users running alternate browsers like Firefox. You&#8217;ll get more <a href="http://caminobrowser.org/">Camino</a> users on a Mac-oriented site, and <a href="http://www.konqueror.org/">Konqueror</a> will show up more often on sites with content for Linux users. That means we have to at least take into account the content of the site when drawing conclusions from the numbers.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s what I&#8217;ve found myself, and what others have shared with me, so far.  Understandably, some folks shared their stats with me asked to remain anonymous, or that the site they come from not be revealed. I&#8217;ve described them as best I can.  Also note that in some cases I received just info on Mac browsers, and others I had data for all browsers. I&#8217;ve calculated a ratio and &#8220;winner&#8221; at the end of each entry.</p>

<p>Is this data <em>conclusive</em>? Of course not. It&#8217;s a small sample of a handful of sites, and not particularly popular ones at that. But, it does seem to at least indicate that Firefox may be quite a bit more popular among Mac users than I &#8211; and certainly other people &#8211; thought.</p>

<p>If you&#8217;d like to contribute data, just drop me a line or leave a comment.</p>

<h3>Funkatron.com</h3>

<p><em>This site, obviously strongly tech-oriented, but also gets a decent amount of sport-oriented search engine traffic</em></p>

<table>
<thead>
<tr>
  <th>Browser</th>
  <th align="right">% of total</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
  <td>Firefox/Macintosh</td>
  <td align="right">19.31</td>
</tr>
<tr>
  <td>Safari/Macintosh</td>
  <td align="right">13.38</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<p><strong>Approx ratio:</strong> 1.5/1  Firefox</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Funcaday.com, or, Paul Reinheimer threatens me with physical violence"
url_title: funcadaycom-or-paul-reinheimer-threatens-me-with-physical-violence
permalink: funcadaycom-or-paul-reinheimer-threatens-me-with-physical-violence.html
tags: "php, funcaday, calendar, learning, tips, intimidation, violence"
published: true
category:
- Design
- PHP
- Widgets
date: 2007-12-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2414
---
<blockquote>
  <p><strong>Paul Reinheimer</strong> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <em>8:43</em><br />
  did you plug funcaday yet?</p>
  
  <p><strong>funka7ron</strong> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <em>8:53</em><br />
  &#42;hides&#42; I need to get on dat</p>
  
  <p><strong>Paul Reinheimer</strong> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <em>8:54</em><br />
  Here&#8217;s what I&#8217;m going to do: I&#8217;m going to bring a few copies of my book, see<br />
  They roll up nice and tight<br />
  I&#8217;m going to beat you with them<br />
  then shove them a few places, and light them on fire<br /></p>
</blockquote>

<hr />

<p>I&#8217;m super excited about <a href="http://funcaday.com/">Funcaday</a>, the brainchild of <a href="http://blog.preinheimer.com/">Paul Reinheimer</a> and <a href="http://www.moonsoar.com/">Courtney Wilson</a>. What a cool concept - basically an electronic daily calendar for PHP functions.</p>

<p><a href="http://funcaday.com"><img src="http://funkatron.com/images/uploads/displayEntry.php.png" alt="Funcaday" /></a></p>

<p>The <a href="http://funcaday.com/rss.xml">RSS feed</a> delivery is just <em>begging</em> for little desktop apps and widgets. <a href="http://benramsey.com/archives/funcadaycom-dashboard-widget/">Ben Ramsey</a> has already made <a href="http://benramsey.com/media/downloads/Funcaday.wdgt.zip">one for the OS X dashboard</a>.</p>

<p>Kudos to Paul and Courtney!</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Code simplicity"
url_title: code-simplicity
permalink: code-simplicity.html
tags: "php, ruby, python, syntax, languages, minimalism"
published: true
category:
- Development
- PHP
date: 2007-12-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2413
---
<p><a href="http://al3x.net">Alex Payne</a> did a much better job <a href="http://www.al3x.net/2007/11/minimalism-in-code.html">expressing this</a> that I could in my slightly addled state:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>I enjoy programming in Ruby, but it doesn&#8217;t have the crisp simplicity that I prefer. Syntactical shortcuts inherited from Perl combined with upteen different ways to write a given expression make the language extremely flexible, but also extremely complex. It&#8217;s possible to write clean, minimal Ruby, but such code rarely takes full advantage of the language. Idiomatic Ruby is powerful but complicated. While Ruby programs are often shorter than their equivalents in other languages, line density frequently offsets length for rapid comprehension.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>That&#8217;s always something I&#8217;ve noticed with Ruby - that it borrows too many &#8220;magic symbols&#8221; from Perl for my liking. I strongly dislike idiomatic code because reading it is too much like parsing hieroglyphics. To some extent you&#8217;re gonna get that with any computer language, and a lot of it is dependent on what you&#8217;re used to syntactically, but I do think there are tendencies for some languages to be more or less &#8220;readable.&#8221; PHP does a pretty decent job of it; I think Python is even better in this regard, and probably why I dig the language a lot.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2413" data-url-title="code-simplicity">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6125" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Bertrand Mansion</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://golgote.freeflux.net</div>
		<div class="comment-date">12/07/2007 09:32:05 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Try Lua.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6127" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Michael</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://fupeg.blogspot.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">12/07/2007 05:34:11 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>That&#8217;s some tough calculus. Martin Fowler would argue that expressiveness in a language makes developers more productive. Expressiveness and terseness go hand-in-hand.</p>

<p>For example, there is a lot of debate in Java about adding closures to the language. Does Java need the expressiveness of closures, or will its terseness make Java code harder to develop/maintain? Closures are common enough in other languages that the expressiveness argument probably wins out. Some of the hard-to-grok terseness of Ruby is from Perl, as you mentioned and not common to other scripting languages like PHP and Python.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6128" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Edward  Finkler</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://funkatron.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">12/07/2007 10:52:01 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Bertrand,</p>

<p>Thanks for the tip. I&#8217;ll look into Lua.</p>

<p>Michael,</p>

<p>Smarter people than me can certainly make better arguments on this topic. ;) However, I do find that as much as I like closures in Javascript, I also see them making my code harder to maintain. That doesn&#8217;t mean I&#8217;m willing to give them up, though, because they&#8217;re super cool.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "php|tek, AIR dev and PHPSecInfo"
url_title: phptek-air-dev-and-phpsecinfo
permalink: phptek-air-dev-and-phpsecinfo.html
tags: "AIR, php, phpsecinfo, phptek, tek08, conferences, talks, chicago"
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- PHP
date: 2007-12-03
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2412
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/tychay/1382824242/"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1194/1382824242_a8c1e4075e.jpg" alt="Reinhemer Quad-Core" /></a></p>

<p>Clearly the free booze and other gifts provided to the <a href="http://phparch.com">php|arch</a> team is paying off, as two of my talks have been accepted for <a href="http://tek.phparch.com/">php|tek 2008</a> in Chicago. I&#8217;ll be speaking on desktop app development with <a href="http://adobe.com/go/air">AIR</a>, and the <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PHPSecInfo</a> project.  <a href="http://tek.phparch.com/c/schedule">The full schedule of talks</a> will help you plan on how best to avoid me.</p>

<p>Desktop app dev with <a href="http://adobe.com/go/air">AIR</a> has been something near and dear to my heart lately, as I&#8217;ve spent a lot of time in the past several months developing <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a>, a <a href="http://twitter.com">Twitter</a> client based on AIR.  In the process I&#8217;ve learned a whole heck of a lot about Javascript development, and learned intimately what works well in AIR and what doesn&#8217;t. Combining PHP on the server side and Javascript/HTML on the client side makes a lot of sense for me, then. Getting the two sides to work together has gotten a fair bit easier with the <a href="http://php.net/json">JSON extension</a> that was added in PHP 5.2.0.  With that, exchange of data structures carries a lot less overhead.</p>

<p><a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PHPSecInfo</a> has been quiet for a while on the development side, but I&#8217;m hoping things will pick up a bit with the introduction of <a href="http://code.google.com/p/phpsecinfo">public SVN access</a> to the project. The trunk version has some extra stuff in it, like the beginnings of a new view system to output results in various formats.  I&#8217;ve also added <a href="http://blog.preinheimer.com/">Paul Reinheimer</a> as a contributor, so feel free to guilt him into making updates as well.  If you&#8217;re interested in contributing patches or updates to PHPSecInfo, drop me a line and we&#8217;ll chat.</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz 0.3.0 available; now with screencast action"
url_title: spaz-030-available-now-with-screencast-action
permalink: spaz-030-available-now-with-screencast-action.html
tags: "spaz, twitter, AIR, adobe AIR, javascript, ajax, RIA, screencast, Spaz.AIR"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Development
- OS X
- Spaz
date: 2007-10-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2409
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/funkatron/1766349188/"><img src="http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2183/1766349188_232cf230c6.jpg" class="alignright" /></a>
I&#8217;m not dead &#8212; I&#8217;m just busy.  Spaz has had a few long-standing issues since the upgrade to AIR Beta 2, and this new version (0.3.0) fixes many of them. If you already have Spaz, just go to the Prefs tab > Upgrades > Check Now. If you don&#8217;t have Spaz installed, you can install it from <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">the Spaz homepage</a>.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s a breakdown of what&#8217;s new in 0.3.0:</p>

<p>3.0 (2007-10-30)</p>

<ul>
<li>All timelines now retrieve all data, not just from last 24 hours (including DMs, @s, sent messages, followers/following lists)</li>
<li>New theme: &#8220;Dumb Terminal.&#8221; Works best on Windows with Bistream Vera Sans Mono or Iconsolata font; OS X has readable mono fonts by default</li>
<li>New window behaviors: Minimize to systray (on by default), minimize when in background, restore when in foreground</li>
<li>Added Native Shell Menus under OS X</li>
<li>Added System Tray Icon in Windows w/ context menu</li>
<li>Added Dock item menu</li>
<li>User-defined CSS tweaks file now works again</li>
<li>Tweets can now be &#8220;selected.&#8221; Hit &#8216;@&#8217; (SHIFT+2) to send reply to selected tweet&#8217;s user</li>
<li>Prefs that require restart to be applied are now indicated</li>
<li>Better descriptions of data retrieval errors; should properly determine if response timed out or if request limit is exceeded</li>
<li>Fixed charcount to reset properly after successful send</li>
<li>Added simple DOM context menus - currently allow user to copy URLs to clipboard</li>
<li>Use &#8216;-khtml-user-select&#8217; to limit selectability of elements; should eliminate many problems with onlick operations</li>
<li>Popup panels should work a bit better; center properly and drag more easily. Popup panels will be moved to modal windows soon</li>
<li>Upgraded to jQuery 1.2.1</li>
<li>Dumped Interface lib, added jQuery.UI lib</li>
<li>Fixed size of protected post icon</li>
<li>Lots of code cleanup and refactoring</li>
</ul>

<p>I&#8217;ve also created <a href="http://funkatron.com/content/UserCSS_A_Simple_Example.swf" target="_blank">a simple screencast</a> in <a href="http://www.jingproject.com/">Jing</a> to show off what I think is one of the coolest, most underused Spaz features: User CSS tweaks. It lets you load up your own CSS file to modify the current theme. If you don&#8217;t like the font size or a color, you can change it yourself, without having to author a whole theme.</p>

<ul>
<li><strong><a href="http://funkatron.com/content/UserCSS_A_Simple_Example.swf" target="_blank">Screencast: UserCSS in Spaz - a simple example</a> (Flash required)</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>I didn&#8217;t record any audio with this screencast, as I didn&#8217;t have a decent mic handy.  Hope it&#8217;s still helpful!</p>

<p>As always, direct bug reports, questions or suggestions to <a href="http://twitter.com/spaz">Spaz at Twitter</a>.</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Help Derek Allard with his open source licensing concerns"
url_title: help-derek-allard-with-his-open-source-licensing-concerns
permalink: help-derek-allard-with-his-open-source-licensing-concerns.html
tags: "bambooinvoice, derek allard, codeigniter, gpl, creativecommons, opensource, copyright"
published: true
category:
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-10-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2408
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/pugno_muliebriter/1384247192/"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1271/1384247192_1328157f35.jpg?v=0" alt="fuzzy copyright" /></a></p>

<p>My friend <a href="http://www.derekallard.com/">Derek Allard</a>, of <a href="http://codeigniter.com/">CodeIgniter</a> fame, <a href="http://www.derekallard.com/blog/post/bambooinvoice-may-be-moving-away-from-the-gpl-open-source-license/">is concerned</a> about the GPL licensing he chose for his open-source web application <a href="http://www.bambooinvoice.org/">BambooInvoice</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Around February of this year, a CodeIgniter user contacted me privately to point out that someone was re-distributing BambooInvoice as their own work.  I&#8217;m not going to use any names or URLs (no point in adding any publicity to them), but they essentially called it &#8220;their business&#8221;-Invoice.  So they offered it for download under a different name, and claimed it was their invoicing software.  They offered a &#8220;demo&#8221; (identical in every way to Bamboo) and it was apparent to me that all they really did was a giant search and replace of the word &#8220;Bamboo&#8221; with &#8220;their business&#8221;.  No credit to me.  No mention of Bamboo, no CodeIgniter license (that was visible), nothing - just a wholesale search and replace.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Derek has clearly thought about this issue a lot, but I bet he could use some sage advice from people who have been through similar situations.  If you have, please consider reading <a href="http://www.derekallard.com/blog/post/bambooinvoice-may-be-moving-away-from-the-gpl-open-source-license/">his post</a> and offering some input. Derek&#8217;s given a lot to the OSS community via CodeIgniter, and I think we should help him out here.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.derekallard.com/blog/post/bambooinvoice-may-be-moving-away-from-the-gpl-open-source-license/">BambooInvoice may be moving away from the GPL Open Source License</a></li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz Wins Best HTML Community App in Adobe AIR Developer Derby"
url_title: spaz-wins-best-html-community-app-in-adobe-air-developer-derby
permalink: spaz-wins-best-html-community-app-in-adobe-air-developer-derby.html
tags: "spaz, twitter, AIR, AIR developer derby, cal evans, award, adobeMAX2007, RIA"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Design
- Spaz
date: 2007-10-01
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2406
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/olddelpasso/998694031/"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1009/998694031_4a27c25ba6.jpg?v=0" alt="slayer - metal hammer awards 2007" /></a></p>

<p>I am pleased as punch to finally be able to announce publicly that <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a>, the <a href="http://twitter.com">Twitter</a> client I developed in HTML and Javascript for the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/air/">Adobe Integrated Runtime</a>, has won <a href="http://www.adobe.com/devnet/air/articles/air_derby_winners.html">&#8220;Best HTML Community Application&#8221;</a> in the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/showcase/special/airderby/">AIR Develper Derby</a>.</p>

<p>I submitted Spaz as something of an afterthought, to be honest. I had received some good feedback on it from a couple people at Adobe, but I didn&#8217;t think it was <em>all that</em>, so to speak.  Throughout the development process I avoided looking at what other developers were doing, especially other Twitter devs, because I was sure it would send me into a tailspin of despair at the bush league-ness of my own kung fu.  After all, Spaz is the first &#8220;Rich Internet Application&#8221; I&#8217;ve written. I hadn&#8217;t even written an AJAX call in any code up until Spaz.</p>

<p>So, receiving this award is a great surprise to me, and very encouraging.  There are a lot of <em>great</em> Twitter clients out there, and this makes me believe that Spaz is at least in the ballpark.  Or, as <a href="http://www.calevans.com/">Cal Evans</a> put it far more succinctly, &#8220;Spaz doesn&#8217;t suck.&#8221;</p>

<p>Thanks to all the users of Spaz, and everyone who has given me feedback. I wrote Spaz because I wanted people to <em>use</em> it, and everyone who does gives me a great deal of encouragement.  And very special thanks to those who have given me feedback &#8212; Spaz is an &#8220;award-winning&#8221; app thanks to you.</p>

<p>BTW, I&#8217;m at <a href="http://www.adobemax2007.com/na/">AdobeMAX2007</a> in Chicago now, so if you&#8217;re an attendee and want to chat about Spaz, drop me a line.</p>

<p>Now, onward to <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/downloads/air.html">AIR Beta 2</a>!</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.adobe.com/devnet/air/articles/air_derby_winners.html">Adobe AIR Developer Center: Adobe AIR Developer Derby winners</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.adobe.com/newsletters/edge/september2007/articles/article1/index.html?trackingid=BHUMJ">Adobe Edge: Announcing the winners of the Adobe AIR Derby</a></li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHP|Works 2007: Presentations and Thoughts"
url_title: phpworks-2007-presentations-and-thoughts
permalink: phpworks-2007-presentations-and-thoughts.html
tags: "phpsecinfo, infosec, codeigniter, slides, presentation, phpworks, phpworks2007, works07, php, conference"
published: true
category:
- Inspekt
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2007-09-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2370
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/tychay/1381970953/in/set-72157602016776951"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1226/1381970953_fd15b3e524.jpg" alt="php|works - it's about the booze. Photo by Terry Chay" title="php|works - it's about the booze. Photo by Terry Chay" /></a></p>

<p><a href="http://works.phparch.com/">php|works 2007</a> was last week, and it was a great experience for me.  Here are the slides and code from the presentations I gave:</p>

<ul>
<li><strong><a href="http://funkatron.com/content/EdFinkler-Introduction%20to%20CodeIgniter.pdf">Introduction to CodeIgniter</a></strong>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/content/CI-talk.zip">Example app used in talk &#8212; includes CodeIgniter and ZendFramework</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><strong><a href="http://funkatron.com/content/EdFinkler-Securing%20the%20PHP%20Environment%20With%20PhpSecInfo.pdf">Securing the PHP Environment With PHPSecInfo</a></strong></li>
</ul>

<p>I really enjoyed my trip to Atlanta and the conference experience. Much like php|tek this year in Chicago, &#8216;works was filled with lots of great content, smart people, and a casual, comfortable atmosphere that makes the whole thing a lot of fun. The <a href="http://phparch.com/">php|architect</a> conferences lack pretension, and that&#8217;s really nice &#8212; it&#8217;s about the people and sharing knowledge. And this one was really special for me because it&#8217;s the first time I&#8217;ve given a presentation to my colleagues in the community.  I was very nervous, but it all turned out well.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m too <strike>lazy</strike> busy to write out an extended journal of the whole experience, but here are some memorable moments:</p>

<ul>
<li>Being sick just two days before I was about to leave, and getting better just in time to go</li>
<li>Having my first flight cancelled, giving me time to mostly finish my CodeIgniter talk before I left the Indy airport</li>
<li>Getting to the hotel just in time to catch <a href="http://shiflett.org/">Chris Shiflett</a>&#8217;s funny PHP4 is Dead keynote</li>
<li>Discovering the hotel room had a flat-panel TV. Unfortunately, no HD content</li>
<li>Catching up with Lucas Nealan, and getting an unexpected phonecall with great news</li>
<li>The fact that there were about 7,000 iPhones on-hand</li>
<li>The <a href="http://www.preinheimer.com/">Paul Reinheimer</a> quad-core drinking demo (sponsored by Microsoft)</li>
<li><em>Ramblecast</em>: the loudest, drunkest, least productive group podcasting experiment ever</li>
<li>Learning a lot more about <a href="http://php.net/filter">the Filter extension</a> from <a href="http://www.derickrethans.nl/">Derick Rethans</a>, and seeing how it compares to <a href="http://inspekt.org">Inspekt</a></li>
<li>Losing power in the middle of my <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PHPSecInfo</a> talk, and <a href="http://paul-m-jones.com/">Paul M. Jones</a> resuscitating the projector</li>
<li><a href="http://terrychay.com">Terry Chay</a>&#8217;s software architecture talk. I didn&#8217;t agree with everything he said, but I laughed my ass off</li>
<li>Meeting people who have actually heard of me and used tools I&#8217;ve made. Weird</li>
<li>Good conversations with too many people to name</li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Giving Two Talks at php|works Atlanta this week"
url_title: giving-two-talks-at-phpworks-atlanta-this-week
permalink: giving-two-talks-at-phpworks-atlanta-this-week.html
tags: "php, conference, php|works, works07, phpsecinfo, codeigniter, ellislab, infosec"
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- Development
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-09-10
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2368
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/55786483@N00/370594198/" alt="James Gang" title="James Gang"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/187/370594198_2682eb5585_m.jpg" alt="James Gang" class="alignright" /></a></p>

<p>This Friday, I&#8217;ll be giving two talks at <a href="http://works.phparch.com">php|works Atlanta</a>: one on <a href="http://codeigniter.com">the CodeIgniter framework</a>, and one on <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PhpSecInfo</a>.</p>

<h3><a href="http://works.phparch.com/c/schedule/talk/d2s4/2">Intro to CodeIgniter</a></h3>

<p><em>September 14, 2007 @ 1:15 &#8211; 2:15pm</em></p>

<p>CodeIgniter is an open-source web application framework written in PHP. Created by EllisLab, CI is descended from the ExpressionEngine CMS system, and therefore has a focus on real-world needs and solutions for PHP developers. CI is easy to deploy, and works with a wide variety of environments (even FTP-only shared hosting accounts). It offers powerful features like MVC and ActiveRecord without requiring the developer to adhere to strict coding guidelines. It&#8217;s easy to extend, and plays well with other code libraries like PEAR and Zend Framework.</p>

<p>In this talk we&#8217;ll go over the basics of CI: how to deploy it and writing a simple application. As time allows, we&#8217;ll discuss how to extend the framework with other libraries.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://works.phparch.com/mats/Ed-codeigniter.mp3">Audio preview of the session</a></li>
</ul>

<h3><a href="http://works.phparch.com">Securing the PHP Environment With PhpSecInfo</a></h3>

<p><em>September 14, 2007 @ 4:30 &#8211; 5:30pm</em></p>

<p>PhpSecInfo is an easy to use security auditing tool for the PHP Environment. We&#8217;ll discuss how to use PhpSecInfo as part of your web app security toolkit, and how to customize and extend it for your specific needs, including using the Zend_Environment_Security module from the Zend Framework.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://works.phparch.com/mats/Ed-phpsecinfo.mp3">Audio preview of the session</a></li>
</ul>

<p>Hope to see you there!</p>




<!-- end of post -->

<p>A relatively major new release of <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz/">Spaz.AIR</a>, version 0.2.0, is now available.  This version has a number of new features:</p>

<ul>
<li>New &#8220;borderless&#8221; window</li>
<li>Multiple themes</li>
<li>User-defined CSS &#8220;overrides&#8221;</li>
<li>Event sounds, using the <a href="http://www.adiumxtras.com/index.php?a=xtras&amp;xtra_id=602">Tokyo Train Station</a> soundset by Dominik Dimaano</li>
<li>Debugging tools and logging</li>
</ul>

<p>I&#8217;m really happy with this new version, and anxious to hear what you think.  Please check it out, and let me know your impressions.  Remember that you can contact me on Twitter at <a href="http://twitter.com/spaz">twitter.com/spaz</a></p>

<hr />

<ul>
<li><strong><a href="http://funkatron.com/getspaz">Download the latest version of Spaz.AIR</a></strong> (Requires the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/downloads/air.html">Adobe Integrated Runtime</a>)</li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz/">More information on Spaz</a></li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "What Matt Mullenweg doesn&#8217;t know about PHP5, and how it hurts him and his users"
url_title: what-matt-mullenweg-doesnt-know-about-php5-and-how-it-hurts-him-and-his-use
permalink: what-matt-mullenweg-doesnt-know-about-php5-and-how-it-hurts-him-and-his-use.html
tags: "wordpress, photomatt, matt mullenweg, ignorance, php5, php4, security"
published: true
category:
- Development
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-07-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2355
---
<p>Matt Mullenweg, the dude behind Wordpress, has posted something of <a href="http://photomatt.net/2007/07/13/on-php/">a rant</a> about PHP5 in the light of the upcoming drop of PHP4 support:</p>

<blockquote>None of the most requested features for WordPress would be any easier (or harder) if they were written for PHP 4 or 5 or Python. They&rsquo;d just be different. The hard part usually has little to do with the underlying server-side language.</blockquote>

<p>Here&#8217;s a hint: don&#8217;t give the users what they <em>say</em> they want until you give them what they <em>need.</em> &#8212; even if they don&#8217;t realize what that is.  Here&#8217;s some PHP5-only features that could be helping Wordpress users <em>right now</em>:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>Parameterized SQL input to eliminate SQL injection attacks (security)</strong><br />
Strictly enforcing the use of parameterized SQL input in Wordpress development would dramatically reduce, and in all likelyhood <em>eliminate</em>, the possibility of SQL  injection attacks against Wordpress.  Using <a href="http://us.php.net/pdo">the PHP5-only PDO extension</a> would allows this <em>even with databases that don&#8217;t natively support this feature</em>.</p></li>
<li><p><strong><a href="http://us.php.net/filter">Filter extension</a> to combat XSS, CSRF, etc. attacks (security)</strong><br />
The PHP5-only filter extension adds fast, built-in input filtering functions.  Given the history of problems Wordpress has with handling user input properly, enforcing the use of this or another solid input filtering system would surely reduce the amount of input handling errors in the WP codebase.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Turning off remote file inclusion by default (security)</strong><br />
Remote file inclusion vulnerabilities account for approximately 40% of all security issues with PHP-based applications.  The <a href="http://us2.php.net/manual/en/ref.filesystem.php#ini.allow-url-include"><code>allow_url_include</code></a> configuration setting, added in PHP 5.2.0, disables remote file inclusion by default.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Prepared statement/transaction support in <a href="http://us.php.net/pdo">PDO</a> and <a href="http://us.php.net/manual/en/ref.mysqli.php">MySQLi</a> (performance)</strong><br />
Prepared statements not only provide the benefits of parameterized input mentioned above, but significant performance increases can be had with them.  AFAIK, it&#8217;s not possible to support these features in MySQL under PHP4.</p></li>
<li><p><strong><a href="http://us.php.net/manual/en/language.oop5.php">Improved OOP features</a> and support (code quality, extensibility)</strong><br />
This would aid developers first, which in turn would benefit users, by making (in my opinion and based on anecdotal evidence) a large project like Wordpress easier to maintain.  Code reusability is improved, quality is increased, and hackish approaches like global variables become unnecessary.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve hacked the guts of Wordpress and written numerous plugins, and I&#8217;m <em>still</em> shocked at what a garbled mess the WP codebase is, and how much easier it is to write extensions for content management systems that embrace OOP.  Of course, OOP is very possible in PHP4, but PHP5 adds a number of features that make a significant difference in team development (public/private/protected properties and methods, for example).</p>

<p>(A cynic might suggest that one reason to <em>not</em> clean up the WP architecture is because that would break backwards compatibility with the extensive library of plugins that has a lot to do with Wordpress&#8217; success.  There would be some irony in that, no?)</p></li>
</ul>

<p>I think this line from Matt&#8217;s post might be telling:</p>

<blockquote>Even hosted PHP-powered services who have no shared host compatibility concerns like 30boxes, Digg, Flickr, and WordPress.com, have been slow to move and when they do it will probably be because of speed or security, not features.</blockquote>

<p>The thing is, support of PHP5-only features in WP would give it better speed and security <em>right now</em>.  And especially in the case of security, Matt&#8217;s reliance on what users <em>say</em> they want is a critical error: users don&#8217;t ask about security until well after it becomes a serious issue.  Wordpress has one of the worst security records of any PHP application, so I&#8217;ll go out on a limb and say that it&#8217;s a problem <strong>now</strong>.  Even if WP users aren&#8217;t talking about it, <strong>WP&#8217;s core dev team should have addressed this already</strong>.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve said before that web app developers are the stewards of their users&#8217; data.  Our users need and expect us to anticipate and address their security.  If we don&#8217;t do that, and simply <a href="http://www.logicalfallacies.info/appealtopopularity.html">base our actions on popular opinion</a>, we&#8217;re being <strong>irresponsible</strong>.</p>

<hr />

<p>On a basically unrelated note, it <em>really</em> is disappointing to see Matt sink to <a href="http://www.logicalfallacies.info/personalattack.html">ad-hominem attacks</a> when making his argument:</p>

<blockquote>In 2007, [the PHP site] still doesn&rsquo;t have obvious permalinks. They do have a RSS 1.0 feed though, remember those?</blockquote>

<blockquote> Some app makers felt sorry for PHP 5 and decided to create the world&rsquo;s ugliest advocacy site&#8230;</blockquote>

<p>That&#8217;s bush league, Matt.  Cut the elitism BS and stick to a proper, logically sound argument.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2355" data-url-title="what-matt-mullenweg-doesnt-know-about-php5-and-how-it-hurts-him-and-his-use">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1834" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Joshua May</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://www.notjosh.com/blog</div>
		<div class="comment-date">07/15/2007 10:59:58 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>yeah, I agree. It&#8217;s just a cat-fight, though. Not everyone would be happy, and that was obvious, but it&#8217;d kind of sad to see someone in that position reacting that way.</p>

<p>That said, I completely understand where he&#8217;s coming from. But I still think it&#8217;s much better to embrace progress. Early adoption is key.</p>

<p>Consider me still not a Wordpress user or advocate.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1835" class="comment-id anchor"></a>

	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1836" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Matt</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://photomatt.net/</div>
		<div class="comment-date">07/16/2007 05:51:59 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Thanks for the thoughtful entry! This is just the kind of thing I was hoping people would post. Just a few notes:</p>

<ol>
<li>We now have parameterized SQL in core.</li>
<li>We&#8217;re not concerned with databases besides MySQL.</li>
<li>We have fine HTML filtering with KSES. The filtering has never been a problem, it&#8217;s just places where it&#8217;s been not applied.</li>
<li>While it would be nice to get a little more performance by using prepared statements, SQL is generally less than 5% of execution time.</li>
<li>OOP - In our experience strict OO can be fairly intimidating to casual coders, who are the people who have created the countless plugins for WP that make it as popular as it is today and, as you note, we&#8217;d like to maintain backward compatibility for. However internal APIs and code has embraced OO methods where appropiate.</li>
</ol>

<p>While significant efforts have been made in auditing WP&#8217;s code, and we will continue to do so, I&#8217;m operating under the assumption that someday someone will find something, so our focus is on notification and ease of upgrading. Since people are using WP as a platform we need to make it upgrade like one.</p>
</div>
	</li>

I hope so, but I don&#8217;t know that either. 		<div class="comment-body"><p>On the topic of parameterized queries and prepared statements with PDO, you might want to check out the successor to PEAR DB - MDB2:</p>

<p>http://pear.php.net/MDB2</p>

<p>You&#8217;ll likely want to load the &#8220;Extended&#8221; module too:</p>

<p>$db =&amp; MDB2::connect($dsn);
$db-&gt;setFetchMode(MDB2_FETCHMODE_ASSOC);
$db-&gt;loadModule(&#8220;Extended&#8221;, NULL, FALSE);</p>

<p>MDB2 works in PHP4 too if you&#8217;re feeling sinful. :)</p>

	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1850" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">funkatron</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://funkatron.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">07/18/2007 11:49:10 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>@alex: &#8220;Certainly we can all agree that compelling features make for quicker adoption of upgrades.&#8221;</p>

<p>True, yes, but&#8230; let&#8217;s look at something matt said in his post:</p>

<p>&#8220;What was it that made PHP 4 so successful? What are we doing to emphasize those strengths? Why wasn’t PHP 5 compelling to that same audience? &#8220;</p>

<p>I think a lot of what made PHP4 so successful was simply timing, good integration with Apache, and a shallow learning curve.  All of these things are also present in PHP3.  A couple features in PHP4 aided things a bit, like native sessions (although pure PHP solutions existed, which Matt seems to prefer), but I don&#8217;t think it&#8217;s the case that particular PHP4-only features dramatically increased adoption. PHP4 had a fully rewritten engine, but feature-wise 4 was very much an <em>evolutionary</em> change, just like PHP5 and just like PHP6 seems to be. Things that have been present in <em>all</em> PHP versions since 3 were, imho, what led to PHP&#8217;s dominance.</p>

<p>The difference between the jump from 3 to 4 and 4 to 5 is that PHP has a far, far larger audience to deal with, and a MUCH larger group of applications which may have bc issues (although I think those are fairly minor in most cases).  I suspect that is why adoption of PHP5 is slower, and not because of anything inherent to PHP4 that&#8217;s not there in PHP5.</p>
</div>
	</li>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>I&#8217;m with Sean on this one - the problem for the vast majority of developers out there isn&#8217;t that they don&#8217;t want to move to PHP5, it is that they <em>cannot</em> because their host doesn&#8217;t support it.</p>

<p>When the PHP developers broke all chance web hosts had of making a painless upgrade from 4 to 5, they broke with it all chance of quick adoption. Sadly I believe ultimately the blame must lay with them and no-one else. It was an internals design decision that caused this mess beyond anything else.</p>

<p>If they do the same from PHP 5 to 6 then quite frankly most of us can kiss our beloved language goodbye within a very short period of time (which, as a full-time professional PHP developer, scares me greatly).</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">

<p>Yep, in larger projects with multiple programmers OOP is a blessing. That is quite true. But like above stated, a new OOP vs Procedure war is a bit too much and I won&#8217;t join it. ^^</p>

<p>If any, my point was actually that PHP5 doesn&#8217;t make it anymore secure persee, it&#8217;s not like: I install PHP5 and I&#8217;m safe. That is giving developers the wrong example.</p>

<p>Most PHP scripters think they are safe, I guess it&#8217;s a good start by changing attitudes of PHP scripters by convincing them it&#8217;s okay to upgrade to PHP5, but it doesn&#8217;t mean you back sit back and relax now.</p>

In order to offer both flavours you have to have one of them running as CGI, or split them out across different servers, both of which are quite messy solutions. If you host a number of high traffic PHP 4 sites and then swap them all to the CGI vrsion just so you can get PHP 5 on there, you are going to notice the hit on your servers.</p>

<p>If you are a decently sized host then you replicate this across thousands of servers, it is no trivial matter.</p>

<p>If PHP 6 will not work with PHP 5 (which I highly suspect) then web hosts are shit-out of luck - at the moment they can at least juggle 4 and 5 via CGI and Module, but which one gets the elbow when 6 comes along?</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Vintage Computer Festival This Weekend @ Purdue"
url_title: vintage-computer-festival-this-weekend-purdue
permalink: vintage-computer-festival-this-weekend-purdue.html
tags: "purdue, west lafayette, midwest, vintage, retro, computing, commodore, atari, vendors, collection, festival
"
published: true
category:
- Hardware
date: 2007-07-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2354
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/herby_fr/75562564/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/37/75562564_71ca52357f.jpg" alt="Untitled by herby_fr" class="centered" /></a></p>

<p>I&#8217;m totally pumped about this weekends&#8217; <a href="http://www.vintage.org/2007/midwest/">Vintage Computer Festival Midwest 3.0</a> at <a href="http://www.purdue.edu/">Purdue University</a>.  It&#8217;s only $5 to get in and free for kids under 17.  Some registered exhibits that sound cool include:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><strong>Geek Museum Collection:</strong>
&#8220;Sampling of the Geek Museum&#8217;s mobile collection focusing on a wide range of general consumer electronics computing history will be displayed with demos. Great for kids!&#8221;</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Commodore Plus/4:</strong>
&#8220;The Commodore Plus/4 was a home computer released by Commodore International in 1984. Commodore billed the Plus/4 as the first home computer designed especially for productivity applications. The Plus/4 included a ROM based integrated software package containing word processing, spreadsheet, database, and graphing applications.&#8221;</p></li>
</ul>

<p>I&#8217;m something of a collector of old hardware myself, especially game consoles and home computers.  My current collections includes, off the top of my head:</p>

<ul>
<li>Magnavox Odyssey</li>
<li>Commodore 64 + 1541 Floppy Drive</li>
<li>Atari 7800</li>
<li>NES x2</li>
<li>Amiga 600</li>
<li>SuperNES</li>
<li>TurboGrafx-16</li>
<li>Sega Genesis + 32X + Sega CD</li>
<li>Atari Jaguar</li>
<li>Sega Saturn</li>
<li>Sony Playstation</li>
<li>Gameboy Color</li>
<li>Sega Dreamcast</li>
<li>Sony Playstation 2</li>
<li>Microsoft XBox</li>
<li>Nintendo Wii</li>
</ul>

<p>And I&#8217;m sure I&#8217;m forgetting some stuff (I think I have a 128k Mac, but I honestly am not sure).  That&#8217;s just the hardware; I have hundreds of games crossing all of those systems.  I need to dig through that stuff sometime and catalog it.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz.AIR early alpha screencast"
url_title: spazair-early-alpha-screencast
permalink: spazair-early-alpha-screencast.html
tags: "AIR, adobe integrated runtime, apollo, twitter, spaz, screencast"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- The Web Problem
- Spaz
date: 2007-07-11
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2353
---
<p><img src="http://funkatron.com/images/uploads/spazAIR.png" alt="spazAIR.png" border="0" width="124" height="147" align="right" />So I&#8217;m basically rewriting <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a> as an <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/air/">AIR</a> app.  You get a ton of wins with AIR, the biggest for me being the ability to leverage my web skillz to write a desktop app.  Some folks may not realize that <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/air/develop_ajax.html">AIR allows you to write apps in pure HTML+JS</a> &#8212; no Flash, no Flex.  This is a Big Win for me, and a lot of other folks, I think.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s what I&#8217;m using to write Spaz.AIR:</p>

<ul>
<li>Dreamweaver (although you really don&#8217;t need to &#8212; it just makes packaging the app a bit easier)</li>
<li><a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/spry/">Spry JS Framework, v1.5</a></li>
<li><a href="http://jquery.com/">JQuery</a></li>
<li>Plain old HTML and CSS</li>
</ul>

<p>Anyway, I recorded a <a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/spaz.AIR-earlyAlpha.mp4">screencast</a> of a <em>very</em> early alpha version of Spaz.AIR.  <strike>The file is <strong>big</strong>, because I wanted high quality but also something my poor 12&#8221; Powerbook could actually handle recording</strike> I was having trouble with playback on Windows, so I converted the file to mp4 via Quicktime Pro.  Now it&#8217;s 9MB instead of 290MB, and looks almost identical.</p>

<ul>
<li><strong><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/spaz.AIR-earlyAlpha.mp4">Spaz.AIR early alpha screencast (~9MB)</a></strong></li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/gudguds/21768217/" title="HI Atl"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/17/21768217_99259cdbfe.jpg" class="centered" /></a></p>

<p>Through an apparent clerical error, I&#8217;ve been chosen to speak at <a href="http://works.phparch.com/c/p/index" title="Harness the Power of PHP, or something">php|works Atlanta</a> on September 12-13.  I&#8217;ll be speaking on <a href="http://PhpSecInfo.com" title="PhpSecInfo provides an equivalent to the phpinfo() function that reports security information about the PHP environment, and offers suggestions for improvement.">PHPSecInfo</a>, the PHP environment security auditing tool.</p>

<p>I really enjoyed php|tek Chicago this May, which was my first <a href="http://www.phparch.com/" title="Write something about mayonaise and PHP here">PHP Architect</a> conference, and I trust this one will be just as cool, with talks from folks like <a href="http://benramsey.com/" title="I'm jealous of him because he has way more feed subscribers than me">Ben Ramsey</a>, <a href="http://eliw.com/" title="Note: lay off the Digg jokes">Eli White</a>, <a href="http://shiflett.org/" title="Try not to be sick this time">Chris Shiflett</a>, and <a href="http://www.terrychay.com/blog/" title="Mothafuckin'">Terry Chay</a>.  Terry and I will also be competing in the first annual PHP offend-off, where we see who can most efficiently insult the sensibilities of a room full of attendees.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve never been father south than D.C., so I&#8217;m interested to see what the land of Andre 3000 is like.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "New Spaz v0.3.3 available; future plans"
url_title: new-spaz-v033-available-future-plans
permalink: new-spaz-v033-available-future-plans.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Development
- Spaz
date: 2007-07-01
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2350
---
<p><img src="http://funkatron.com/images/uploads/spaz-icon-QS.png" border="1" height="166" width="168" alt="spaz-icon-QS.png" align="right" style="margin:0 0 5px 5px" />My little twitter client <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz">Spaz</a> has a new release out, v0.3.3. This adds a 2-minute auto refresh of the currently displayed timeline, and fixes a high CPU usage bug. Unfortunately, this latter is also a bit of a regression, as the cause of the high CPU usage helped Spaz handle loading and painting userpics more quickly. Hopefully I can improve this in later releases.</p>

<p>Speaking of later releases, I&#8217;m giving serious consideration to rewriting Spaz using the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/air/">Adobe Integrated Runtime</a> (AIR, previously Apollo). There&#8217;s a great deal of appeal in utilizing web development and design skills to create desktop apps. <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/spry/">Adobe&#8217;s Spry javascript framework</a> has <em>excellent</em> data handling tools, beyond what most other JS frameworks offer: you can use arbitrary XML, JSON, or even HTML as a data source.  Combining that with the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/wiki/index.php/AIR:Dreamweaver_CS3_Extension">Dreamweaver AIR extension</a> and <a href="http://www.adobe.com/devnet/spry/">DW CS3 Spry integration</a>, and there is some real power to rapidly develop RIAs without having to learn new tools and languages.</p>

<p>[tags]spaz, spry, AIR, dreamweaver, twitter[/tags]</p>




<!-- end of post -->

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rabih/658917185/"><img src="http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1390/658917185_e8a2ecc481.jpg" alt="i can see my butt" /></a></p>

<p>Cal Evans just posted <a href="http://devzone.zend.com/article/2248-PHP-Abstract-Podcast-Episode-8-CodeIgnighter-Overview" title="PHP Abstract Podcast Episode 8: CodeIgnighter Overview">Episode 8 of the PHP Abstract podcast</a>, which I contributed.  This time I talk about <a href="http://codeigniter.com" title="CodeIgniter is a powerful PHP framework with a very small footprint, built for PHP coders who need a simple and elegant toolkit to create full-featured web applications.">CodeIgniter</a>, which is my development framework of choice lately.  I really like CI&#8217;s balance of convention <em>and</em> flexibility, which I think makes it more &#8220;PHP-like&#8221; than, say, <a href="http://cakephp.org" title="CakePHP">Cake</a> or <a href="http://www.symfony-project.com/" title="symfony is an open-source PHP web framework">Symfony</a>.</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "New Spaz &amp; Ars Article"
url_title: new-spaz-ars-article
permalink: new-spaz-ars-article.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Development
- Spaz
date: 2007-06-28
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2348
---
<p><img src="http://funkatron.com/content/uploads/spaz-qs.png" alt="Spaz Icon" width="155" height="158" border="1" align="right" />It&#8217;s been a while, but I&#8217;m back on the <a href="http://funkatron.com/spaz" title="Spaz, the multiuser Twitter client for OS X, Windows and Linux">Spaz</a> development bandwagon again. The newest release is 0.3.2, and it adds a few new things:</p>

<ul>
<li>added new right-click/ctrl+click menus on messages.</li>
<li>changed double-click action: starts reply to user, unless double-clicking
on a direct message, in which case it starts a dm.</li>
<li>Fixed/added direct message reading</li>
<li>Added &#8220;replies&#8221; support</li>
<li>Added &#8220;featured&#8221; support</li>
<li>Increased depth of message boxes to handle larger sizes</li>
<li>Switched to multiline output of statuses.  All statuses should now be
fully readable.</li>
<li>Removed rounded rects from Windows version because standard drawing funcs
look horrible
</pre></li>
</ul>

<p>Also, there&#8217;s <a href="http://arstechnica.com/journals/apple.ars/2007/06/28/spaz-the-other-twitter-client-for-os-x-and-windows-and-linux" title="Spaz: the other Twitter client for OS X (and Windows, and Linux)">a great article on Spaz at ArsTechnica</a>, a site I&#8217;ve been reading for many, many years now.  If you like it, consider <a href="http://digg.com/apple/Spaz_the_other_Twitter_client_for_OS_X_and_Windows_and_Linux" title="click-whoring is fun">Digg-ing</a> the article and let more people know about Spaz.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "This is Intelligent Television, fool!"
url_title: this-is-intelligent-television-fool
permalink: this-is-intelligent-television-fool.html
tags: "intellivision, retro, master component"
published: true
category:
- Hardware
- Gaming
date: 2007-06-14
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2345

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Shocker: Beta software contains bugs! To find out more, pay me"
url_title: shocker-beta-software-contains-bugs-to-find-out-more-pay-me
permalink: shocker-beta-software-contains-bugs-to-find-out-more-pay-me.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
date: 2007-06-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2343
---
<p>David Maynor, previously known for <a href="http://wifinetnews.com/archives/007454.html" title="the disastrous clown car known as the Apple Wifi Hack">the disastrous clown car known as the Apple Wifi Hack</a>, posted some info on <a href="http://erratasec.blogspot.com/2007/06/niiiice.html" title="Niiiice">exploits he&#8217;s discovered in the new Safari beta</a>.  This is a bit disappointing, but not altogether surprising, considering it&#8217;s, ya know, beta software.</p>

<p>What&#8217;s more disappointing is this &#8220;I don&#8217;t like Company A, so being irresponsible is kosher&#8221; kind of thinking that Maynor exhibits:</p>

<blockquote>Keeping with our disclosure policy, we do not report bugs to Apple.</blockquote>

<p>And further down:</p>

<blockquote>&#8230; in most cases we will give vendors as long as they need to fix problems. If the vendor is unresponsive or make threats, we will give them 30 days then release details. If a vendor answers a vulnerability disclosure with marketing and spin attempts, we no longer report vulnerabilities to that vendor but the information goes into our Hacker Eye View program for customers and will be used in pentesting.</blockquote>

<p>So if you happen to use a product that is made by a company Mr. Maynor decides he doesn&#8217;t like, he won&#8217;t tell you what the problem is or how to fix it.  Unless you pay him.  But you will get vague descriptions of the exploit in his official Blogger site.</p>

<p>Two things are problematic with this.  First, the fact that Maynor even <em>has</em> a policy like this, one that is so obviously open to abuse via personal preference and emotion.  There are bigger things to consider than hurt feelings when dealing with vulnerabilities, like <strong>the safety of the people using the exploitable product</strong>.  Anyone who decides to take on the role of a security &#8220;expert&#8221; or &#8220;adviser&#8221; needs to understand that and act accordingly.  If they can&#8217;t, they need to find a new line of work.</p>

<p>Secondly, the caveat that Maynor is willing to release this info for a price.  I won&#8217;t make the argument that <em>no</em> exploit information should ever be anything but free &#8212; I haven&#8217;t thought that one out enough &#8212; but I do think it is wrong to only release exploit information about a free, widely distributed, consumer-level application to folks who have paid the toll.  This is, I believe, a matter of public safety, and treating it like some kind of mercenary mission demonstrates a disappointing lack of regard towards those who will be most affected by these exploits: the users.</p>

<p>All of us who do work in security need to do a gut check, and make sure we&#8217;re doing this for the right reasons.  The public good needs to be placed before our greed and our egos.</p>

<p>The use of the word, “public good” is very apropos. Unfortunately, free market systems (driven by greed and immune to egos) are not good at pricing “public goods” (e.g. fire, police, national security, roads, airwaves, libraries, schools) in an efficient manner—instead the good is drastically underproduced.</p>

<p>When you see thinly veiled extortion attempts, it is a natural outcome from an attitude that doesn’t realize that there are limits to rampant capitalism.</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Safari 3.0 Beta and Speed Download: busted"
url_title: safari-30-beta-and-speed-download-busted
permalink: safari-30-beta-and-speed-download-busted.html
tags: "safari, beta, speed download, crash, plugin"
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2007-06-11
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2342
---
<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/novemberborn/107403175/" title="Safari Crash"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/44/107403175_ca67804b3e_o.png" /></a></p>

<p><strong>Update: This is fixed in <a href="http://www.yazsoft.com/" title="Yazsoft">Speed Download 4.1.12</a></strong></p>

<p><strike>Suckers</strike> Early adopters like me have already downloaded the Safari 3.0 beta, because it pays to be super cool like us.  However, it&#8217;s hard to be awesome when your browser crashes on startup, like mine was.  It looks like the Speed Download plugin I had installed was at fault.</p>

<p>To remove it, I went to <code>&lt;My Home Directory&gt;/Library/InputManagers/</code> and trashed the <code>SpeedDownload Enhancer</code> folder. Now Safari 3.0 starts nicely.</p>

Full API docs are included in the download.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://inspekt.googlecode.com/files/inspekt-20070531.zip">http://inspekt.googlecode.com/files/inspekt-20070531.zip</a></li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://code.google.com/p/inspekt/wiki/BasicUsage">http://code.google.com/p/inspekt/wiki/BasicUsage</a></li>
</ul>

<p>You can also get an SVN checkout from the Google Code page:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://code.google.com/p/inspekt/source">http://code.google.com/p/inspekt/source</a></li>
</ul>

<p>I&#8217;m interested to hear feedback on Inspekt, so please feel free to drop me a line or leave a comment.  Thanks!</p>

    echo "YOU SHOULD &lt;strong&gt;JOIN&lt;/strong&gt; US! drop your resume to contact@grou.ps &lt;br /&gt;";

    exit;
}
else {
    die("maybe next time...");
}</pre>

<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/x180/503535890/in/set-72157600225783815/" title="I could feed a family of 15 in Somalia for the price of my hipster doofus t-shirt."><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/191/503535890_b929f73b2e.jpg" alt="A picture of that fucking prick DHH" /></a></p>

<pre>
powerfunk:~ coj$ curl -I <a href="http://gettingreal.37signals.com/index.php">http://gettingreal.37signals.com/index.php</a>
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 22 May 2007 04:00:18 GMT
Server: Apache/2.2.4
Accept-Ranges: bytes
X-Powered-By: <strong>PHP/4.4.4</strong>
Content-Type: text/html
</pre>

<p><em>Bwahahahaha</em></p>

<p />

<p>Funny thing is, I don&#8217;t see why they&#8217;re using PHP for this.  There&#8217;s no dynamic aspect to the site from a user perspective, and it&#8217;s a single page site.  Seems like plain old html would be a better, faster choice.  But hey, when has 37Signals ever been interested in performance? <em>rimshot</em></p>

<p />

<p>(Thanks to <a href="http://pixelated-dreams.com/">Davey</a> for the tip)</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Inspekt Project funded by OWASP"
url_title: inspekt_project_funded_by_owasp
permalink: inspekt_project_funded_by_owasp.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2007-05-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2334
---
<p>I&#8217;m very, very excited to announce that <a href="http://www.owasp.org/">OWASP</a> has <a href="https://lists.owasp.org/pipermail/owasp-all/2007-May/000039.html">chosen to fund development</a> of what I&#8217;m calling &#8220;<strong>Inspekt</strong>&#8221; as part of their <a href="http://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Spring_Of_Code_2007">OWASP Spring of Code 2007</a>.  You can read my full proposal at the <a href="http://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Spring_Of_Code_2007_Applications#EdFinkler_-_A_comprehensive_input_retrieval.2Ffiltering_system_for_PHP">OWASP SoC Application Page</a></p>

<p>The idea behind Inspekt is to provide a comprehensive input filtering and validation library for PHP.  Building upon Chris Shiflett&#8217;s original Zend_Filter_Input implementation, the primary <em>new</em> features will be:</p>

<ul>
<li>Provide retrieval and filtering support for multidimensional arrays</li>
<li>Provide solutions for scoping issues (avoid the need for &#8220;global&#8221; keywords everywhere)</li>
<li>A variety of helper methods to reduce code verbosity</li>
<li>Block deprecated HTTP_*_VARS and other ways to grab input data without filtering</li>
<li>Auto-restrictions on input defined programatically or via configuration files</li>
<li>Compatible with PHP4 and PHP5</li>
<li>Self contained; not reliant on external libraries</li>
<li>Able to work with a wide variety of frameworks and app architectures; easily &#8220;pluggable&#8221; into any given web app</li>
</ul>

<p>At this point I&#8217;m not sure where exactly the project will be hosted during development.  I want to at least have a browsable SVN repo, and some kind of mailing list.  I&#8217;m in the middle of php|tek 2007 right now, but I expect this weeked I can sort more of the details out.  I only have about two months to do this, so I need to get started!</p>

<p>[tags]php, infosec, php security, inspekt, owasp, tek07[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The PHP App Insecurity Top 20"
url_title: the_php_app_insecurity_top_20
permalink: the_php_app_insecurity_top_20.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-04-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2316
---
<p>I&#8217;ve spent some of my down time in the past couple weeks working with the <a href="http://nvd.nist.gov">NIST NVD</a> data to get stats on PHP application vulnerabilities.  What follows is a breakdown of the 20 PHP-based applications that had the highest aggregate vulnerability scores (NIST assigns a score from 1-10 for the severity of each entry), and the highest total number of vulnerabilities, over the past 12 months.  Of the two, I feel that the aggregate score is a better indicator of security issues.</p>

<p>A few caveats:</p>

<ul>
<li>The data here covers the period between April 1 2006 and April 1 2007.</li>
<li>This obviously only includes <strong>reported</strong> vulnerabilities.  There are surely a lot more applications that are very insecure, but for one reason or another haven&#8217;t had as many reports.</li>
<li>I chose 20 as the cutoff mainly for the sake of making the data a little easier to swallow (and chart nicely). There are about 1,800 distinct apps in the NIST NVD that are (as far as I could determine) PHP-based.</li>
</ul>

<p>Without further ado, here are the tepid Excel charts:</p>

<p><a href="http://blog.funkatron.com/wp-content/php-top20-april-score.png"><img src="http://blog.funkatron.com/wp-content/_php-top20-april-score.png" alt="Nist NVD Data - April 1 2006 to April 1 2007 - PHP Apps by Score Count" title="" /></a></p>

<p><a href="http://blog.funkatron.com/wp-content/php-top20-april-entries.png"><img src="http://blog.funkatron.com/wp-content/_php-top20-april-entries.png" alt="Nist NVD Data - April 1 2006 to April 1 2007 - PHP Apps by Entry Count" title="" /></a></p>

<p>A couple notes:</p>

<ul>
<li>There are 25 entries in the top &#8220;20&#8221; by vulnerability count, due to matching vulnerability counts.</li>
<li>I&#8217;d never even <strong>heard</strong> of <a href="http://www.mybboard.net/">MyBulletinBoard</a>, the top entry in both lists.  It hasn&#8217;t had any vulnerabilities in the NVD since September of 2006, which says something about how numerous and severe the entries between April and September 2006 were.  This appears to be the same product as &#8220;MyBB,&#8221; so perhaps the situation has improved, as MyBB only has one NVD entry in the entire period (<a href="http://nvd.nist.gov/nvd.cfm?cvename=CVE-2007-0544">CVE-2007-0544</a>).</li>
<li>Wordpress has had a bad start to 2007, with numerous vulnerabilities that significantly increased its ranking.  March 2007 was particularly bad, with 7 new vulnerabilities reported.</li>
<li>Bulletin board/forum software is by far the most common type of application in the top 20.  A couple forum apps that have very <strong>low</strong> numbers of vulnerability reports: <a href="http://getvanilla.com/">Vanilla</a> and <a href="http://fudforum.org/">FUDForum</a>.</li>
</ul>

<p>I do intend to keep this data up-to-date if people find it interesting, so let me know if you&#8217;d like me to do so, or if you&#8217;d like to see other types of analysis.</p>

<p>[tags]php, security, application security, vulnerabilities, nist, nvd, statistics[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Poop poop poop!!!"
url_title: poop_poop_poop
permalink: poop_poop_poop.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-04-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2315
---
<p>So about a month and a half ago I turned on the ancient water softener in our basement, because we had tons of calcium deposits on our dishes.  I believe I had run it for a while when we first moved in, but gave after a bit because I thought it wasn&#8217;t worth the trouble of handling the salt and such.<br /><br />This morning, a guy from the water dept came to my door.  He was checking to see if the meter was messed up, or if we had a leak.<br /><br />Uh-oh.<br /><br />I turned off the softener.  The meter stopped spinning.  That was &#8220;the leak.&#8221;  I guess it just never shut itself off, so it was constantly running water through itself.  I actually noticed it seemed to run a lot, but I&#8217;m a total novice with this shit, and assumed it was okay.<br /><br />So I called the utility office, because I was concerned about what the bill might be.  For good reason.<br /><br />Apparently, in the month of march, we had used 115,000 gallons of water.<br /><br />That will be <strong>$683</strong>, please.<br /><br />And of course, since I didn&#8217;t turn it off until the middle of march, I&#8217;d expect another half that much to get tacked on for April.  That should kick us up over $1000.<br /><br />Coulda bought a new softener for that, and done other improvements we need.<br /><br />They&#8217;ll spread it over 6 months, which is nice.  I <em>could</em> pay it all now, but it wouldn&#8217;t be easy.<br /><br />I know, I know, it&#8217;s just money, but&#8230; dammit.  I was hoping we were getting ahead.  And now something stupid I did cost us a whole chunk of change.<br /><br /><em>frown</em></p>

Something like that happened to us in the late 80&#8217;s or early 90&#8217;s, but only cost us about $125.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "What are your chances of getting audited by the IRS?"
url_title: what_are_your_chances_of_getting_audited_by_the_irs
permalink: what_are_your_chances_of_getting_audited_by_the_irs.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-04-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2313
---
<p>From <a href="http://www.wisebread.com/">WiseBread</a>: <a href="http://www.wisebread.com/what-are-your-chances-of-getting-audited-by-the-irs-your-guess-is-probably-wrong">What are your chances of getting audited by the IRS? Your guess is probably wrong</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>According to <a href="http://video.msn.com/v/us/fv/money/fv.htm??g=0a730c1b-b4ab-4f5e-bdeb-141b9174a6c8&amp;t=&amp;f=15/64yourrealtaxrate40&amp;p=&amp;fg=">this Kiplinger&#8217;s tax tip video</a>, only 1 in 150 personal tax returns get audited. Realistically speaking, your odds of getting audited are probably even lower than that. In fact, it&#8217;s virtually zero.<br /><br />The Kiplinger editor calls the taxpayer&#8217;s fear of audits &#8216;very stupid.&#8217; He explains that you will not get audited as long as you don&#8217;t claim any insane tax deductions. Therefore, everyone should be aggressive and take advantage of all the available deductions within reason.<br /><br /><b>Our irrational fear of audits</b><br /><br />One recent survey conducted by a CPA at Louisiana State University shows that the average taxpayers believe 1 in 7 people gets audited by the IRS. Over 80% of the people surveyed had unrealistically high expectations of getting audited.<br /><br />When the survey takes into consideration the likely income bracket of the participants, the results get even more ridiculous:<br /></blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Screw Myspace, I&#8217;m down with Virb"
url_title: screw_myspace_im_down_with_virb
permalink: screw_myspace_im_down_with_virb.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- Music
date: 2007-04-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2310
---
<p>Since last post was a good Myspace trashing, I thought I&#8217;d mention a social network site I&#8217;ve been digging: <a href="http://virb.com">Virb</a>. Here&#8217;s why I like it:</p>

<ul>

    <li>It&#8217;s pretty and clean. You&#8217;re not overwhelmed with information. It&#8217;s *pleasant* to look at Virb.</li>

    <li>It&#8217;s easy to make basic changes to your profile, and you have full CSS control if you want or need it. I haven&#8217;t come across a site that handled &#8220;themeing&#8221; as well as Virb.</li>

    <li>Virb clearly thought about how to organize your stuff, and it does a good job of letting you do so in an easy and logical manner</li>

    <li>It&#8217;s easy to add new modules to your profile that can include more advanced html and embedded media. Where your media can come from is whitelisted, which means <strong>better security</strong>; there&#8217;s much less chance of having your profile hijacked just by viewing someone else&#8217;s page</li>
    <li>Embedding Flickr photos is SO easy. Since I use Flickr for everything, it&#8217;s totally awesome.</li>

    <li>If you&#8217;re into music, Virb does a good job of letting you check out tunes, add bands, keep track of their shows, and the like *without* all the shittiness of Myspace</li>

    <li>It&#8217;s not flooded with ads and doesn&#8217;t make you log-in and &#8216;start over&#8217; unnecessarily</li>

</ul>

<p>So what don&#8217;t I like about Virb so much?</p>

<ul>
    <li>I really really wish I could import data into my profile via RSS. I already have 3 blogs (counting my work blog) &#8212; I have no interest in maintaining another. If I could just have my blog entries imported into my Virb blog, it&#8217;d be perfect. (<strong>update:</strong> Virb has blog importing via RSS <a href="http://virb.com/is/new_features">listed as &#8220;Coming Soon&#8221;</a>)</li>

    <li>Worse, no RSS feeds for my Virb blog! This is a big missing piece, and I&#8217;m really surprised they don&#8217;t have this yet. This bad boy should be filled with subscribable (is that a word?) data so you can track your friends, your bands&#8217; shows, and the like.</li>
</ul>

<p>So consider this an invitation:</p>

<ul>

    <li><a href="http://virb.com/funkatron">My personal Virb profile</a></li>

    <li><a href="http://virb.com/cultofjester">Cult of Jester&#8217;s Virb profile</a></li>

</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "MySpace Sucks as a Social Tool"
url_title: myspace_sucks_as_a_social_tool
permalink: myspace_sucks_as_a_social_tool.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-04-11
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2309
---
<p>Marcys Whitney thinks <a href="http://www.marcuswhitney.com/2007/04/10/myspace-sucks-as-a-social-tool/">MySpace Sucks as a Social Tool</a>:<br /></p>

<blockquote>So, I think MySpace sucks.  It sucks because it has absolutely no technically social qualities outside of itself aside from RSS and email, both of which are very limited and poorly implemented.  Wordpress on the other hand is an example of the Internet as an operation system environment.  Do you think it sucks?  If so why, if not… I don’t think I care.<br /><br />It is a great user generated content web destination however.   So kudos to them for at least succeeding there</blockquote>

<p><br /><br />It&#8217;s very insular, indeed, which is why I&#8217;ve pretty much given up on it.  Plus the extremely obvious attempts to pump up ad view stats with crap like:<br /><br />- Letting me view some of a person&#8217;s profile while not logged-in<br />- Forcing me to log-in when I want to view, say, pictures<br />- Not returning me to where I was before I logged in, but forcing me to AGAIN navigate back to the person&#8217;s profile.<br /><br />Beyond lame.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jlee43/244136188/"><img src="http://farm1.static.flickr.com/80/244136188_48881dce29_m.jpg" align="right" alt="I hate my job" /></a>Saw <a href="http://www.phpdeveloper.org/news/7586">this</a> on the excellent <a href="http://www.phpdeveloper.org">PHPDeveloper.org</a>:</p>

<blockquote><strong>Company</strong> Warner Bros. Records
<strong>Location</strong> Burbank, CA
<strong>Title</strong> PHP Developer
<strong>Summary </strong>
Warner Brothers Records is looking for a freelance PHP developer skilled in Drupal themeing and programming. To be considered you must be able to work at our office, <strong><em>provide your own computer</em></strong> and be very comfortable developing using SVN.

You&#8217;ll be in New Media, a very relaxed work environment, with cool and quirky people. We prize Mac users but welcome all. This is a great chance to work with bands like Arctic Monkeys, White Stripes, Damien Rice, Muse and more.

To apply please send an e-mail with the following to nmtech@warnerbrosrecords.com:

<ul>
<li>PHP Developer and your full name in the Subject line.</li>
<li>3 Links to actual code you have written and or sites worked on what you worked on.</li>
<li>Tell us a little about yourself and send a link to your blog you have one.</li>
</ul></blockquote>

<p>Lemme get this straight: I have to work at your office, but <em>provide my own computer???</em>  This reads like a really slimy way of getting people to work cheap in exchange for <em>maybe</em> doing a web site for some half-wit modern &#8220;rock&#8221; band.  I&#8217;ll keep my iMac at home and make more money doing contracting work, but thanks all the same, WB.</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHPSecInfo v0.2.1 now available"
url_title: phpsecinfo_v021_now_available
permalink: phpsecinfo_v021_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-04-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2306
---
<p><a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PhpSecInfo</a> v0.2.1 is now available.  It&#8217;s primarily a bugfix release, but a fairly significant one.  From the <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/CHANGELOG">CHANGELOG</a>:</p>

<ul>
<li>uid and gid tests now correctly test the user and group that PHP is executing as (requires that <code>exec()</code> or <a href="http://us.php.net/posix">posix functions</a> are enabled)</li>
<li>Changed upload_max_filesize and post_max_size return &#8220;OK&#8221; if current value is equal to recommended value</li>
<li>fixed nonstandard naming with a couple locally used constants</li>
<li>fixed problem with XHTML validity in cases of not run tests (thanks Thomas Corbiere)</li>
</ul>

<p>Get your security auditing on at <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">phpsecinfo.com</a>.</p>

<p>[tags]phpsecinfo, uid, gid, php, security[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Determining if a function is *really* available in PHP"
url_title: determining_if_a_function_is_really_available_in_php
permalink: determining_if_a_function_is_really_available_in_php.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- Development
- PHP
date: 2007-03-29
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2302
---
<p>After pounding for a few hours, I think I finally got the UID and GID tests for <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PHPSecInfo</a> in an acceptable state.  Two things have made this hard:</p>

<ol>
<li>You can really only do this with an exec() call to the &#8220;id&#8221; UNIX command, or the posix_* functions, either of which are frequently disabled</li>
<li>There basically is not a foolproof way to programatically tell if a function is available or not in PHP</li>
</ol>

<h1>2 is the real rub, and quite annoying.  <code>is_callable()</code> will return TRUE even if a function has been disabled in php.ini with <code>disabled_functions</code> (which, in my mind, is contrary to what &#8220;is_callable&#8221; implies).  <code>function_exists()</code> will return FALSE if the function is disabled in php.ini, but will return TRUE if the function is being blocked by <code>safe_mode</code>.</h1>

<p>For now, the tests try <code>exec('id')</code> first, seeing if it passes <code>function_exists()</code> <i>and</i> <code>safe_mode</code> is disabled.  If it fails those, the <code>posix_*</code> functions are checked against <code>function_exists</code> (they aren&#8217;t affected by <code>safe_mode</code>.  If those fail as well, the test will be skipped.</p>

<p>[tags]phpsecinfo, uid, gid, posix, exec, safe_mode, disabled_functions, function_exists, is_callable[/tags]</p>




<!-- end of post -->
