---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The Power (and Peril) of Praising Your Kids&#8212;New York Magazine"
url_title: the_power_and_peril_of_praising_your_kids_new_york_magazine
permalink: the_power_and_peril_of_praising_your_kids_new_york_magazine.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-03-24
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2295
---
<p>I was really, really interested in <a href="http://nymag.com/news/features/27840/">this article from New York Magazine</a> about how different forms of &#8220;praise&#8221; children receive can dramatically effect how well they are able to perform in school.<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Scholars from Reed College and Stanford reviewed over 150 praise studies. Their meta-analysis determined that praised students become risk-averse and lack perceived autonomy. The scholars found consistent correlations between a liberal use of praise and students’ “shorter task persistence, more eye-checking with the teacher, and inflected speech such that answers have the intonation of questions.”<br /><br />Dweck’s research on overpraised kids strongly suggests that image maintenance becomes their primary concern—they are more competitive and more interested in tearing others down. A raft of very alarming studies illustrate this.<br /><br />In one, students are given two puzzle tests. Between the first and the second, they are offered a choice between learning a new puzzle strategy for the second test or finding out how they did compared with other students on the first test: They have only enough time to do one or the other. Students praised for intelligence choose to find out their class rank, rather than use the time to prepare.<br /><br />In another, students get a do-it-yourself report card and are told these forms will be mailed to students at another school—they’ll never meet these students and don’t know their names. Of the kids praised for their intelligence, 40 percent lie, inflating their scores. Of the kids praised for effort, few lie.<br /><br />When students transition into junior high, some who’d done well in elementary school inevitably struggle in the larger and more demanding environment. Those who equated their earlier success with their innate ability surmise they’ve been dumb all along. Their grades never recover because the likely key to their recovery—increasing effort—they view as just further proof of their failure. In interviews many confess they would “seriously consider cheating.”</blockquote>

<p><br /><br />This is scarily consistent with my own experience as a kid who was constantly told I was smart and special throughout elementary school.  Throughout this period, I basically got by without having to work very hard.  This changed in junior high, and my grades took a nosedive.  To this day I have serious trouble doing things that don&#8217;t give me some kind of &#8220;reward&#8221; quickly, and this is very frustrating to me.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2295" data-url-title="the_power_and_peril_of_praising_your_kids_new_york_magazine">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1781" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Jenna</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://my.cyberspacebabes.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/24/2007 02:44:23 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><h2>I had a similar experience: coasting by on infant laurels in elementary school, not because I could do the work (I sure as hell didn&#8217;t) but because I could answer all the questions.  The &#8220;Gifted &amp; Talented&#8221; program only reinforced the idea that I was intellectually superior to my classmates.  Until junior high, of course. My grades dropped, I felt incredibly stupid, and frustrated with the constant struggle to prove myself.  To this day I want that reward, or praise, or instant recognition.  As for competitiveness, heh.  I still need to crush opposition so I can say, &#8220;I have a High IQ and I am Smarter Than You.  Worship me, dammit.&#8221;  That only leads me to avoiding people that <em>are</em> smarter or more accomplished than me.  Suckage.</h2>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>

<p><a href="http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/nist-nvd-data-2006.002.png"><img src="http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/nist-nvd-data-2006.002.png" border="0" height="600" width="800" alt="NIST NVD Data 2006.002.png" align="" /></a></p>

<p><em>Click for the image if it&#8217;s cut off</em></p>

<p>PHP Applications <strong>by themselves</strong> account for over 40% of all NIST NVD entries in 2006.</p>

<p>We need more than new frameworks. <em>We need new paradigms for PHP development.</em></p>

<p>[tags]php security, php, infosec, phpsecinfo, nist nvd[/tags]</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The Zend Framework and It&#8217;s Influence on Secure PHP Development"
url_title: the_zend_framework_and_its_influence_on_secure_php_development
permalink: the_zend_framework_and_its_influence_on_secure_php_development.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-03-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2288
---
<p>I posted this rather lengthy argument in the <a href="http://www.nabble.com/Zend-Core-f16191.html">Zend fw-core mailing list</a> after I learned that the <code>Zend_Filter_Input</code> component had been dropped from the Zend Framework.  I have used this component extensively in various projects, and had written up a contribution to the <a href="http://devzone.zend.com/">Zend DevZone</a> that described using a bootstrap script to block direct access by your developers to the superglobal user input arrays ($_GET, $_POST, $_COOKIE, etc).</p>

<p>I want to be clear that I think the ZFW project leads have done a very good job of guiding the development of the framework.  I think they&#8217;re very smart, capable folks who have done a ton of good, hard work.  I just disagree strongly with what&#8217;s happened to the input filtering components, and feel that it should be addressed before the 1.0 release.</p>

<p>Here&#8217;s my post:</p>

<blockquote><p>Let me start off with some context.  If we do a search for &#8216;php&#8217; in the 2006 records of the <a href="http://nvd.nist.gov/">NIST NVD</a>, over <em>40%</em> of the total number of vulnerabilities are returned.  Removing language level issues, which would account for a small number of these, we&#8217;re left with an enormous number of PHP application vulnerabilities &#8212; well over 1/3 of all the 2006 entries in the NVD, for sure.</p>

<p>I believe those numbers say a lot about the following things:
1. How popular PHP is
2. How much web applications are a target
3. How many PHP devs are incapable of writing secure applications</p>

<p>I don&#8217;t necessarily fault PHP as a language for this, as I think any language of similar ease and popularity would suffer many of the same problems.  And as more and more of our business and social activity is conducted online, web applications are inevitably going to increasingly be targeted.</p>

<p>But we can do a <em>lot</em> about #3, in two major areas: <strong>education</strong>, and <strong>empowerment</strong>.</p>

<p>Education is fairly easy to understand, I think: books, training courses, articles, tutorials, etc.  In a sense, the ZFW project has a significant opportunity to educate PHP developers by serving as an example to the community.  Zend&#8217;s profile in the community gives it an opportunity to raise the bar, and change expectations about what effective, secure web app development entails.</p>

<p>Empowering developers, in my mind, means making it easier to do the right thing.  Our toolsets &#8212; editors, debuggers, frameworks, etc &#8212; should make it <em>easier</em> to write secure applications.  The default action should be the secure action.  It shouldn&#8217;t be <em>impossible</em> to do potentially dangerous stuff, but it should require clear intent on the part of the developer.</p>

<p>This is where I feel the Zend Framework has <strong>regressed</strong> as of version 0.8.  Out of the box, it is <strong>more difficult</strong> to write secure applications with ZFW as of 0.8.0 than it was in 0.7.0.</p>

<p>For example, let&#8217;s look at stripping tags from user input.  In 0.7:</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
require "Zend/Filter.php";
$searchtxt = Zend_Filter::noTags($searchtxt);
</pre>

<p>In 0.8:</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
require "Zend/Filter/StripTags.php";
$noTags    = new Zend_Filter_StripTags();
$searchtxt = $noTags->filter($searchtxt);
</pre>

<p>Only one extra line, but when you&#8217;re having to instantiate a new filter every time you want different functionality, it adds up.  And if you&#8217;re not using class autoloading, you have to do a require statement for every filter class, whereas in 0.7 you only needed to do a single require.</p>

<p>In some ways, the new Zend_Filter is a win, especially in terms of expandability, but it lacks the proper hooks for making filtering and validation as speedy and easy as it was before.  Make no mistake: verbosity <em>matters</em>.  I am not alone in preferring an option that makes me type less.</p>

<p>More disturbing, though, is the total removal of the <strong>Zend_Filter_Input</strong> component from the ZFW.  ZFI was a very effective tool for limiting access to user input arrays like $_POST and $_COOKIE, wrapping them in an object and forcing the developer to use object methods to access the data.</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
require "Zend/Filter/Input.php";
$f_POST = new Zend_Filter_Input($_POST);
$searchtext = $f_POST->noTags('searchtxt');
$id = $f_POST->getInt('id');

// you can only get the raw input with the getRaw method
$unfiltered_input = $f_POST->getRaw('xssWaitingToHappen');
</pre>

<p>It wasn&#8217;t perfect &#8212; as of 0.7 it lacked iterative access and didn&#8217;t work well with multidimensional arrays &#8212; but it established a strong new paradigm for PHP development that was a long time in coming.  The vast majority of vulnerabilities in PHP apps come from mishandling user input, and Zend_Filter_Input made it significantly <strong>easier to do the right thing</strong>, and significantly <strong>harder to do the wrong thing</strong>.  This was a <em>major</em> jewel for the Zend Framework, something no other high-profile PHP framework was offering (AFAIK).  And it evidently had been considered a fundamental component, having been present in the core since the initial public release (0.1.2).  Now, it&#8217;s gone, with no comparable functionality in place, and no concrete plans to restore it.</p>

<p>Zend has a significant opportunity to influence how PHP development is done with the ZFW 1.0 release.  The Zend Framework will be, for better or worse, considered an example as to how PHP development <em>should</em> be done.  It&#8217;s disappointing, then, to see the framework move backwards in terms of easing secure development while it speeds towards 1.0.  This opportunity will not come again.  I hope these decisions are reconsidered, and the feature freeze is delayed so that previously-existing functionality can be restored.</p></blockquote>

<p>[tags]zend framework, php, security, infosec, webdev, zfw, input filtering[/tags]</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2288" data-url-title="the_zend_framework_and_its_influence_on_secure_php_development">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1773" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Cristian Bichis</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://www.zftutorials.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/15/2007 02:08:07 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>Hello,</p>

<p>I was concerned myself a lot about all those things: i made a tutorials site which is supposed to be already used by lot of people according to emails i am receiving&#8230;</p>

<p>Also, started a dedicated Zend Framework forum (www.zfforums.com), aso&#8230; More interesting things coming soon&#8230;</p>

<p>Also, as stated into my forum post from here:
http://www.zfforums.com/zend-framework-general-discussions-1/concepts-ideas-planning-39/zend-framework-performance-27.html</p>

<p>IMHO PHP is now surviving only due to large scale of existing developers rather than things as security, rapid development, aso&#8230; I worked with a lot of other platforms (not necessary web oriented) so i think i know what i am talking bout&#8230; So, without a major enhancement - as ZF can be i am said to say but we going to be repeated same mistakes for each newbie developer, same problems unsolved by language itself by lot of time&#8230;</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Using Beagle with web sites?"
url_title: using_beagle_with_web_sites
permalink: using_beagle_with_web_sites.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-03-14
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2287
---
<p>So here&#8217;s a thought about a different approach to searching a content-thick web site, or relating a variety of content types to one another, based on my messing around more with <a href="http://code.google.com/p/macfuse/">MacFUSE</a>:</p>

<p>What about using something like <a href="http://beagle-project.org">Beagle</a>, <a href="http://fuse.sourceforge.net/">FUSE</a> and <a href="http://rlove.org/log/2006070601">BeagleFS</a> to create a search engine of static content and related data?  This might be a little heavy because you&#8217;d basically have to create a new filesystem for each different query, but it would only get that hit the first time it&#8217;s created.  If that&#8217;s too much, though, maybe a PHP/Python/Ruby library to act as a query client against a Beagle database would be adequate.</p>

<p>At <a href="http://www.cerias.purdue.edu">CERIAS</a> we have a ton of static content (lots of PDFs, a huge FTP site full of source code and message archives and OS mirrors, etc.).  Something like this could really help get a handle on this, both in relating disparate types of data to one another, and in finding the right content in this mass of files.</p>

<p>Does this make sense?</p>

<p>[tags]beagle, beaglefs, FUSE, metadata, searching, search engine, webdev[/tags]</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Now what am I supposed to do with this?"
url_title: now_what_am_i_supposed_to_do_with_this
permalink: now_what_am_i_supposed_to_do_with_this.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-03-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2285
---
<p>This dialog popped up on login after I had to do a hard reset on my Powerbook. I went with &#8220;No,&#8221; FYI.<br /><br /></p>

<p><a href="http://www.cinematical.com/2007/03/12/anti-michael-moore-doc-manufacturing-dissent-premieres-at-sx/">Anti-Michael Moore Doc, &#8216;Manufacturing Dissent,&#8217; Premieres At SXSW - Cinematical</a>: &#8220;One of the film&#8217;s discoveries is that all of the evasiveness in Roger & Me was a crock &#8212; apparently Moore did talk with Roger Smith, but the footage was cut. All of this came about when the duo realized that their attempts at an interview needed to be taken from a different angle. They began to investigate his filmmaking process, which of course, brought up the questions of his practices. I think Melnyk really describes the man best: &#8216;We&#8217;re a bit disappointed and disillusioned with Michael, but we are still very grateful to him for putting documentaries out there in a major way.&#8217;&#8221;</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Zend_Environment&#8217;s Security Module In Action"
url_title: zend_environments_security_module_in_action
permalink: zend_environments_security_module_in_action.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2007-03-01
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2275
---
<p>I just checked in a bunch of bug fixes that get the security module of Zend_Environment working properly.</p>

<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/picture-1.png" rel="lightbox" title="Zend_Environment's Security Module"><img src="http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/picture-1.thumbnail.png" width="350" height="262" alt="Zend_Environment's Security Module" class="imageframe" style="margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;" /></a></p>

<p>If you want to try it yourself, you&#8217;ll need to:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://framework.zend.com/wiki/display/ZFDEV/Subversion+Standards">Check out the latest Zend Framework from SVN</a></li>
 <li>Add the <code>library</code> <em>and</em> <code>incubator/library</code> directories from the SVN checkout to your include path</li>
 <li>Do some code-foo like this:
<pre class="prettyprint">require 'Zend.php';
function __autoload($class) {
    Zend::loadClass($class);
}

$sec = new Zend_Environment_Module_Security('sec');
$ze = new Zend_Environment(array($sec));
echo $ze->toHtml();</pre>
</li>
</ul>

<p>There&#8217;s a lot more you can do with the Zend_Environment package that&#8217;s all due to Simon Mundy&#8217;s kickass work (more modules, you can iterate over results, query for settings, etc).  I&#8217;ll try to cover some other usage scenarios in upcoming posts.</p>

<p>[tags]php security, php, zend framework, zend_environment[/tags]</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHPSecInfo v0.2 now available"
url_title: phpsecinfo_v02_now_available
permalink: phpsecinfo_v02_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2007-02-26
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2273
---
<div align="center">
<a href="http://phpsec.org/images/psi_ss1.png"><img src="http://phpsec.org/images/th_psi_ss1.png" alt="PHPSecInfo Screenshot" /></a> <a href="http://phpsec.org/images/psi_ss2.png"><img src="http://phpsec.org/images/th_psi_ss2.png" alt="PHPSecInfo Screenshot" /></a>
</div>

<p>The newest version of PHPSecInfo, version 0.2, is now available.  Here are the major changes:</p>

<ul>
 <li>Added link to &#8220;more info&#8221; in output.  These lead to pages on the phpsec.org site giving more details on the test and what to do if you have a problem</li>
 <li>Modified CSS to improve readability and avoid license issue with PHP (the old CSS was derived from the output of <code>phpinfo()</code>)</li>
 <li>New test: <code>PhpSecInfo_Test_Session_Save_Path</code></li>
 <li>Added display of &#8220;current&#8221; and &#8220;recommended&#8221; settings in test result output</li>
 <li>Various minor changes and bug fixes; <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/CHANGELOG">see the CHANGELOG</a> for details</li>
</ul>

<h3>-<strong><a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/phpsecinfo.zip">Download now</a></strong></h3>

<h3>-<strong><a href="http://lists.phpsec.org/mailman/listinfo/phpsecinfo">Join the mailing list</a></strong></h3>

<p>[tags]php, phpsecinfo, infosec, audit, tool, security[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Zend_Environment_Security and its relation to PhpSecInfo"
url_title: zend_environment_security_and_its_relation_to_phpsecinfo
permalink: zend_environment_security_and_its_relation_to_phpsecinfo.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- My Projects
- Development
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2007-02-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2271
---
<p>I just posted this to the <a href="http://lists.phpsec.org/mailman/listinfo/phpsecinfo">phpsecinfo mailing list</a>:</p>

<blockquote>Folks who download today&#8217;s <a href="http://framework.zend.com/">Zend Framework</a> 0.8 release will notice the a new library in the &#8220;incubator&#8221; section: <a href="http://www.peptolab.com/">Simon Mundy</a>&#8217;s <a href="http://framework.zend.com/apidoc/incubator/Zend_Environment/Zend_Environment.html">Zend_Environment</a>.  People who look closer will notice that there is a &#8220;security&#8221; module for Zend_Environment, and a test framework called <a href="http://framework.zend.com/apidoc/incubator/Zend_Environment/Zend_Environment_Security_Test.html">Zend_Environment_Security_Test</a> that looks a lot like <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PhpSecInfo</a>.

Zend_Environment_Security is basically a port of the tests I&#8217;ve written for PhpSecInfo to work with Simon&#8217;s Zend_Environment module.  It does *not* replace PhpSecInfo, but rather provide a similar testing capability built into the ZFW core.  PhpSecInfo could be described as the &#8220;parent&#8221; project, with Zend_Environment_Security being based on the work I do in PSI.  PSI is *definitely* the core, and will for the foreseeable future take priority over any &#8220;sibling&#8221; projects.

Why did I only refer to my work on PSI, and not the other very helpful folks who have contributed?  Because I cannot convert any contributed code from PSI unless the contributors have signed the <a href="http://framework.zend.com/wiki/display/ZFPROP/Contributor+License+Agreement">ZFW Contributor License Agreement</a>.  For this reason, a few tests that are present in PhpSecInfo don&#8217;t have equivalents in Zend_Environment_Security.

If you have contributed tests to PhpSecInfo, or plan on doing so, I&#8217;d like you to give serious consideration to signing the Zend CLA.  It won&#8217;t put any additional burden on you, as I&#8217;ll take care of porting contributed tests to the Zend_Environment_Security model.

- <a href="http://framework.zend.com/wiki/display/ZFPROP/Contributor+License+Agreement">Zend Contributor License Agreement</a>

Note that I will *not* require PhpSecInfo contributors to sign the Zend CLA.  If you choose not to do so, I will be happy to use your work in PhpSecInfo.

I hope this clears up any confusion.  If you have questions, please let me know.</blockquote>

<p>[tags]phpsecinfo, zend, zfw, zend framework, security[/tags]</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain - A LAME-based mp3 Encoder and CD Ripper"
url_title: lamebrain_a_lame_based_mp3_encoder_and_cd_ripper
permalink: lamebrain_a_lame_based_mp3_encoder_and_cd_ripper.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2007-02-20
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2269
---
<p><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/lamebrain-icon.png' alt='LameBrain icon' align="right" /></p>

<p>It&#8217;s been (ugh) nearly 4 years since LameBrain was updated.  It was an enjoyable project, but I simply lost interest: I didn&#8217;t use the program myself, moving to encoding most of my music with the iTunes AAC encoder.  I also had pushed the app feature wise as far as I ever intended.</p>

<p>Still, people continue to search for and download LameBrain every day from this site.  It evidently scratches an itch for some people, and that&#8217;s a source of pride for me.  So I&#8217;d hate to just sit on the program and not give others an opportunity to run with it.  I think there are some valuable bits in the horribly structured code I wrote back then, and maybe someone with more drive than me will build on what&#8217;s here.</p>

<p>Thanks to everyone who has used LameBrain, and especially to the folks who donated money for its development.  It&#8217;s been a lot of fun.</p>

<p><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/lamebrain/LameBrain_Source_Code.zip">Get LameBrain source code</a></p>

<p>[tags]lamebrain, mp3, source code, realbasic, lame, OS X, ripper, encoder[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spaz - An Open-Source Twitter Client for Mac OS X, Windows and Linux"
url_title: spaz
permalink: spaz.html
tags: "twitter, client, desktop, windows, os x, mac, linux, multiuser, multiple users, apollo, adobe AIR, ajax, spry, jquery"
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Spaz
date: 2007-02-20
summary: Spaz is a Twitter client for users who value free, <em>open-source</em> software, attractive <em>design</em>, and <em>customizability</em>
old_entry_id: 2265
---
<a name="features"></a><h2>Features</h2>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Cross-platform</strong>: available on all AIR-compatible platforms: Windows, OS X, and Linux</li>
	<li><strong>Open source</strong> software using a New BSD-style license (source available at <a href="http://code.google.com/p/spaz" target="_blank">Spaz Google Code project site</a>)</li>
	<li>Written in pure Javascript, XHTML and CSS. Utilizes the powerful <strong><a href="http://jquery.com" title="jQuery">jQuery</a></strong> Javascript framework</li>
	<li>Built-in global <strong>search</strong> powered by <a href="http://search.twitter.com/">Summize</a></strong></li>
	<li><strong>Short URL creation</strong> tool with support for multiple services (is.gd, bit.ly, snurl.com, and more)</li>
	<li>In-line <strong>short URL decoding</strong></li>
	<li><strong>No ads</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Markdown</strong> syntax support
	<li><strong>Multiple themes</strong> and support for <strong>user-created themes</strong></li>
	<li><strong>User-defined CSS</strong> overrides</li>
	<li><strong>Event sounds</strong> using the <a href="http://www.adiumxtras.com/index.php?a=xtras&amp;xtra_id=602">Tokyo Train Station</a> soundset by Dominik Dimaano</li>
	<li><strong>Directory listings</strong> of users you&#8217;re following, and your followers.</li>
	<li><strong>Debugging and development tools</strong> and debug logging</li>
</ul>

<a name="faq"></a><h2>FAQ &amp; Help</h2>

<ul>
	<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/spaziki/" title="Spaziki!">Spaziki: The Spaz Wiki and FAQ</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://groups.google.com/group/spaz-users" title="Spaz Users |
	  Google Groups">Join the Spaz Users Group</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://code.google.com/p/spaz/issues/list" title="spaz - Google Code">File a bug or suggestion</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://twitter.com/spaz" title="Twitter / spaz">Follow Spaz on Twitter</a></li>
</ul>

<a name="join-the-team"></a><h2>Join the Team</h2>

<p>Spaz.AIR is written entirely in XHTML and Javascript.  It uses the <a href="http://labs.adobe.com/technologies/spry/">Spry</a> and <a href="http://jquery.com/">jQuery</a> frameworks.</p>

<p>Spaz is <strong>open-source</strong> and licensed under <a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/LICENSE.txt" target="_blank" title="Spaz license">a New BSD-style license</a>.</p>

<h3 id="subversion_repository">Subversion Repository</h3>

<p>You can access the SVN repo at <a href="http://code.google.com/p/spaz">Spaz&#8217;s Google Code site</a>.</p>

<p>The source code of Spaz.AIR is available in the <code>.air</code> file &#8212; you should be able to open it with any &#8220;unzip&#8221; tool.</p>



<a name="download"></a><h2>Download</h2>


<h3 id="automated_8220one_step8221_install">Automated &#8220;One-step&#8221; Install</h3>

<div id="flashcontent" style="width:215px; height:180px;">
	<strong>Please upgrade your Flash Player</strong>
	This is the content that would be shown if the user does not have Flash Player 9.0.115 or higher installed.
</div>

<script type="text/javascript">
	// <![CDATA[

	// version 9.0.115 or greater is required for launching AIR apps.
	var so = new SWFObject("http://funkatron.com/assets/AIRInstallBadge.swf", "Badge", "215", "180", "9.0.115", "#222222");
	so.useExpressInstall('http://funkatron.com/assets/expressinstall.swf');

	// these parameters are required for badge install:
	so.addVariable("airversion", "1.0"); // version of AIR runtime required
	so.addVariable("appname", "Spaz"); // application name to display to the user
	so.addVariable("appurl", "http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/SpazAIR.air"); // absolute URL (beginning with http or https) of the application ".air" file

	// these parameters are required to support launching apps from the badge (but optional for install):
	//so.addVariable("appid", "Spaz.AIR"); // the qualified application ID (ex. com.gskinner.air.MyApplication)
	//so.addVariable("pubid", ""); // publisher id

	// this parameter is required in addition to the above to support upgrading from the badge:
	//so.addVariable("appversion", "0.3.7"); // AIR application version

	// these parameters are optional:
	so.addVariable("imageurl", "http://funkatron.com/assets/spaz-screenshot-205x170.png"); // URL for an image (JPG, PNG, GIF) or SWF to display in the badge (205px wide, 170px high)
	so.addVariable("appinstallarg", "installed from web"); // passed to the application when it is installed from the badge
	so.addVariable("applauncharg", "launched from web"); // passed to the application when it is launched from the badge
	//so.addVariable("helpurl", "help.html"); // optional url to a page containing additional help, displayed in the badge's help screen
	so.addVariable("hidehelp", "false"); // hides the help icon if "true"
	so.addVariable("skiptransition", "false"); // skips the initial transition if "true"
	so.addVariable("titlecolor", "#00AAFF"); // changes the color of titles
	so.addVariable("buttonlabelcolor", "#00AAFF"); // changes the color of the button label
	so.addVariable("appnamecolor", "#00AAFF"); // changes the color of the application name if the image is not specified or loaded

	// these parameters allow you to override the default text in the badge:
	// supported strings: str_error, str_err_params, str_err_airunavailable, str_err_airswf, str_loading, str_install, str_launch, str_upgrade, str_close, str_launching, str_launchingtext, str_installing, str_installingtext, str_tryagain, str_beta3, str_beta3text, str_help, str_helptext
	so.addVariable("str_err_airswf", "<u>Running locally?</u><br/><br/>The AIR proxy swf won't load properly when this demo is run from the local file system."); // overrides the error text when the AIR proxy swf fails to load

	so.write("flashcontent");

	// ]]>
</script>

<h3 id="manual_install">Manual Install</h3>

<p>Note: Spaz.AIR <strong>requires</strong> that the Adobe Integrated Runtime be installed on your system.</p>

<ol>
<li><a href="http://get.adobe.com/air">Download and install AIR</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/getspaz">Download Spaz</a></li>
</ol>

<h3 id="extras">Extras</h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/whatsnew.html">View the changelog</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/LICENSE.txt" target="_blank" title="Spaz license">View the license</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/AIR/spaz-css-dev.zip">Get the theme development template</a>(this is a bit out of date)</li>
</ul>

<h3 id="old_versions">Old Versions</h3>

<p>Previous versions of Spaz were written in <a href="http://realbasic.com">RealBasic</a>, and compiled for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux.  The new AIR-based Spaz is, in the creator&#8217;s opinion, a far superior program, but you can still download the old versions and source code if you like:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/RB/Spaz-OSX-Universal.zip">Spaz-RB for OS X</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/RB/Spaz-Windows.zip">Spaz-RB for Windows</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/RB/Spaz-Linux.zip">Spaz-RB for Linux</a></li>
<li><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/spaz/RB/Spaz-Source.zip">Spaz-RB source code</a></li>
</ul>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>You&#8217;ll get the best support for problems on the Spaz users group:</p>

<p>http://groups.google.com/group/spaz-users</p>

<p>However, the error is pretty well described in the message. Your account is probably sending more than 70 requests per hour. Make sure you do not run <em>any</em> other Twitter API programs at the same time, and you may lower your refresh rate in Spaz&#8217;s preferences. The minimum is every 3 minutes, which would be 60 requests per hour.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain Source Code Release"
url_title: lamebrain_source_code_release
permalink: lamebrain_source_code_release.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- Development
- OS X
date: 2007-02-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2263
---
<p><a href='http://funkatron.com/apps/lamebrain/LameBrain_Source_Code.zip' rel='attachment wp-att-611' title='LameBrain Source Code'><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/lamebrain-icon.png' alt='LameBrain icon' align="right" /></a>I&#8217;ve uploaded <a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/lamebrain/LameBrain_Source_Code.zip">the source code for LameBrain</a>, my LAME-based mp3 encoder for OS X.</p>

<p>It&#8217;s been (ugh) nearly 4 years since LameBrain was updated.  It was an enjoyable project, but I simply lost interest: I didn&#8217;t use the program myself, moving to encoding most of my music with the iTunes AAC encoder.  I also had pushed the app feature wise as far as I ever intended.</p>

<p>Still, people continue to search for and download LameBrain every day from this site.  It evidently scratches an itch for some people, and that&#8217;s a source of pride for me.  So I&#8217;d hate to just sit on the program and not give others an opportunity to run with it.  I think there are some valuable bits in the horribly structured code I wrote back then, and maybe someone with more drive than me will build on what&#8217;s here.</p>

<p>Thanks to everyone who has used LameBrain, and especially to the folks who donated money for its development.  It&#8217;s been a lot of fun.</p>

<p><a href="http://funkatron.com/apps/lamebrain/LameBrain_Source_Code.zip">Get LameBrain source code</a></p>

<p>[tags]lamebrain, mp3, source code, realbasic, lame, OS X, ripper, encoder[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "A little Ruby goes a long way"
url_title: a_little_ruby_goes_a_long_way
permalink: a_little_ruby_goes_a_long_way.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2007-02-17
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2262
---
<p>I&#8217;ve been coding PHP for 8 years now, and it can be hard to jump into another language when you&#8217;re so entrenched in the syntax and quirks of another.  However, I still think it&#8217;s a useful exercise from an intellectual standpoint to dabble in &#8220;competitors&#8221; to PHP, like Python and Ruby.  It can also provide some real productivity gains when you leverage something another language does more effectively than PHP.</p>

<p>The Web2.0 kids love to chatter about Ruby&#8217;s beauty and elegance and super awesomeness.  I don&#8217;t give a crap about that per se, but their groovy love-in has produced some <em>very</em> nice libraries for handling Web2.0-ish stuff like XML feeds.  The <a href="http://sporkmonger.com/projects/feedtools/">FeedTools</a> lib is a very comprehensive, very powerful Ruby library that makes creating, consuming and manipulating feeds <em>much</em> easier &#8212; moreso than anything I&#8217;ve found in PHP.</p>

<p>Ruby existed as a good general-purpose scripting language long before Rails made it a nerd-hipster household name, and that&#8217;s how we&#8217;re going to use it here: as a good ol&#8217; fashioned CLI script to aggregate a few separate XML feeds into a single aggregated feed.  You&#8217;ll need to have Ruby and the <a href="http://rubygems.org/">RubyGems</a> package manager installed, which is an exercise left up to the reader (it varies from platform to platform).  Once we have them working, you&#8217;ll need to install the <a href="http://sporkmonger.com/projects/feedtools/">FeedTools</a> gem:</p>

<pre>
# gem install feedtools
</pre>

<p>Now that we have that installed, you can use the feed_tools library in your Ruby scripts.  Here&#8217;s a script I wrote to aggregate three feeds from <a href="http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/">CERIAS</a> into a single combo feed:</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
require "RubyGems"
require "feed_tools"

feedurls = %w(http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/feeds/news
  http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/weblogs/feed/
  http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/feeds/seminars_podcast)

combo = FeedTools::build_merged_feed feedurls

combo.feed_type = 'atom'
combo.title = 'CERIAS Super Combined Feed'
combo.copyright = '2006 CERIAS'
combo.author = 'CERIAS &lt;webmaster@cerias.purdue.edu&gt;'
combo.id = "http://foo.bar/foobar/combo.xml"

File.open('./combo.xml', 'w') do |file|
  file.puts combo.build_xml()
end

puts "done writing"
</pre>

<p>To execute this, you&#8217;ll want to do something like:</p>

<pre>
# ruby /path/to/script/generatecombo.rb
</pre>

<p>The best idea would be to run this as a cron job, as the feed combination process takes maybe a minute even for just these three feeds.</p>

<p>I think most of the script is pretty self-explanatory, but let&#8217;s break it down:</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
require "RubyGems"
require "feed_tools"
</pre>

<p>This works just like you&#8217;d imagine.  Note that to use gem libs, we <em>need</em> to require the RubyGems lib first, as it does some mucketymuck with the require statement to get it to handle gems properly.</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
feedurls = %w(http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/feeds/news
  http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/weblogs/feed/
  http://www.cerias.purdue.edu/feeds/seminars_podcast)
</pre>

<p>This section just makes an array called <code>feedurls</code> that contains the three feed URLs.  <code>%w(...)</code> is just a handy little shorthand for &#8220;treat the stuff between the parentheses as a string, and explode it into an array with whitespace as the delimiter&#8221;.  I <strong>really</strong> wish PHP had something like this, as writing out array data can be pretty tedious.</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
combo = FeedTools::build_merged_feed feedurls
</pre>

<p>This is the line that does all the work of combining the feeds.  One line.  Pretty smooth.  So we now have a Feed object called <code>combo</code>.</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
combo.feed_type = 'atom'
combo.title = 'CERIAS Super Combined Feed'
combo.copyright = '2006 CERIAS'
combo.author = 'CERIAS &lt;webmaster@cerias.purdue.edu&gt;'
combo.id = "http://foo.bar/foobar/combo.xml"
</pre>

<p>We need to set a few properties for <code>combo</code> before it can be published, though.  A couple might not be self-explanatory:</p>

<ul>
<li><code><a href="http://sporkmonger.com/projects/feedtools/api/classes/FeedTools/Feed.html#M000077">feed_type</a></code> determines your feed format.</li>
<li><code><a href="http://sporkmonger.com/projects/feedtools/api/classes/FeedTools/Feed.html#M000082">id</a></code> sets a unique URL for the feed</li>
</ul>

<p>There are many more attributes for feeds available; read the docs on <a href="http://sporkmonger.com/projects/feedtools/api/classes/FeedTools/Feed.html">the Feed class</a> for more info.</p>

<pre class="prettyprint">
File.open('./combo.xml', 'w') do |file|
  file.puts combo.build_xml()
end
</pre>

<p>The <code>build_xml</code> method generates the XML for the feed object we&#8217;ve created.  This final piece of code opens (or creates and opens, if necessary) a file called &#8220;combo.xml&#8221; in the current directory and writes that XML.  The file is automatically closed when this block finished executing.  </p>

<p>So, we now have a nice combined XML feed, ready to be parsed into our PHP apps using <a href="http://simplepie.org">Simplepie</a> or <a href="http://framework.zend.com/manual/en/zend.feed.html">Zend_Feed</a>, and/or served up as-is to feed reading clients.</p>

<p>[tags]ruby, FeedTools, php, xml, generator, parsing, combining[/tags]</p>

	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6384" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">engtech</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://InternetDuctTape.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/15/2008 10:59:44 PM</date>

<p>I&#8217;m doing my usual &#8220;blog search&#8221; before wasting time on a library, and I was wondering if you ended up having any issues with it?</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6385" class="comment-id anchor"></a>

title: "Antibiotic use conclusively linked to bacterial resistance"
url_title: antibiotic_use_conclusively_linked_to_bacterial_resistance
permalink: antibiotic_use_conclusively_linked_to_bacterial_resistance.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:

date: 2007-02-08
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2258
---
<p><a href="http://arstechnica.com/journals/science.ars/2007/2/8/6968">Ars Technica: Antibiotic use conclusively linked to bacterial resistance</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Prior to the development of the first antibiotics in the 1930s, surgery carried a much greater risk of mortality from post-operative infection, and many diseases we take for granted today were life-threatening.  But massive over-prescription and the use of antibiotics as livestock growth supplements have lead to the emergence of antibiotic resistant strains such as MRSA and VRSA that are a growing problem in hospitals around the world.</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "You can&#8217;t do Rails with PHP, and it&#8217;s time to get over it"
url_title: you_cant_do_rails_with_php_and_its_time_to_get_over_it
permalink: you_cant_do_rails_with_php_and_its_time_to_get_over_it.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- PHP
date: 2007-02-03
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2255
---
<p><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/weeping_men.gif' alt='Weepy' /></p>

<p><a href="http://www.soledadpenades.com/2007/01/22/php-will-never-have-a-real-rails-like-framework/">Soledad Penad&eacute;s says &#8220;PHP will never have a (real) Rails-like framework.&#8221;</a> She&#8217;s right. And people need to quit getting their panties in a bunch about this fact.</p>

<blockquote>I know the title is harsh but it’s so true. At least it is according to nowadays php’s implementation of classes and objects, which do not permit to “reopen” and add or redefine new methods to an existing class definition, which is the basis upon Rails (and I presume lots more of applications and frameworks) is built.</blockquote>

<p>I don&#8217;t really think it&#8217;s particularly harsh; it&#8217;s just a matter of fact.  I love PHP, and I&#8217;ve been working in it for the past 8 years, but I need to be a grown-up about this and realize that while it&#8217;s very good for some kinds of things, it is not &#8212; and has never tried to be &#8212; the be-all-end-all of scripting languages.  It&#8217;s accessible, fairly simple, and easy to use in web apps.</p>

<p>I think it&#8217;s rather funny that in the comments so many people are throwing links to PHP frameworks at her, saying &#8220;but, but, but <strong>this</strong> one really is as good as Rails!&#8221;  Guys, please, <em>calm down</em>.  Your testicles have not withered and dropped off because 37 Signals did a good job marketing their framework to The Blogosphere, turning Rails into the programming buzzword for Web2.0.  Just take a deep breath and speak the following mantra until your blood pressure drops: &#8220;Digg, Flickr, Yahoo, Wikipedia&#8230; Digg, Flickr, Yahoo, Wikipedia&#8230;&#8221;</p>

<p>Look, PHP is not Ruby.  It&#8217;s not Scheme.  It&#8217;s not Java.  It&#8217;s not C.  There are great things to be learned and outright stolen from each of these languages, but PHP devs need to stop sweating these stupid language pissing matches and appreciate PHP for what it is.  And maybe spend an evening going through a Ruby tutorial &#8212; it&#8217;ll be good for you.</p>

<p>[tags]php, ruby, rails, pissing match[/tags]</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2255" data-url-title="you_cant_do_rails_with_php_and_its_time_to_get_over_it">

<p>It&#8217;s nice to see there&#8217;s someone which took the time to read even the comments instead of just dropping the name of their favourite php framework or getting disappointed with ruby&#8217;s classes model (like if I had written it heh).</p>

<p>By the way - I use LameBrain. Great tool, funny coincidence :-)

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "e - TextMate for Windows, and more"
url_title: e_textmate_for_windows_and_more
permalink: e_textmate_for_windows_and_more.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
date: 2007-01-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2250
---
<p><div style="float:right;"><a href='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s1.png' title='e screenshot showing PHP syntax highlighting, bundles, and integrated browser for documentation lookups'><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s1.thumbnail.png' alt='e screenshot showing PHP syntax highlighting, bundles, and integrated browser for documentation lookups' /></a>

<a href='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s2.png' title='e screenshot showing current scope information'><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s2.thumbnail.png' alt='e screenshot showing current scope information' /></a>

<a href='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s3.png' title='e screenshow showing Markdown syntax highlighting'><img src='http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/e-editor_s3.thumbnail.png' alt='e screenshow showing Markdown syntax highlighting' /></a></div>I think I may have finally found an equivalent to TextMate that runs on Windows. &#8220;<a href="http://www.e-texteditor.com/">e - The Collaborative Text Editor for Windows</a>&#8221; unabashedly duplicates numerous features from TextMate, with the <a href="http://e-texteditor.com/blog/2006/textmate_on_windows">full endorsement of TM creator Allan Odgaard</a>.  <strong>e</strong> ships with an extensive set of bundles converted from TM, and nearly every kind of bundle operation is supported.  A few items that hook into OS X-specific technologies aren&#8217;t ported, but shell commands are handled by your Cygwin install on Windows.  It works surprisingly well.</p>

<p><strong>e</strong> also has what seems to be a unique feature &#8212; <a href="http://e-texteditor.com/blog/2006/making-undo-usable">an integrated revision control system</a> that enables collaborative editing and a very powerful, advanced &#8220;undo&#8221; functionality.  I haven&#8217;t delved into this much, but it looks like a really cool feature.</p>

<p>I don&#8217;t know how much longer I&#8217;ll be using a Windows box as a primary development machine, but for as long as I do, <strong>e</strong> <em>will</em> be my main text editor.  Even in its current beta, semi-buggy state, it&#8217;s head and shoulders above anything else I&#8217;ve tried.</p>

<p>[tags]textmate, windows, rcs, collaboration, e[/tags]</p>




<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Rounding corners in Illustrator"
url_title: rounding_corners_in_illustrator
permalink: rounding_corners_in_illustrator.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- Design
date: 2007-01-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2248
---
<p>Adobe Illustrator is a lovely vector drawing tool, but one of the places where it&#8217;s mucho lame is in dealing with rounded corners on objects.&nbsp; There actually is a Rounded Corner tool in Illustrator CS2 (maybe earlier too, I can&#8217;t recall), but you can&#8217;t edit the corner roundness after you&#8217;ve drawn the object. <i><b>LAME</b>.</i></p>

<p>To apply rounded corners to an existing object, there is a filter called &#8220;Rounded Corners,&#8221; but this will only round <i>all</i> of the object corners.&nbsp; Sometimes this is fine, but yesterday I wanted to be all Web2.0 and only round 1 corner of an object. I could have made a rectangle with standard corners and do some magic with object mashing, but that&#8217;s fruity.</p>

<p>Thankfully, I came across <a href="http://park12.wakwak.com/~shp/lc/et/en_aics_script.html">a handy little collection of scripts for Illustrator CS and CS2</a>.&nbsp; One of the scripts is called &#8220;<a href="http://park12.wakwak.com/~shp/lc/et/en_aics_script.html#roundany">Round Any Corner</a>,&#8221; and it lets you select a single corner point and apply rounding only to that corner.&nbsp; Totally awesome timesaver for when you&#8217;re trying to make your <a href="http://www.andrewwooldridge.com/myapps/webtwopointoh.html">hipster Internet startup</a> web site.</p>

<p>[tags]illustrator, rounded corners, scripting[/tags]</p>

<p><a href="http://macromates.com/">TextMate</a> on OS X has me completely spoiled, and I really really miss a good text editor on Windows.&nbsp; Much of it has to do with aesthetics, and the fact that the monospaced fonts on Windows suck ass.&nbsp; Thankfully, I found <a href="http://keithdevens.com/wiki/ProgrammerFonts">a cool page that collects links to a bunch of programming-oriented fonts</a>, which will help me escape from the crappiness of Courier New.&nbsp; The TextMate Wiki also has <a href="http://macromates.com/wiki/Main/AlternativeFonts">a good page</a> on alternative fonts for people who are sick of Monaco on OS X (although Monaco is <i>much </i>better than any monospaced font that ships with Windows).<br /><br />The fonts I&#8217;m digging are:<br /></p>

<ul><li><a href="http://dejavu.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Main_Page">DejaVu Sans Mono</a> (has native bold and italic)</li><li><a href="http://www.tobias-jung.de/seekingprofont/">ProFont</a></li><li><a href="http://www.proggyfonts.com/">ProggyClean</a></li><li><a href="http://www.bok.net/MonteCarlo/">MonteCarlo</a> (the bitmap .fon version)</li><li><a href="http://www.netalive.org/tinkering/triskweline/">Triskweline</a> (the bitmap .fon version)</li><li><a href="http://www.ms-studio.com/FontSales/anonymous.html">Anonymous</a></li></ul>

<p><br />Also of note is <a href="http://www.arcavia.com/Software/ProgFont/">this insanity</a>.</p>

<p>[tags]fonts, monospaced, programming[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "As if we needed more evidence that register_globals is bad"
url_title: as_if_we_needed_more_evidence_that_register_globals_is_bad
permalink: as_if_we_needed_more_evidence_that_register_globals_is_bad.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- PHP
date: 2007-01-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2240
---
<p>For the past few years, PHP security experts have been pounding on the heads of sysadmins to <strong>turn off <a href="http://php.net/register_globals">register_globals</a></strong>.  While default installs of PHP turn it off, some popular web apps (especially older versions) insist on using it, so some webhost sysadmins will turn it on, presumably to make things go smoothly for their customers.  Oops!</p>

<p><a href="http://nvd.nist.gov/nvd.cfm?cvename=CVE-2007-0233">CVE-2007-0233</a>, what seems like the 300th Wordpress vulnerability in the last two weeks, reports an sql injection vulnerability in Wordpress 2.0.6 (which was only released 11 days ago).  The exploit appears to rely on register_globals being enabled, though:</p>

<pre>
funkatron@foo > php xpl.php foo.com /wp/

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Wordpress < = 2.0.6 wp-trackback.php Zend_Hash_Del_Key_Or_Index /
/ sql injection admin hash disclosure exploit
(needs register_globals=on, 4 <= PHP < 4.4.3,< 5.1.4)
by rgod
dork: "is proudly powered by WordPress"
mail: retrog at alice dot it
site: http://retrogod.altervista.org
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

pwd hash   ->
admin user ->
exploit failed...
</pre>

<p>This is a good example of why web app security (and any security, for that matter) must be multilayered: on the hardware level, on the server daemon level, on the language environment level, and on the code level.</p>

<p>So, for the love of god, STOP ENABLING REGISTER_GLOBALS, upgrade to <a href="http://wordpress.org/development/2007/01/wordpress-207/">Wordpress 2.0.7</a>, and  (shameless plug) use <a href="http://phpsecinfo.com">PhpSecInfo</a> to audit your PHP environment. ;)</p>

<p>[tags]php, phpsecinfo, register-globals, sql-injection, wordpress[/tags]</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "C64 color palette for Photoshop and Fireworks"
url_title: c64_color_palette_for_photoshop_and_fireworks
permalink: c64_color_palette_for_photoshop_and_fireworks.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Design
date: 2007-01-14
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2235
---
<p><img src="http://funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/uploads//c64.gif" border="0" height="212" width="200" alt="c64.gif" align="right" />For my new C64-inspired Wordpress theme, I really wanted to use authentic colors and characters.  I used <a href="http://www.infinite-loop.at/Power64/index.html">Power64</a>, a C64 emulator for PPC, to generate <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PETSCII">the block graphics characters</a> that were unique to Commodore machines.  For the colors, I made a 16-color palette from an image I found on <a href="http://alex.kazik.de/en/convert.html">Alex Kazik&#8217;s site</a> that included the 16 colors supported by the C64.  Now I can use this palette to convert full-color images to 16-color ones that have a C64 &#8220;look.&#8221;</p>

<p>If you&#8217;re interested, you can <a href="/downloads/c64-pallette.act.zip">download the .act palette</a>.  It should work fine with Photoshop and Fireworks.</p>

<p>[tags]commodore, 64, c64, palette, photoshop, fireworks[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Bug in Zend Studio 5.5&#8217;s php.ini"
url_title: bug_in_zend_studio_55s_phpini
permalink: bug_in_zend_studio_55s_phpini.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2007-01-02
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2230
---
<p>In the php.ini file used by the PHP5 executable, the include path is hosed.&nbsp; If you installed in the default location and are running Windows, you&#8217;ll probably find the file at</p>

<pre>C:\Program Files\Zend\ZendStudio-5.5.0\bin\php5\php.ini</pre>

<p>This line is from the original file:</p>

<pre>include_path = C:\Program Files\Zend\ZendStudio-5.5.0\bin\ZendFramework\library;.</pre>

<p>You might notice that the value is not wrapped in quotes, which makes the ; character demark the beginning of a comment.  That eliminates your current working directory from the include path, which is a pretty major disaster when requiring external files into your script.  The solution is (taa-daa!) to wrap the value in quotes:</p>

<pre>include_path = "C:\Program Files\Zend\ZendStudio-5.5.0\bin\ZendFramework\library;."</pre>

<p>What&#8217;s more annoying is that this bug was in the Beta of 5.5 as well, and apparently didn&#8217;t get fixed.</p>

<p>[tags]zend studio, php5, php.ini, bug, include_path[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHPSecInfo: New release (0.1.2), new plans"
url_title: phpsecinfo_new_release_012_new_plans
permalink: phpsecinfo_new_release_012_new_plans.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- PHPSecInfo
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2006-12-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2226
---
<p>First off, <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/" title="PHPSecInfo">a new build of PHPSecInfo is out</a>: Version 0.1.2, build
20061218. Here&#8217;s what&#8217;s new:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Code is now licensed under &#8220;New BSD&#8221; license. See LICENSE</p></li>
<li><p>Added PhpSecInfo_Test_Core_Allow_Url_Include to test for
allow_url_include in PHP5.2 and above</p></li>
<li><p>fix bug in post_max_size check where upload_max_size value was being
checked</p></li>
<li><p>change curl file_support test to recommend upgrading to newest
version of PHP rather than disabling support in cURL for &#8216;file://&#8217;
protocol</p></li>
<li><p>removed =&amp; calls that force pass by reference in PHP4, so as to not
throw PHP5 STRICT notices. It means passing objects by value in PHP4,
but this seems acceptable for our purposes (memory usage isn&#8217;t
terribly high).</p></li>
<li><p>Fixed bug in PhpSecInfo_Test_Session_Use_Trans_Sid where wrong ini
key was requested (Thanks Mark Wallert)</p></li>
<li><p>New, detailed README file with explanations and basic usage
instructions - Now providing an md5 hash for releases</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Here&#8217;s what I&#8217;m planning to do in the next few releases:</p>

<ol>
<li>More detailed test results, including the current and recommended
settings</li>
<li>A web-based &#8220;glossary&#8221; with more details on each test &amp;
how to fix problems</li>
<li>More tests!!! I especially need your help with
this one!</li>
</ol>

<p>I&#8217;m also going to look into options to reformat the test result
structure, so it plays more nicely with templating systems. No
promises on how this will go, but we&#8217;ll see.</p>

<p>[tags]phpsecinfo, php, security, audit, tool[/tags]</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "On Vox: The Best Pixar Movie"
url_title: on_vox_the_best_pixar_movie
permalink: on_vox_the_best_pixar_movie.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "to spend or not to spend"
url_title: to_spend_or_not_to_spend
permalink: to_spend_or_not_to_spend.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-12-13
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2215
---
<p>The <a href="http://macheist.com/">Macheist</a> folks have finally quit fucking around with fruity puzzles and just started selling software cheap.&nbsp; This is apparently their final hurrah before the whole thing sinks back into the primordial ooze from which flash sites are born.&nbsp; The deal they&#8217;re offering is pretty sweet: a bundle of 8 (and maybe 2 more) shareware apps that would cost nearly $300 individually for <b>$49</b>.&nbsp; It&#8217;s a hot deal, and one I&#8217;d jump on&#8230; except the stuff I <i>really</i> want, I already own.<br /><br />Here&#8217;s what they&#8217;re offering:<br /></p>

<ul><li><b>Delicious Library</b> - totally kickass, but I own it and don&#8217;t really need another copy for any reason.<br /></li><li><b>FotoMagic </b>- apparently lets you make fancy slideshows.&nbsp; Eh&#8230; not compelling.</li><li><b>Shapeshifter </b>- own it, but only one license, and it would make sense to have two for my two macs (I&#8217;m cheating right now)</li><li><b>DEVONthink personal </b>- one of those organization tools that I use for like a week and then end up never opening again</li><li><b>Disco </b>- a <a href="http://www.tuaw.com/2006/11/03/dissing-disco/3">wildy overhyped</a> CD/DVD burning tool that I don&#8217;t want to buy on principle</li><li><b>RapidWeaver </b>- A pretty fancy WYSIWYG web page authoring tool.&nbsp; Looks kinda cool, but it&#8217;s so outside of my usual workflow that I&#8217;m unsure if I&#8217;d ever need it</li><li><b>iClip 4</b> - a more kickass clipboard.&nbsp; Yeah, I just don&#8217;t do that much with the clipboard to make this worthwhile</li><li>One game from <b>Pangea </b>- All of their games look stupid, honestly.&nbsp; If it was a game from <a href="http://www.ambrosiasw.com/">Ambrosia</a>, I&#8217;d totally be up on this</li></ul>

<p><br />If 5000 bundles are sold:<br /></p>

<ul><li><b>NewsFire </b>- a desktop RSS reader that seemed pretty cool, but I already own NewsNewsWire and NewsFire wasn&#8217;t <i>that</i> much cooler.</li></ul>

<p><br />If 10000 bundles are sold:<br /></p>

<ul><li><b>TextMate </b>- The best text editor I&#8217;ve ever used, period.&nbsp; I also already own it, but another license would keep me morally sound.<br /></li></ul>

<p>OTOH, 25% of the proceeds go to charity, and even as-is it&#8217;s probably worth $49 to me.&nbsp; But it&#8217;s not a slam dunk for sure.</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "A tip for system administrators"
url_title: a_tip_for_system_administrators
permalink: a_tip_for_system_administrators.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-11-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2209
---
<p>When entering DNS info, make sure you actually type in the correct IP address for your A records, so that you don&#8217;t spends hours trying to figure out why SMTP works fine with one hostname but not another.<br /><br /><b>64 != 66</b>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "New PHPSecInfo build out (20061023; v0.1.1)"
url_title: new_phpsecinfo_build_out_20061023_v011
permalink: new_phpsecinfo_build_out_20061023_v011.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHPSecInfo
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2006-10-24
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2195
---
<p>This version fixes the errant Notices we were getting, makes it easier to extract test data for your own nefarious purposes, and fixes a bug with the curl file protocol test on PHP4.  The latter unfortunately just skips the test on PHP4 because I&#8217;m not sure how to do the check; suggestions are welcome.</p>

<p>Download: <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/phpsecinfo.zip" title="PHPSecInfo">http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/phpsecinfo.zip</a></p>

<p>Docs: <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/docs/" title="PHPSecInfo Docs">http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/docs/</a></p>

<p><strong>What&#8217;s new:</strong>
v0.1.1
 - Added PhpSecInfo::getOutput(), PhpSecInfo::loadAndRun() and PhpSecInfo::getResultsAsArray() methods
 - Modified PhpSecInfo::runTests() to fix undefined offsent notices
 - Modified PhpSecInfo_Test::setMessageForResult() to fix undefined offset notices
 - Modified PhpSecInfo_Test_Curl_File_Support to skip if PHP version is &lt; 5 (detection of file protocol support relies on PHP5 version of curl_version)</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Interview at Zend Developer Zone"
url_title: interview_at_zend_developer_zone
permalink: interview_at_zend_developer_zone.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- PHPSecInfo
- PHP
date: 2006-10-21
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2194
---
<p>I decided to not be all self-deprecating as I usually am with things like this, and admit that I&#8217;m really happy and proud to say that I was interviewed by Cal Evans for the <a href="http://devzone.zend.com" title="">Zend Developer Zone</a>.</p>

<p />

<blockquote><strong>I guess the first question that comes to my mind is “Why did you build this?”</strong><br />
I built it because there was no good way to audit the security settings in your PHP.INI or your PHP environment. The average PHP user I feel is someone who can use an installer to install scripts on their server, get them running and do a little customization or hack up some code but they are not educated developers. These users have no easy way to check how secure their environment is. So I wrote PHPSecInfo to give these uses something easy to run and present the information in a format they are already familiar with.</blockquote>

<p />

<p><strong><a href="http://devzone.zend.com/node/view/id/1099" title="ED FINKLER TALKS ABOUT PHPSECINFO">Read the rest &raquo;</a></strong></p>

<p />

<p>So we finally went public with <a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/">PHPSecInfo</a> as an official project of the <a href="http://phpsec.org">PHP Security Consortium</a>.<br /><br /><a href="http://phpsec.org/about/news/20oct2006.html">http://phpsec.org/about/news/20oct2006.h<wbr />tml</a><br /><br /><a href="http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/">http://phpsec.org/projects/phpsecinfo/</a><br /><br /><a href="http://phpdeveloper.org/news/6543">http://phpdeveloper.org/news/6543</a><br /><br />I just was interviewed by <a href="http://www.calevans.com/">Cal Evans</a> for the <a href="http://devzone.zend.com/">Zend Developer Zone</a>, which was pretty cool &#8212; it was nice to talk to him again.  He said the story should be posted sometime this weekend or Monday.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Haters"
url_title: haters
permalink: haters.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-10-02
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2187
---
<p>It really bothers me when people talk about how the place I live is objectively bad.&nbsp; Not &#8220;I don&#8217;t like [place]&#8221;, but &#8220;[the place I live] is hell.&#8221;&nbsp; It&#8217;s hard not to take that as a slap in my own face, because I live here by choice, and actually like it pretty well.&nbsp; I&#8217;m sorry you don&#8217;t like it here, but try to be a bit more respectful of the people who do, because not all of them are the slack-jawed yokels you seem to think permeate the population.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Secret Reports Dispute White House Optimism"
url_title: secret_reports_dispute_white_house_optimism
permalink: secret_reports_dispute_white_house_optimism.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-10-02
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2186
---
<p>from <a href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/30/AR2006093000293.html">The Washington Post:</a><br /></p>

<blockquote>
<p>&#8220;We&#8217;ve made three tragic decisions,&#8221; Garner told Rumsfeld.</p>
<p>&#8220;Really?&#8221; Rumsfeld asked.</p>
<p>&#8220;Three terrible mistakes,&#8221; Garner said.</p>
<p>He cited the first two orders Bremer signed when he arrived, the first one banning as many as 50,000 members of Saddam Hussein&#8217;s Baath Party from government jobs and the second disbanding the Iraqi military. Now there were hundreds of thousands of disorganized, unemployed, armed Iraqis running around.</p>
<p>Third, Garner said, Bremer had summarily dismissed an interim Iraqi leadership group that had been eager to help the United States administer the country in the short term. &#8220;Jerry Bremer can&#8217;t be the face of the government to the Iraqi people. You&#8217;ve got to have an Iraqi face for the Iraqi people.&#8221;</p>
<p>Garner made his final point: &#8220;There&#8217;s still time to rectify this. There&#8217;s still time to turn it around.&#8221;</p>
Rumsfeld looked at Garner for a moment with his take-no-prisoners gaze. &#8220;Well,&#8221; he said, &#8220;I don&#8217;t think there is anything we can do, because we are where we are.&#8221;<br /><br />He thinks I&#8217;ve lost it, Garner thought. He thinks I&#8217;m absolutely wrong. Garner didn&#8217;t want it to sound like sour grapes, but facts were facts. &#8220;They&#8217;re all reversible,&#8221; Garner said again.<br /><br />&#8221;<strong>We&#8217;re not going to go back</strong>,&#8221; Rumsfeld said emphatically. </blockquote>

Dermoid cysts are formed from the outer layers of embryonic skin cells. These cells are able to mature into teeth, bones, or hair, and these cysts are able to form anywhere the skin folds inwards to become another organ, such as in the ear or the vagina. The actual vagina is, of course, not able to bite, as the pubococcygeus muscles are not as strong as a human jaw.<br /><br /></font></font><font size="2"><font color="#16569e">(14:18:35) <font size="3"><strong>****</strong></font></font></font><font color="#16569e"><strong><font size="3">@gmail.com/Gaim:</font></strong></font><font size="3"> of course!</font></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Technolust - media edition"
url_title: technolust_media_edition
permalink: technolust_media_edition.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-09-12
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2175
---
<p>So today I had to wait at home in the afternoon for the cable dude to come and hook up the <a href="http://broadband.motorola.com/dvr/dct6412.asp" target="_blank">HD DVR box</a>.  We&#8217;ve had <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-HL-R4266W-Widescreen-HDTV-DLP/dp/B0009EXVIA" target="_blank">an HDTV</a> for about a week now and love it, but haven&#8217;t had a lot of true HD content to view on it.  We don&#8217;t have a whole lot now, but it&#8217;s maybe 12 channels that can carry HD content.  Sports HD content does look really freakin&#8217; good, as does the HD content on HBO.</p>

<p>We also got some crappy cable wiring changed out.  I mentioned that I thought sometimes we were getting low signal power to the tech, and he apparently agreed when he viewed the signal meter and asked to see where the cable was coming in.  I showed him our splitter box, and he said &#8220;how is this working??&#8221;  Apparently the cable that was running in from outside was not the proper type (he called it &#8220;copper&#8221;, but isn&#8217;t it all copper?), and he expected that we would have had more problems than we were.  He also said the guy who first set us up here should have noticed this and fixed it.  Go team!  Anyway, we put in new cable and he saw a +6 dB increase in signal (which I think is significant).  Hopefully we&#8217;ll have less cable modem drops than before.</p>

<p>The biggest challenge is now going to be sorting out how to integrate <a href="http://www.amazon.com/TiVo-TCD540040-Series2-Digital-Recorder/dp/B00029ZE2S" target="_blank">my wondeful Tivo</a> with this setup.  The HD DVR box can record shows, but it&#8217;s extremely basic in terms of functionality when compared to the Tivo unit.  It can send a downsampled signal out of its composite outputs, so for now I have the Tivo hooked up to that, but I&#8217;m not really sure how having two options for watching TV will work out.  The Tivo made everything so easy, and I&#8217;m loathe to complicate things.  I could have kept the standard digital cable box, but I decided to save the $8 a month that would have cost on top of my other increases for HD.  At the end of the day, tho, $8 ain&#8217;t much, so maybe I&#8217;ll ask for another one.  We&#8217;ll see.</p>

<p>Oh, and I&#8217;m really glad I got a TV with lots of inputs, including 2 HDMI inputs.  I can use one for my DVD player and one for the HD DVR box.  The cables are kinda crazy now with all the power cables and Tivo &amp; <a href="http://www.xboxmediacenter.de/" target="_blank">Xbox</a> output, but it would be BATSHIT (8 more than now) if I was running component.  </p>

<p>Oh, and I am SO lusting for an <a href="http://www.engadget.com/2006/09/12/apple-to-release-itv-video-streaming-box-in-2007/" target="_blank">iTV</a> now, so long as it can output HDTV resolution video and someone hacks around the iTunes requirement.  It would be such an awesome front-end for something like <a href="http://www.mythtv.org/" target="_blank">MythTV</a>.</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "How to recover a lost admin password in Contribute, and a tip for connecting via SFTP"
url_title: how_to_recover_a_lost_admin_password_in_contribute_and_a_tip_for_connecting
permalink: how_to_recover_a_lost_admin_password_in_contribute_and_a_tip_for_connecting.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2167
---
<p>A couple tips for administrators of <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/contribute/">Contribute</a> 3 content management systems:</p>

<ul> <li>If you lose your site administrator password, Macromedia/Adobe tells you some lies about having to wipe out all the Contribute settings on your server.&nbsp; <strong>This is not at all true</strong>.&nbsp; Do this to reset the password without wiping out your settings:  <ol> <li>in the document root of your server, there will be a <strong>_mm </strong>directory.&nbsp; In that directory, find a file called something like <strong>cthub[a bunch of numbers].csi</strong>.&nbsp; This is the file that stores your Contribute site settings.  <li>Make a copy of the <strong>cthub</strong>[&#8230;]<strong>.csi</strong> file, so you can restore it if you mess something up.  <li>Edit the file with a text editor (it&#8217;s just an XML file), and change the admin_password and admin_password_salt values to empty strings, like so:<br> <blockquote> <p>&lt;admin_password value=&#8221; /&gt;<br>&lt;admin_password_salt value=&#8221; /&gt;</p></blockquote> <li> <p><a href="http://pics.livejournal.com/funkatron/pic/0002198d" atomicselection="true"><img style="margin: 0px 0px 0px 5px" height="97" src="http://pics.livejournal.com/funkatron/pic/00022y69" width="137" align="right"></a> Now you can make a new connection to the site and make yourself part of the Administrator role without having to enter a password.&nbsp; You&#8217;ll want to set up a new password under <em>Administer Website » Administration</em>, though, and Contribute will complain if you don&#8217;t, so listen to it.</p></li></ol> <li> <p>Is Contribute not accepting your SFTP username and password, even though it works fine in other programs?&nbsp;&nbsp;It might&nbsp;be a weird issue with sshd that I only&nbsp;recently came across, and solved thanks to&nbsp;<a href="http://altbit.org/?p=173">a blog post at altbit.org</a>.&nbsp; It seems that Contribute will not work if <strong>PasswordAuthentication no </strong>is set in the&nbsp;sshd_config file on your server, even if <strong>UsePAM yes</strong> is enabled.&nbsp; So, you <em>must</em> enable <strong>PasswordAuthentication</strong> for Contribute to connect.&nbsp; Fruity.</p></li></ul>

<p></li></li></li></li></p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Spafford On the Use of Lie Detectors by the US Gov&#8217;t"
url_title: spafford_on_the_use_of_lie_detectors_by_the_us_govt
permalink: spafford_on_the_use_of_lie_detectors_by_the_us_govt.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-29
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2165
---
<p><a href="http://digg.com/security/Spafford_On_the_Use_of_Lie_Detectors_by_the_US_Gov_t">Interesting article</a> in zee work blog:</p>

<blockquote>Noted security and cybercrime expert Eugene Spafford discusses the challenges and complexities in the use of lie detectors by the US Government to screen for security clearances.  &#8220;Lie detectors have a non-zero rate of error. As with many real-world systems, these errors manifest as Type I errors (alpha error, false positive) and Type II errors (beta error, false negative), and instances of &#8216;can&#8217;t tell.&#8217; It&#8217;s important to understand the distinction because the errors and ambiguities in any system may not be equally likely, and the consequences may be very different.&#8221;</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Where are the feed creation classes for PHP?"
url_title: where_are_the_feed_creation_classes_for_php
permalink: where_are_the_feed_creation_classes_for_php.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-28
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2164
---
<p>Everybody and their mom has feed parsers built into their fancy frameworks and component libraries, and a couple stand-alone components do an excellent job of making feed consumption a piece of cake, but XML feed <em>creation</em> tools are really lacking in PHP.&nbsp; Of all the major general purpose PHP framework/component&nbsp;collections I know of (PEAR, EZC, ZFW, Cake, Symfony, CodeIgniter), none include a class for creating XML feeds.</p>

<p>The best tool I&#8217;ve seen for the job is Kai Blankenhorn&#8217;s <a href="http://www.bitfolge.de/rsscreator-en.html">FeedCreator</a>.&nbsp; I&#8217;ve used it quite a bit, and it&#8217;s a well-designed class that makes feed creation very easy.&nbsp; It&#8217;s not thoroughly documented, though, and hasn&#8217;t been updated since 2004, so no ATOM 1.0 support.&nbsp; More problematic is that it doesn&#8217;t support enclosures, making it&nbsp;mostly useless&nbsp;for folks wanting to *Cast stuff.</p>

<p>A couple of forks have popped up here and there to address these problems.&nbsp; <a href="http://feedcreator.org/">This one</a>&nbsp;by Mohammad Hafiz bin Ismail&nbsp;has the advantage of looking more like a serious attempt to restart development of the project, rather than a onetime hack to add a couple features.&nbsp; It doesn&#8217;t look like a lot of development has gone on since the initial upload, though, and that&#8217;s a bummer.</p>

<p>So tell me: am I missing something, or is this an area where more work needs to be done?</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Paul Reinheimer will fuck you up and steal your woman"
url_title: paul_reinheimer_will_fuck_you_up_and_steal_your_woman
permalink: paul_reinheimer_will_fuck_you_up_and_steal_your_woman.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-23
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2163
---
<p><img hspace="5" src="http://ec1.images-amazon.com/images/P/0764589547.01._AA240_SCLZZZZZZZ_V60288727_.jpg" align="right" vspace="5"/>My friend Paul Reinheimer just had his new book <a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0764589547/104-9758124-0409541?v=glance&amp;n=283155"><strong>Professional Web APIs with PHP</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;</strong>come out.&nbsp; The book covers using PHP to interface with a variety of web-based APIs, like those of eBay, Google, Paypal and Amazon. You can tell from Paul&#8217;s picture on the cover that he is not one to be trifled with. I strongly suggest that if you value your teeth, you pick up a copy <em>today</em>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Posting from Windows Live Writer"
url_title: posting_from_windows_live_writer
permalink: posting_from_windows_live_writer.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2155
---
<p>So this new blogging tool from Microsoft, <a href="http://windowslivewriter.spaces.live.com/">Windows Live Writer</a>, is pretty nice.&nbsp; It&#8217;s the first Windows blogging client that works with LJ that didn&#8217;t make me want to stab myself in the eye.&nbsp; It also apparently works with Blogger,&nbsp;TypePad, WordPress, Movable Type, and other stuff that uses the <a href="http://www.xmlrpc.com/metaWeblogApi">Metaweblog API</a> or the <a href="http://www.movabletype.org/mt-static/docs/mtmanual_programmatic.html">Movable Type API</a>.</p>

<p>Microsoft&#8217;s embracement of the blogging community seems to have inspired much better UI design and use of open stadards.&nbsp; I&#8217;m very pleased.</p>

<p><a href="http://pics.livejournal.com/funkatron/pic/0001z8z0" atomicselection="true"><img style="border-top-width: 0px; border-left-width: 0px; border-bottom-width: 0px; border-right-width: 0px" height="233" alt="Screenshot from Windows Live Writer" src="http://pics.livejournal.com/funkatron/pic/0001y1a1" width="240" border="0"></a> </p>

<p>The image insertion stuff is the <em>bomb</em>.&nbsp; It auto-generates a thumbnail with a neat little dropshadow, and you can apply watermark text and basic effects (sepia, b&amp;w, sharpen, et al), and do more operations.</p>

<p><strong>Hint:</strong> when you browse for a picture it only filters for .gif and .jpg, but you can change the file type to All Files and use PNGs.</p>
