---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Movin on up!"
url_title: movin_on_up
permalink: movin_on_up.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-08-04
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2146
---
<p>So while I&#8217;ve been generally very happy with Dreamhost, the shared account i have just hasn&#8217;t been able to keep up with the needs of one of my particularly popular sites.  So, I signed up for a VPS account with <a href="http://vpslink.com">http://vpslink.com</a>.<br /><br />If you&#8217;re not familiar with VPS hosting, it stands for Virtual Private Server.  I think there are a few different ways of implementing it, with VPSLink using Virtuozzo (<a href="http://www.swsoft.com/en/products/virtuozzo/">http://www.swsoft.com/en/products/virt<wbr />uozzo/</a>), but basically it entails setting up several virtual machines on one actual server.  These VMs act completely independently of one another, and the customer has full root access on it, but you share the resources of the physical machine with other users.  Basically it ends up being somewhere between a shared account and a dedicated machine in terms of price and performance.<br /><br />I decided on Ubuntu 6.06 for my OS.  I like the Debian package manager, but Ubuntu is a little bit more current with the software they support, and I have a tendency to want to try out new stuff.  It&#8217;s still been really easy for me to set up, even thought I&#8217;m only using the shell account to install and config shit.  It&#8217;s been a good learning experience and assessment of my real knowledge of system administration:<br /><br />&#8212; I know how to set up Apache, PHP and related shit very, very well<br />&#8212; I know how to set up MySQL and PostgreSQL pretty well<br />&#8212; I know very little about setting up mail servers (well, until now)<br />&#8212; DNS and Bind is just beyond me<br /><br />I&#8217;m avoiding messing with DNS too much right now, because looking at Bind and the docs for it made my head explode, but I was able to get Postfix and Dovecot up and running with some research and careful reading of HOWTOs.  Apache et al was a piece of cake, and mega fast thanks to aptitude / apt-get and the much quicker US ubuntu package mirrors.<br /><br />Even without an opcode cache installed, a little testing with http_load indicates that the new system is maybe 10 times faster than my dreamhost shared hosting.  This is encouraging.</p>

Both massive overkill when you just want one binary. 90 minutes of building and half a gigabyte under /opt for it to bomb out on libtiff because my XCode version isn&#8217;t new enough by one minor version, even though the gcc version is fine. It pulled down a <em>lot</em> of stuff that&#8217;s already on the system by default, or has an equivalent. e.g. it&#8217;s building sed, perl, mesa, python, etc, all for kcachegrind! It was quicker to download and install Fedora under VirtualBox and use the linux kcachegrind binary from yum! Not impressed.</p>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="6889" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">funkatron</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://funkatron.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">08/10/2009 11:27:58 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>I would agree. The state of package managers on OS X isn&#8217;t close to Linux. OTOH, there just isn&#8217;t the support there for it. A shame.</p>
</div>
	</li>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>MacCallGrind is actually not to bad. Very basic, no graphs, etc, but does display time results, call tree, and line numbers pretty well. Plenty of features could be added to make it more useful, though.</p>

<p>Another web-based option is Carica CacheGrind:
http://sourceforge.net/projects/ccg/</p>

<p>Like webgrind you can bank on httpd (if you&#8217;re using apache) to run at about 95% CPU usage for a good long while if you&#8217;re parsing large cachegrind files (as I am&#8230;).</p>

<p>MacCallGrind is much faster, but could use more &#8220;goodies.&#8221;</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Running Symfony on Gentoo PHP5"
url_title: running_symfony_on_gentoo_php5
permalink: running_symfony_on_gentoo_php5.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-07-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2137
---
<p>A couple notes for those who are, like me, trying to run <a href="http://www.symfony-project.org/"><span>Symfony</span> </a>on <a href="http://php.net"><span>PHP</span>5</a> in <span><a href="http://www.gentoo.org/">Gentoo</a></span>:</p>

<ul> <li>You&#8217;ll need to make sure that <a href="http://us3.php.net/manual/en/ref.info.php#ini.magic-quotes-gpc">magic_quotes_<span>gpc</span></a> is disabled.&#xA0; It should be anyway, but I believe it defaults to &#8220;on.&#8221;</li> <li>You need to <a href="http://www.symfony-project.com/forum/index.php/m/3955/#msg_3955">add &#8220;reflection&#8221; to the <span>Gentoo</span> <span>useflags</span></a> for <span>dev</span>-<span>lang</span>/<span>php</span>.&#xA0; This functionality seems to be used by the <span>symfony</span> <span>CLI</span> <span>app</span> to build the propel models/<span>sql</span>/do inserts.</li> </ul>

<p>I&#8217;ll add more notes as I come across them.<br /> <br /></p>

<p><strong>Update: official universal builds <a href="http://funkatron.com/wp/archives/os-x/new-builds-of-scplugin-available-including-universal-binaries/">are now available</a>.</strong></p>

<p>Raf. wrote it to let me know that he&#8217;s created an Intel binary of <a href="http://scplugin.tigris.org/">SCPlugin</a>, the Finder plugin that enables SVN access</p>

<blockquote>Hi Ed,

I’ve compiled an Intel version of the plugin (I noticed some comments on your blog <a href="http://funkatron.com/wp/archives/os-x/binary-build-of-scplugin/"> requesting Intel versions</a>)

Please find the file at: <a href="http://studiofunk.com.au/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip">http://studiofunk.com.au/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip</a>
</blockquote>

<p>I&#8217;ve also <a href="http://funkatron.com/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip">mirrored the file locally</a>.</p>

<h1>if !defined(<strong>ppc</strong>) &amp;&amp; !defined(<strong>POWERPC</strong>)</h1>

<p>#error &#8220;this code is currently PowerPC-only&#8221;</p>

<h1>endif</h1>

<p>So, I suspect that there is a missing thing for Intel here.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Opera 9"
url_title: opera_9
permalink: opera_9.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-06-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2127
---
<p>I&#8217;ve given Opera tries here and there when new versions came out, but the newly-released <a href="http://opera.com">Opera 9</a> is <em>really</em> nice.  It&#8217;s <em>extremely</em> fast (much faster than FF on Windows, and appears to be faster than Safari on my iBook G4), has lots of useful features, some great tab handling ideas (multiple undos on closed tabs!!!!!), etc.  PLUS&#8230;. I&#8217;ve seen nary a rendering quirk.  The speed of it is a godsend when dealing with myspace promo crap, especially being able to toggle off images, plugins, and extra styling.  Oh, and did I mention it used orders of magnitude less memory than my Firefox install (which has several extensions installed, of course)?  There are lots of other features too, some extremely useful (almost everything is searchable, including your history), some not so much (did we need another widget standard?)<br /><br />It&#8217;s nice.  I&#8217;m going to give this a serious shot as my main browser.  Firebug on Firefox still is a killer HTML/CSS/JS debug tool that will keep me from ditching FF altogether, but for day to day use I can see myself using this.</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Using PostgreSQL SERIAL keys and PEAR DB sequences properly"
url_title: using_postgresql_serial_keys_and_pear_db_sequences_properly
permalink: using_postgresql_serial_keys_and_pear_db_sequences_properly.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-06-26
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2125
---
<p>Our internal CRUD app framework uses DB_DataObject as its data access layer, and DB_DO is in turn built on top of the <a target="_blank" href="http://pear.php.net/package/DB/">Pear_DB</a> layer.  Pear_DB has <a target="_blank" href="http://pear.php.net/manual/en/package.database.db.intro-sequences.php">a special sequence system</a> that works great out of the box with MySQL AUTO_INCREMENT keys, but it needs a little fiddling to play nice with PostgreSQL&#8217;s SERIAL metatype.  Basically, if you don&#8217;t tweak the sequence stuff a bit, Pear_DB won&#8217;t be able to retrieve the next ID # in the sequence.  This is an ignorable problem for single-table situations, but can cause problems (including data loss) with many-to-many relationships and other more complex cases.</p>

<p>The easiest way to get the Pear_DB sequences to play nice with your PostgreSQL sequences is to redefine the <tt>sequenceKey()</tt> method in your DB_DataObject-extending class:</p>

<pre class="code">class Otacon_Contact extends DB_DataObject 
{
     [...]

    /* the code above is auto generated do not remove the tag below */
    ###END_AUTOCODE

    /* this is required to get PEAR DB sequences working properly */
    function sequenceKey() { return array('contact_id', false, 'contact_contact_id_seq'); }

     [...]
}

</pre>

<p>In the example above, <tt>contact_id</tt> is the primary_key of the table, and <tt>contact_contact_id_seq</tt> is the sequence that <tt>contact_id</tt> gets its next value from.  This makes the Pear_DB sequence stuff to query this sequence to get the next value for your primary key, and you should be golden.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2125" data-url-title="using_postgresql_serial_keys_and_pear_db_sequences_properly">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1722" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">ucho</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://litestep.boo.pl</div>
		<div class="comment-date">07/11/2006 08:02:55 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><h2>They should put this in both PSQL and PEAR::DB manual :P</h2>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>
</div>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Parallels Desktop is Pretty Awesome"
url_title: parallels_desktop_is_pretty_awesome
permalink: parallels_desktop_is_pretty_awesome.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-06-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2120
---
<p><a href="http://flickr.com/photos/39241541@N00/170016368"><br />  <img src="http://static.flickr.com/46/170016368_cbe12036d3_m.jpg" alt="Parallels Desktop is Pretty Awesome" /><br /></a><br /> <br /></p>

<p>Running <a href="http://www.zend.com/products/zend_studio">Zend Studio</a> 5.2 in WinXP within <a href="http://www.parallels.com">Parallels Desktop</a> on my 20&#8221; iMac Core Duo (1.5GB RAM).&#xA0; It runs pretty nicely, and since it&#8217;s a crapshoot getting the <a href="http://www.zend.com/products/zend_studio">ZDE</a> installed on an Intel Mac, quite handy.</p>

<p>Parallels Desktop has gotten better since the last time I tried it.&#xA0; Seems more stable, and has added some handy features, like automatically adding a network share on your OS X host to allow you to map it as a drive in Windows.&#xA0; CD/DVD handling seems to work better now too, although I have only tried reading, not writing disks.<br /> </p>

<p>I really highly recommend an Intel Mac for anyone who&#8217;s interested in running OS X and Windows (even for midlevel gaming).&#xA0; I&#8217;ve been extremely happy with this purchase.&#xA0; If <a href="http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/Research/SRG/netos/xen/">Xen</a> and/or <a href="http://www.vmware.com/">VMWare</a> come out with host apps for their virtualization systems, it&#8217;s gonna be utterly killer.<br /> </p>





<!-- end of post -->

tags: ""

- General
date: 2006-03-29

old_entry_id: 2093
---
<p>Ya know, I loved Casino, but she is just batshit crazy.<br /><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>In a bizarre explanation she tells this story, according to Contact Music UK:<br /><br />&#8220;I was in the store the other day and I watched a young girl trying on clothes, showing her abdomen.<br /><br />&#8220;Her mother was trying to talk to her about not being inappropriately luring. I said, &#8216;Gee that would look much nicer with a camisole under.&#8217; &#8220;Her mother walked away, and I said to the girl, &#8216;I&#8217;d like to give you a two-minute conversation about sex.&#8217; &#8220;Young people talk to me about what to do if they&#8217;re being pressed for sex? I tell them (what I believe): oral sex is a hundred times safer than vaginal or anal sex.<br /><br />&#8220;If you&#8217;re in a situation where you cannot get out of sex, offer a blow job. I&#8217;m not embarrassed to tell them.&#8221;</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /><a href="http://www.nationalledger.com/artman/publish/article_27264412.shtml">http://www.nationalledger.com/artman/pu<wbr />blish/article_27264412.shtml</a><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/140396.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/140396.html</a></em></p>

<blockquote><a href="http://www.gojobby.com"><img src="http://www.gojobby.com/Jobby/img/logo_small.gif" align="Right"></a>I think Web 2.0 needs a little cultural diversity training.  A new job tracking website called, well, Jobby has just launched in beta.<br /><br />I mean, seriously people, at least give your name <a href="http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=jobby">a spin through Urban Dictionary</a> and then <em>please</em> reconsider making the domain name gojobby.com.  You&#8217;re just not going to get that word-of-mouth marketing when you have to tell people that &#8220;I use Jobby&#8221;&#8230;.<br /><br />This stuff just writes itself:  <em>Build Your Own Jobby Posting Wizard to allow companies and recruiting firms to create their very own version of Jobby.</em></blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Note to MacNN: Plagarism isn&#8217;t cool, and at least link to your sources"
url_title: note_to_macnn_plagarism_isnt_cool_and_at_least_link_to_your_sources
permalink: note_to_macnn_plagarism_isnt_cool_and_at_least_link_to_your_sources.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-03-14
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2084
---
<p><a href="http://arstechnica.com/journals/apple.ars/2006/3/13/3169">http://arstechnica.com/journals/apple.ar<wbr />s/2006/3/13/3169</a><br /></p>

<blockquote><strong>According to a post by narf2006, a user who is said to be very credible on the &#8220;WinXP on Mac&#8221; forums and has been diligently hacking away since the challenge started, the magic has officially happened and he has submitted his super secret process to the owners of the site to review.</strong> His proof offered up in the thread, however, is a Flickr set of photos (some better than others) of what appears to be Windows XP (will the real WinXP please stand up?) on what we assume to be an Intel iMac.<br /><br />Of course, immediate reaction tends to be &#8220;zomg Photochop lol!&#8221; And I won&#8217;t say that that wasn&#8217;t my initial reaction either. However, upon further inspection of the currently available evidence, there may be more to this rumor than mad chops. A post titled &#8220;Mission Accomplished - twice almost&#8221; on the Windows on Mac blog appears to indicate that narf2006&#8217;s processes are (almost) reproducible <strong>and there is even a thread on the forums now asking for testers—three for MacBook Pros, three for iMacs, and three for Mac minis.</strong><br /><br /></blockquote>

<p><a href="http://www.macnn.com/articles/06/03/14/xp.coming.to.mactels/">http://www.macnn.com/articles/06/03/14/x<wbr />p.coming.to.mactels/</a><br /></p>

<blockquote><strong>A recent post by a user who is said to be very credible on the &#8220;WinXP on Mac&#8221; forums has submitted his process to the owners of the site for review, and there is now a thread on the forums asking for testers &#8212; three MacBook Pros, three iMacs, and three Mac minis.</strong> As yet no definitive evidence has been released to the public that Windows XP is running on an Intel-based Mac, however.<br /><br /></blockquote>

<p>I know writing is hard, and C&amp;P can be tempting, but shit, at least reference where you saw the story first.&nbsp; It&#8217;s fucking common courtesy.<br /><br /><strong>Update:</strong> They added a credit, at least.&nbsp; No link tho.&nbsp; Lame.<br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/137325.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/137325.html</a></em></p>

<p>A friend of mine who shall remain nameless let me post this work of his:<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>There are really only 10 stories in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michiana">Michiana</a>:<br />
<ol>
    <li>The Schools are Broke</li>
    <li>Someone is Raising Taxes</li>
    <li>It&#8217;s Fat Tuesday: Eat your Paczki</li>
    <li>Company &#8216;X&#8217;  is closing.</li>
    <li>Company &#8216;X&#8217; is opening.</li>
    <li>You&#8217;re Going to Die</li>
    <li>You&#8217;ve Already Died</li>
    <li>Did the Groundhog see his shadow?</li>
    <li>Something Is on Fire</li>
    <li>Water Skiing Squirrel is in Town</li>
</ol>
</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Thunderbird + IPv6 = No LDAP For You!"
url_title: thunderbird_ipv6_no_ldap_for_you
permalink: thunderbird_ipv6_no_ldap_for_you.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- Development
date: 2006-02-08
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2072
---
<p>For a while now I&#8217;ve not been able to connect to the Purdue campus LDAP server from Thunderbird.  Today I got a bit more determined to figure out the issue, and discovered after about 5 hours that Thunderbird is just fucked in the following situation:</p>

<p>1) You are running WinXP
2) You have the Windows IPv6 stack installed
3) You try to connect to an LDAP server from the Thunderbird Address Book</p>

<p><a href="http://lair.moria.org/blog/entry/Work/Thunderbird_windowsXP_ipv6_and_LDAP_directories.txt" target="_blank">This guy</a> does a better job of explaining it than I ever could, and I only half understood what the fuck was going on anyway, but nevertheless, this is <i>beyond gay</i>.  All the other apps with LDAP server query functionality (like Ye Olde Windows Address Book) work fine.  I actually ended up installing Windump on my machine, and saw that while every other app connected to the LDAP server fine, Thunderbird&#8217;s packets went off on a fucking trip through Singapore and got sold into sex slavery.</p>

<p>Anyway, the workaround &#8212; until the Thunderbird guys fix <a href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=228439" target="_blank">this 2+ year old bug</a> &#8212; is to go into the properties for your ethernet device and uninstall Microsoft Version 6 TCP/IP (or whatever they call it).  I guess I wasn&#8217;t using it anyway&#8230;</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="2072" data-url-title="thunderbird_ipv6_no_ldap_for_you">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1717" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">CS Lauritsen</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://planetlauritsen.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">12/08/2006 03:29:08 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><h2>Awesome! This has been pissing me off for at least a year. I couldn&#8217;t find anything with google until today, when your site came up. Thanks! I can use the &#8216;bird on winxp once again and all is well.</h2>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>
</div>

title: "Eat a dick, Gibson and O&#8217;Reilly"
url_title: eat_a_dick_gibson_and_oreilly
permalink: eat_a_dick_gibson_and_oreilly.html
tags: ""

category:
- General
date: 2006-02-02
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2068
---
<blockquote>Contradicting predictions by commentators that Brokeback Mountain would not attract ticket buyers in red-state strongholds like Montana, the film has actually performed strongly in many of those areas, distributor Focus Features has maintained. (Fox News commentator John Gibson remarked: &#8220;I think most people do not want to go into a darkened room with a tub of popcorn and munch away watching two guys get it on.&#8221; His colleague Bill O&#8217;Reilly has opined that the film has received critical praise because the media &#8220;want to mainstream homosexual conduct.&#8221; And he predicted, &#8220;They&#8217;re not going to go see the gay cowboys in Montana.&#8221;) However, the online magazine Salon today (Thursday) quoted the manager of the Wilma Theater in Missoula as saying that the film grossed $33,006 in its first four weekends there &#8212; &#8220;one of our best starts for a movie we&#8217;ve ever had.&#8221; In the conservative town of Kalispell, the film opened last Friday with $3,656. In the town of Whitefish, it took in $2,312 and beat out the three top national draws, including the No. 1 film, Big Momma&#8217;s House 2. Salon indicated that the film is also a hit in Great Falls, Bozeman, and Helena, where it also opened at No. 1.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br />You know why?  Because it&#8217;s not about two flaming queers smoking meth, throwing on cowboy hats and teabagging each other.  It&#8217;s a sad, romantic story about unfinished love and fear and how it can haunt us to the day we die.  It&#8217;s not as if this movie makes out their relationship to be a super-awesome, healthy thing.  And maybe if folks like O&#8217;Reilly and Gibson weren&#8217;t such fucking assholes, they could but aside their homophobia and knee-jerk morality and see that, <em>even if they don&#8217;t think homosexuality is morally correct</em>.<br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/132480.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/132480.html</a></em></p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Yojimbo stores ALMOST anything"
url_title: yojimbo_stores_almost_anything
permalink: yojimbo_stores_almost_anything.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2006-01-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2058
---
<p>So lots of people are pooping their pants over <a href="http://www.barebones.com/products/yojimbo/index.shtml">Yojimbo</a>, this new personal info organization app from BareBones.  I&#8217;ve started using it, and it is pretty cool, but I&#8217;ve run into a bit of an issue: it doesn&#8217;t like <a href="http://www.omnigroup.com/applications/omnioutliner/">OmniOutliner</a> 2 files.  Try to drag one in, and you get no love.  I guess this is what they mean by the following:</p>

<blockquote>Store <i>almost</i> anything in Yojimbo&mdash;text, rich text, images, PDFs, even serial numbers and passwords</blockquote>

<p>(my emphasis)</p>

<p>Some may wonder why I&#8217;m still running OO v2 when I think <a href="http://www.omnigroup.com/">OmniGroup</a> has had v3.5 out for about a hundred years.  That&#8217;s because I&#8217;m lazy, and I actually like v2 a bit better - it&#8217;s simpler, and I like the way it looks.  Probably it&#8217;s just inertia, though, and I&#8217;d like v3 better if I just used it.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The Sunny Blade Runner"
url_title: the_sunny_blade_runner2
permalink: the_sunny_blade_runner2.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2006-01-05
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2065
---
<p><a href="http://rossignol.cream.org/?p=284">Fascinating story on the PC gaming phenomenon in South Korea</a>:<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>“So this guy has a lot of fans?” I say, knowing the answer but nevertheless incredulous.<br /><br />“Hundreds of thousands in his fan club,” says Yang. “Impossible to track the number of people who watch him play.”<br /><br />Impossible, because the man on the stage is on Korean television almost every day. He is about to sit down and play what is close to becoming Korea’s national sport: Starcraft. His name is Lee Yunyeol, or in game [RED]NaDa Terran. He is The Champion. Last year his reported earnings were around $200,000. He plays a seven year-old RTS for fame and fortune and to many Koreans he is an idol. Every night over half a million Koreans log on to Battlenet and make war in space, many of them with dreams of becoming like Yunyeol. But his skill is almost supernatural. Few people who play all day long will be able to claim a fraction of his split-second timing and pitiless concentration. Practicing eight hours a day, Yunyeol’s methods and tactics are peerless. Well, almost peerless. In fact there are two or three other players who command similar salaries. They might not hold the crown now, and one of them will probably take it from him soon, but for now at least, Yunyeol is king.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/130260.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/130260.html</a></em></p>

<p><a href="http://rossignol.cream.org/?p=284">Fascinating story on the PC gaming phenomenon in South Korea</a>:<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>“So this guy has a lot of fans?” I say, knowing the answer but nevertheless incredulous.<br /><br />“Hundreds of thousands in his fan club,” says Yang. “Impossible to track the number of people who watch him play.”<br /><br />Impossible, because the man on the stage is on Korean television almost every day. He is about to sit down and play what is close to becoming Korea’s national sport: Starcraft. His name is Lee Yunyeol, or in game [RED]NaDa Terran. He is The Champion. Last year his reported earnings were around $200,000. He plays a seven year-old RTS for fame and fortune and to many Koreans he is an idol. Every night over half a million Koreans log on to Battlenet and make war in space, many of them with dreams of becoming like Yunyeol. But his skill is almost supernatural. Few people who play all day long will be able to claim a fraction of his split-second timing and pitiless concentration. Practicing eight hours a day, Yunyeol’s methods and tactics are peerless. Well, almost peerless. In fact there are two or three other players who command similar salaries. They might not hold the crown now, and one of them will probably take it from him soon, but for now at least, Yunyeol is king.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/130260.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/130260.html</a></em></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Binary build of SCPlugin"
url_title: binary_build_of_scplugin
permalink: binary_build_of_scplugin.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- OS X
date: 2005-12-25
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2036
---
<p><strong>It appears that development of SCPlugin has resumed, despite the fact that the news page has not been updated in over two years.  The project&#8217;s <a href="http://scplugin.tigris.org/servlets/ProjectDocumentList">Documents &amp; Files page</a> offers downloads of versions as new as December 9, 2006, including an &#8220;experimental&#8221; Universal Binary build of SCPlugin.  I haven&#8217;t had a chance to test this yet, but this is certainly encouraging.</strong></p>

<p><strong>Older information follows&#8230;</strong></p>

<p><strong>NOTE: Despite the fact that some folks have gotten it to compile, Intel builds of this plugin have proven to be <em>extremely</em> buggy.  At this point I have switched to using <a href="http://www.lachoseinteractive.net/en/community/subversion/svnx/">svnX</a> for all of my svn needs on OS X.  The best I can recommend would be to contact the SCPlugin project maintainers listed at <a href="http://scplugin.tigris.org/">scplugin.tigris.org</a> and request that effort be put into Intel compatibility.</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://scplugin.tigris.org/">SCPlugin</a>, a contextual menu plugin for the OS X Finder, is pretty cool.  The official distro is only via source, tho, which isn&#8217;t super handy for a lot of folks.  So I built the plugin and zipped that bad boy up for your enjoyment:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://funkatron.com/downloads/SCFinderPlugin.zip">Download (2.6MB zip)</a></li>
</ul>

<p>Merry Xmas!</p>

<p><strong>Update:</strong> Raf. has built what promises to be an Intel-compatible version of SCPlugin:</p>

<blockquote>Hi Ed,

I&#8217;ve compiled an Intel version of the plugin (I noticed some comments
on your blog requesting Intel versions: <a href="http://funkatron.com/wp/archives/os-x/binary-build-of-scplugin/">http://funkatron.com/wp/archives/os-x/binary-build-of-scplugin/</a>)

Please find the file at:
<a href="http://studiofunk.com.au/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip">http://studiofunk.com.au/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip</a>

You can <a href="http://funkatron.com/downloads/SCPlugin-Intel.zip">mirror</a> the file if you like and let some of your readers know
with an updated article.</blockquote>

<p>[tags]svn, subversion, OS X, mac, Finder, plugin, scplugin, intel, binary, compile[/tags]</p>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>There&#8217;s a new release of SCPlugin available at the site, release 0.7.  This release is a Universal Binary (Intel and PPC), includes a proper installer, and implements the complete work flow for most users.  New features include:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>You can provide your login info during commit &#8212; no more need for a separate command-line client for this!</p></li>
<li><p>In fact, no need for a command-line client at all: we&#8217;re now building against the libraries themselves, rather than running the external client, so things are faster and more reliable</p></li>
<li><p>In fact, no need for a separate SVN installation at all: we bundle Subversion as a Framework inside the plug-in</p></li>
<li><p>Login info securely cached in the OS X Keychain</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Pop on over and give it a try!  http://scplugin.tigris.org</p>

<p>While you&#8217;re there, join our users list, for help in using it and discussions about what we should implement next.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Duuuuude."
url_title: duuuuude
permalink: duuuuude.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-12-23
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2060
---
<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dude">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dude</a> (thanks <span class='ljuser' style='white-space: nowrap;'><a href='http://pr0t.livejournal.com/profile'><img src='http://stat.livejournal.com/img/userinfo.gif' alt='[info]' width='17' height='17' style='vertical-align: bottom; border: 0;' /></a><a href='http://pr0t.livejournal.com/'><b>pr0t</b></a></span>)<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>There is no definitive origin of the word dude. The Compact Oxford Dictionary suggests it comes from a German dialect word meaning &#8216;fool&#8217;. The Random House Historical Dictionary of American Slang cites an 1877 reference in an unpublished private letter of the painter and sculptor known for Western themes, Frederick Remington: &#8220;Don&#8217;t send me any more women or any more dudes,&#8221; he told a correspondent who was sending him sketches. &#8220;Dude&#8221; first appeared in print in 1878. The word made the rounds of New York City slang of ca 1883, referring to a fastidiously sharp dresser, affecting sophistication. This is what the late 18th century British would have referred to as a &#8220;dandy&#8221;, which brings us to the compelling theory that &#8220;dude&#8221; was actually derived from the &#8220;Doodle&#8221; of the song &#8220;Yankee Doodle Dandy&#8221;.<br /><br />    <blockquote>Yankee Doodle went to town, A-riding on a pony.<br />    Stuck a feather in his cap, and called it &#8220;macaroni&#8221;<br /><br />    Yankee Doodle keep it up, Yankee Doodle Dandy<br />    Mind the music and the step, and with the girls be handy</blockquote><br /><br />The song was actually written by the British as an insult to the colonists during the French and indian war&#8212;the British soldiers have been decked out in their royal uniforms, and the colonists, or yankees, in rags and coonskin caps. So &#8220;Yankee Doodle Dandy&#8221; was a mocking take on colonial lack of sophistication. A &#8220;macaroni&#8221; was a British slang term for French or Italian attire, thus a man who had travelled to Paris or Rome, and adopted their style, affecting a high level of sophistication, was the definitive dandy. Yankee Doodle is so unsophisticated that he when sticks the feather in his cap and calls it &#8220;macaroni&#8221;, he believes he is being fashionable. The British popularized the song during the Revolutionary War, but the colonists in their victory eventually embraced the song as their own, showing pride in their lack of affected sophistication</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/129279.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/129279.html</a></em></p>

<blockquote>In other words, Eichenwald helped convince Berry to quit porn and quit drugs. He found him a lawyer. The lawyer, in turn, persuaded federal prosecutors to give Berry immunity for serving as the state&#8217;s witness.<br /><br />What extraordinary intervention! The analogies aren&#8217;t perfect, but imagine a Times reporter encountering an 18-year-old who had been thrust into the illicit drug business at 13 as a consequence of his neglectful family and unscrupulous dealers? Would he help the young man leave the drug trade and find him a lawyer at a Washington firm who is &#8220;a former federal prosecutor,&#8221; as Eichenwald did Berry? Not likely. Would a Times reporter extend similar assistance to an 18-year-old female prostitute? An 18-year-old fence? A seller of illegal guns? No way.</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The departure of the hyper-enthusiasts"
url_title: the_departure_of_the_hyper_enthusiasts
permalink: the_departure_of_the_hyper_enthusiasts.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
date: 2005-12-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2032
---
<p>Really interesting article on Ruby, Rails, Python, Django, Zope, Java, and EJB.  It covers a lot of ground, but deals with stuff I&#8217;ve been thinking a lot about lately: what direction to follow as a web app developer.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=141312">The departure of the hyper-enthusiasts</a>:</p>

<blockquote>The Java hyper-enthusiasts have left the building, leaving a significant contingent of Java programmers behind, blinking in the bright lights without the constant drumbeat of boosterism.

But the majority of programmers, who have been relatively quiet all this time, always knew that Java is a combination of strengths and weaknesses. These folks are not left with any feelings of surprise, but instead they welcome the silence, because it&#8217;s easier to think and work.

Where did the hyper-enthusiasts go? To Ruby, apparently.</blockquote>

<p>I especially appreciate his comments about Zope:</p>

<blockquote>I&#8217;ve been bumping up against the problem of &#8220;but all I want to do is connect a database to the web&#8221; in Zope2 for several years now. Oh, it&#8217;s definitely something you can do, but unfortunately it&#8217;s past the knee of the &#8220;Z-shaped learning curve,&#8221; and is only trivial if you live and breathe Zope every day. Don&#8217;t get me wrong; Zope is an excellent system and incredibly powerful, and Zope3 may be much easier, but I&#8217;m out of steam. I have realized that on my site, I really just want to do a collection of simple things, and I don&#8217;t want to relearn Zope every time I want to accomplish something. So &#8212; sorry, Jim (Fulton, not Kirk) &#8212; I&#8217;m going to find something drop-dead simple to solve my drop-dead simple problems. Probably PHP5, which actually includes most of Java and C++ syntax, amazingly enough, and I wonder if that isn&#8217;t what made IBM adopt it.</blockquote>

<p>PHP5&#8217;s simplicity makes it perfect for writing (relatively) small apps &#8212; it&#8217;s a lightweight solution that lends itself to &#8220;dead-simple&#8221; problems.  I am kind of curious about Zope3, though &#8212; I closely examined Zope2 a few years back as a possibly solution for a departmental web system, but the learning curve was just way too steep to make up for the wins you got from it.</p>

<p>(Via <a href="http://simon.incutio.com/blogmarks/">Simon Willison Blogmarks</a>.)</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The Medical Malpractice Myth"
url_title: the_medical_malpractice_myth
permalink: the_medical_malpractice_myth.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-12-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2047
---
<p><a href="http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/036480.html">http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chica<wbr />go/036480.html</a>:<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Throughout the medical malpractice crisis, leading newspapers carried accounts of other obvious medical mistakes. Like the L.A. Times piece on Jesica and Jeanella, the accounts often linked the particular mistakes to the larger story about the extent of medical malpractice in U.S. health care. The report by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Science, To Err Is Human, was a common source. That report summarized research showing that nearly 100,000 people die in the United States each year from medical mistakes—more than die from automobile and workplace accidents combined.<br /><br />Because of that research and reporting, public opinion is coming around to the view that, distressingly, Jesica’s and Jeanella’s problems are not unique; our health care system has a serious medical-injury problem. But at the same time, public opinion remains firmly anchored to the view that we have an explosion of what President George W. Bush calls “junk lawsuits” and that medical malpractice lawsuits contribute significantly to the high cost of health care in the United States.<br /><br />Stories like Jesica’s and Jeanella’s helped shift public opinion about medical malpractice only because they were linked to research and reporting that reframed medical malpractice as a public health problem. But their stories did not shift public opinion about medical malpractice lawsuits, because they were not linked to research and reporting that reframed malpractice lawsuits as a public good.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://funkatron.livejournal.com/128244.html">http://funkatron.livejournal.com/128244.html</a></em></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "&#8220;In search of the One True Layout&#8221;"
url_title: in_search_of_the_one_true_layout
permalink: in_search_of_the_one_true_layout.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
- Design
date: 2005-10-28
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2027
---
<p>I fucking love CSS, but certain kinds of layouts are annoyingly difficult to do &emdash; and very doable in table-based approaches.  Since we sure as hell don&#8217;t wanna go down that road anymore, <a href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/articles/onetruelayout/">this article</a> on <a href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/">position is everything</a> is GOLD, JERRY.</p>

<blockquote>Pure CSS-based layouts have come a long way but they still have shortcomings [2] that fail to address certain design goals without compromising the true separation of content and presentation.

In short, the problematic design goals are these:

<strong>Total Layout Flexibility</strong>

That is, the ability to order columns logically in the source while displaying them in any order desired. For any number of columns.

<strong>Equal Height Columns</strong>

Or more accurately, equal height columns without having to rely on faux columns.

<strong>Vertical placement of elements across grids/columns</strong>

Designers face the choice of relying on elements being a particular height, resorting to tables or simply not bothering.</blockquote>

<p><a href="http://www.positioniseverything.net/articles/onetruelayout/">In search of the One True Layout</a></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Apache conf file syntax coloring for nano"
url_title: apache_conf_file_syntax_coloring_for_nano
permalink: apache_conf_file_syntax_coloring_for_nano.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- The Web Problem
date: 2005-10-28
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2026
---
<p>I&#8217;m gonna lose all 1337 h4x0r rep my admitting that my fav editor is <a href="http://www.nano-editor.org/">Nano</a>.  This is a remnant of using <a href="http://www.washington.edu/pine/">Pine</a> as my preferred email program in college (and even today when I can only get in via SSH), which by default uses <a href="http://www.indiana.edu/~ucspubs/b103/">Pico</a> as its editor.  Nano is a Pico clone that has a &#8220;free as in freedom&#8221; license in the GPL, and adds some enhancements like regex searching and <strong>syntax coloring</strong>.</p>

<p>Yesterday I decided to delve back into developing syntax coloring stuff for Nano on our servers, and came up with a pretty decent setup for Apache conf files.  It includes special coloring for the <a href="http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/mod/directives.html">runtime config directives</a>.</p>

<p>To use this, make a text file in your home directory called <code>.nanorc</code> and paste the contents of this file into it:</p>

<p><a href="http://funkatron.com/downloads/nano/apacheconf-coloring.txt">http://funkatron.com/downloads/nano/apacheconf-coloring.txt</a></p>

		<div class="comment-body"><p>Thanks for putting this together.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve found it&#8217;s a good idea to drop these syntax highlighters into their own repositories, wither as a system global or at least in my own personal which is referenced from my .nanorc</p>

<p>as an example&#8230;</p>

<pre><code>## Nanorc files
 include "/usr/local/share/nano/c.nanorc"

## Apache Configuration Files
 include "~/.nanorc.d/apache.nanorc"
</code></pre>

<p>Still great work thanks!!!</p>

<blockquote>RUSSERT: And Matt, the most astounding number in this: 2 percent – just 2 percent - of African-Americans give George Bush a positive rating for his performance as President. The memories of Katrina very much in their minds.<br /><br />LAUER: Is that what this is all about? I mean, obviously that is just a startling number, 2 percent of African-Americans. Is this all about the aftermath of Katrina?<br /><br />RUSSERT: Well, the imagery of that along with the economy and fuel prices and Iraq, but that event, Matt, really did have a searing effect. George Bush and the Republican Party has tried very hard to reach out to African-American voters, but this is a very dramatic setback. <strong>I cannot find a pollster who can remember any President ever getting just 2 percent approval from African-Americans.</strong></blockquote>

<p><br /><br /><br /><br /><a href="http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9672058/" target="_blank">Bush approval dips below 40 percent</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>For the first time in the poll, Bush’s approval rating has sunk below 40 percent, while <strong>the percentage believing the country is heading in the right direction has dipped below 30 percent.</strong> In addition, a sizable plurality prefers a Democratic-controlled Congress, and just 29 percent think Supreme Court nominee Harriet Miers is qualified to serve on the nation’s highest court.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /><br /><br /><a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/theblog/archive/../../bob-burnett/playing-by-bush-rules_b_8788.html" target="_blank">Bob Burnett: Playing by Bush Rules</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Americans know a lot about Christianity as more than 80 percent identify with that religion. We understand that orthodox Christians do not lie, put their personal fortune above the common good, or believe that the ends justify the means. Proper Christians operate by the ethical equivalent of the Marques of Queensbury rules. Most believe that it’s not whether you win or lose but how you play the game.<br /><br />But George W. Bush plays by his own rules. As American watch this administration unravel – as the electorate begins to understand the folly of the Iraq occupation, the fantasy of homeland security, and the abandonment of governance in the pursuit of political gain – one wonders which realization will come first: Will it be that Bush the President is incapable of leading the U.S., or will it be that <strong>Bush the man doesn’t deserve to be called a Christian?</strong></blockquote>

layout: post

title: "Serenity Reviews"
url_title: serenity_reviews
permalink: serenity_reviews.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-10-01
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2019

<p>I don&#8217;t generally agree with critics, but I like to use them for my purposes when I do.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.imdb.com/news/sb/2005-09-30#film4">Movie &amp; TV News @ IMDB.com</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>In her review, Manohla Dargis in the New York Times compares Joss Whedon&#8217;s Serenity with George Lucas&#8217;s Star Wars: Episode III &#8212; Revenge of the Sith. Serenity comes out ahead. &#8220;Scene for scene,&#8221; she writes, &#8220;Serenity is more engaging and certainly better written and acted than any of Mr. Lucas&#8217;s recent screen entertainments. Mr. Whedon isn&#8217;t aiming to conquer the pop-culture universe with a branded mythology; he just wants us to hitch a ride to a galaxy far, far away and have a good time.&#8221; Jan Stuart in Newsday makes a similar comparison, remarking: &#8220;George Lucas could learn a thing or two from Whedon. Serenity flies with sass and spirit, qualities that have been in palpably short supply in that Star Wars series since, well, Star Wars.&#8221; Roger Ebert in the Chicago Sun-Times also indicates that he had a good time watching the movie, writing: &#8220;Serenity is made of dubious but energetic special effects, breathless velocity, much imagination, some sly verbal wit and a little political satire.&#8221; Elizabeth Weitzman in the New York Daily News notes that the movie appears to exist as a the final episode of Whedon&#8217;s canceled Firefly TV series and because the show&#8217;s fans &#8220;made the Firefly DVD set an unexpected best seller.&#8221; She adds: &#8220;Whedon&#8217;s sci-fi fantasies smartly parallel the serious issues we&#8217;re grappling with here on Earth, while his protagonists remain mordantly funny in the face of utter disaster. Like Star Trek before it, the outer-space setting is perfectly suited to a big budget&#8221; movie.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/122394.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/122394.html</a></em></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: ".Mac: as usual, fucked up"
url_title: mac_as_usual_fucked_up
permalink: mac_as_usual_fucked_up.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2005-09-25
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2014
---
<p>I was tricked (and by tricked, I mean they waited until I updated my credit card info to buy some music from the iTMS, and then renewed my account immediately) into renewing my almost never used .Mac account.  I kinda dug it when they were doing stuff like releasing free software to .Mac users, but lately the only cool stuff we got as members were bandwidth limitations.  Poor.</p>

<p>Anyway, after I got the renewal notice, I decided to check up on whether or not anything mildly cool happened with .Mac lately.  Coincidentally, I renewed exactly at the same time they upped the storage to 1GB, added the &#8220;Groups&#8221; features, and released Backup 3 (because who would need backup software if you didn&#8217;t have an iDisk?)</p>

<p>I actually haven&#8217;t tried either yet, because I don&#8217;t see much use for making a group only accessible to other .Mac users, and Backup 2 sucked so deeply and tightly that I throw up a little every time it&#8217;s mentioned.  I don&#8217;t get why Apple didn&#8217;t just pay <a href="http://www.dantz.com/">Dantz</a> for a &#8220;lite&#8221; version of Retrospect , because as ass-backwards as the UI was the last time I tried it, it at least seemed to function.</p>

<p>Anyway, not surprisingly, reports on MacInTouch are that shit&#8217;s wonky with the .Mac groups.  First off:</p>

<blockquote>So somebody who creates a free .Mac ID and lets the .Mac trial expire can continue to participate fully in a .Mac group, but a paying user of an email-only account cannnot. Something is wrong with this picture. </blockquote>

<p>Well, that&#8217;s not so much &#8220;wonky&#8221; as &#8220;par for the course.&#8221;  Anyway, here&#8217;s some more dumb crap:</p>

<blockquote>&#8230;my Dad saw the invitation, looked at the &#8220;sign up for a free .Mac trial&#8221; page it sent him to, and closed the browser. When we later figured out that this was the only way to join, and that it wouldn&#8217;t cost money (as we had initially thought), he started up Firefox, went to www.mac.com and created a trial account. Of course, this new account couldn&#8217;t join the group until I sent it an invitation. Whups! If you don&#8217;t create your new .Mac ID directly from the invitation email, it isn&#8217;t connected to the group.</blockquote>

<p>Truly, the masters of user experience.</p>

<p>As for crap that&#8217;s broken in Backup 3:</p>

<blockquote>I run Backup and select Restore and follow the appropriate prompts and insert the CD and the Restore job appears to run but it takes only about a third of a second and then declares it was &#8220;successful.&#8221; But there are no new files on the destination machine. I&#8217;ve tried restoring to the iTunes folder, and also restoring to an alternate location, same result. No error message, but nothing is restored, either.</blockquote>

<p>&#8230;and&#8230;</p>

<blockquote>I made a 10-disc CD backup of my iTunes library and tonight had to do a restore. The same thing happened to me as did to him: after following Backup&#8217;s procedure, it tells me I had a &#8220;successful&#8221; backup and nothings there.</blockquote>

<p>Man, that is awesome.  I feel better about my renewal already.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Windows Vista: The Final Countdown Begins"
url_title: windows_vista_the_final_countdown_begins
permalink: windows_vista_the_final_countdown_begins.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- OS X
date: 2005-09-24
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2012
---
<p>For utter shite in IT journalism, it&#8217;s hard to beat <a href="http://www.technewsworld.com/story/AViuO5r1twGnhR/Windows-Vista-The-Final-Countdown-Begins.xhtml">this turd</a> that escaped from the bowels of Rob Enderle.  Nothing annoys me more than clearly debatable points that are presented with no evidence, and Robbie&#8217;s article is filled with gems like this:</p>

<blockquote><b>IE improvements are broad and easily eclipse those by Firefox and Netscape</b>, but remember this is still beta code so these competitors do have time to respond. Web applications are now more effectively sand-boxed so they can&#8217;t do damage and IE extends tabs to include full preview windows. In addition, there has been a massive improvement in resistance to phishing which leads me to favor the Netscape browser for individuals. The new IE expands on the idea of tabs to provide real time views of the active pages.</blockquote>

<p>First off, I&#8217;d like to hear what improvements IE7 makes that &#8220;easily eclipse&#8221; those by Firefox and its brethren.  The ones I&#8217;ve heard about are things where IE7 is <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/07/29/445242.aspx">catching up</a> <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/04/26/412263.aspx">to Gecko&#8217;s rendering engine</a>, or adding features <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/09/14/466186.aspx"> that</a> <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/09/06/461675.aspx">have</a> <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/09/02/460115.aspx">been</a> in Firefox and/or related browsers <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/08/02/446280.aspx">for</a> <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/05/16/417732.aspx">quite some time</a>.  Now I&#8217;m not gonna deny that there is some cool work going on in IE7 in <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/09/20/471975.aspx">terms</a> of <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2005/09/09/463204.aspx">security</a>, but it&#8217;s interesting that much of capability is only available on Vista, because XP &mdash; even SP2 &mdash; is fundamentally flawed when it comes to user permissions.  IE7 will continue to be a successful attack vector with all pre-Vista versions of Windows, even assuming that protected mode is flawlessly implemented.  And it sure as hell isn&#8217;t the case that XP users will be falling over themselves to upgrade, let alone the numerous folks who are still running 2000 Pro (the folks who are running stuff from the Win95/98 codebase have been fucked for years, so there&#8217;s really no point talking about them, even though they still are a substantial percentage of Windows users).</p>

<p>One thing that looks interesting the <a href="http://www.ajaxian.com/archives/2005/09/microsoft_atlas_2.html">Atlas web app dev system</a>.  Basically it&#8217;s MS&#8217; Ajax library, and among other cool stuff can integrate with WPF/E, a portable subset of the new Vista UI layer.  When I say portable, I mean it, because at PDC they <a href="http://galbraiths.org/blog/?p=12">showed a demo of it running on a Mac in Safari</a>.  While the issue of a Firefox plugin hasn&#8217;t been addressed, it doesn&#8217;t sound like it would be to terribly difficult for a third party to do (at least on Windows).  So yeah, neat shit, but <b>it&#8217;s not specific to IE7</b>.</p>

<p>Robbie talks a lot about how Apple needs to take Vista seriously.  Yes, it does, for sure.  But Robbie seems to think Vista is a serious threat to Apple &mdash; as serious as Win95 was to the Apple of 1994:</p>

<blockquote>Apple will have to improve its game sharply to compete. However, given the strength at the back end, strength that Apple has never had, the exposure now goes well beyond Apple&#8217;s available resources. This means Apple will have to partner to avoid what may be the most damaging competitive threat the company has ever faced. While possible, Apple&#8217;s one prevailing weakness has been their inability to partner and unless that changes we should be able to call the outcome of this competition relatively easily &#8212; and it isn&#8217;t positive for Apple.</blockquote>

<p>I call bullshit on that, though, because of something Rob points out:</p>

<blockquote>Apple is again growing with the market and, unlike 1994, is dominant in an emerging market &#8212; digital music players.</blockquote>

<p>Mac fans don&#8217;t really like admitting this, but the <b>only</b> reason Apple is totally kicking ass lately is because of the iPod.  Apple is in an enviable position as the clear leader in the market with few companies with the resources <i>and</i> expertise necessary to mount a real attack against them.  It&#8217;s a huge, publicly prominent position.</p>

<p>What this means is that, for the moment, Apple&#8217;s computer sales are kinda gravy.  It doesn&#8217;t matter if they only have 3% of the market, because their massive media influence gives that 3% a lot more sway.  So even if Vista steals a couple tenths of a percentage point from the Mac market, <i>it doesn&#8217;t matter</i>.  Apple doesn&#8217;t need them to <i>thrive</i>, let alone survive.</p>

<p>Plus, Rob doesn&#8217;t even <i>mention</i> Google, the company that MS is surely most worried about right now.  For an article dealing with how Vista and Office 12 position the company against all of its competitors, ignoring the big G is ridiculous.</p>

author: funkatron
title: "Microsoft Changes How It Builds Software"
url_title: microsoft_changes_how_it_builds_software
permalink: microsoft_changes_how_it_builds_software.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Development
- InfoSec
date: 2005-09-24
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2011
---
<p><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/allchin-comic.gif" border="0" height="250" width="200" alt="allchin-comic.gif" align="right" /><a href="http://online.wsj.com/article/0,,SB112743680328349448,00.html?mod=todays_us_page_one">WSJ.com - Battling Google, Microsoft Changes How It Builds Software</a>:</p>

<blockquote>The news got even worse: Longhorn was irredeemable because Microsoft engineers were building it just as they had always built software. Throughout its history, Microsoft had let thousands of programmers each produce their own piece of computer code, then stitched it together into one sprawling program. Now, Mr. Allchin argued, the jig was up. Microsoft needed to start over.</blockquote>

<p>This was a pretty interesting article, and I imagine a more detailed examination of the change in software practices would be pretty interesting.  It&#8217;s easy to hate the Microsoft, but competition is a good thing, kids, and MS getting better at what they do will push Apple/Google/et al to push back harder.</p>

<p>(Via <a href="http://slashdot.org/">Slashdot</a>.)</p>

author: funkatron
title: "Bad Behavior"
url_title: bad_behavior
permalink: bad_behavior.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2005-09-24
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2010
---
<p>I&#8217;ve been getting a lot of comment spam lately, so I&#8217;ve installed <a href="http://www.ioerror.us/software/bad-behavior/">Bad Behavior</a>, which takes a different approach to spam blocking:</p>

<blockquote>Bad Behavior was designed and built by watching actual spambots which harvested email addresses, posted comment spam, and used fake referrers. By logging their entire HTTP requests and comparing them to HTTP requests of legitimate users, it is possible to detect most spambots.</blockquote>

<p>Let me know if you have any problems.  I&#8217;ll post some impressions after I&#8217;ve used it a bit.</p>

<blockquote>Portage Assistant Fire Chief Bill Lundy explains, &#8220;Our job was to advertise a phone number for FEMA. <p><a href="http://www.govexec.com/dailyfed/1104/110304cm1.htm">www.GovExec.com - How FEMA delivered Florida for Bush (11/3/04)</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>In 2004, George W. Bush and FEMA left little room for error. Not long after Hurricane Charley first made landfall on Aug. 13, Bush declared the state a federal disaster area to release federal relief funds. Less than two days after Charley ripped through southwestern Florida, he was on the ground touring hard-hit neighborhoods.<br /><br />Bush later made a handful of other Florida visits to review storm-related damage, but the story on the ground was not Bush&#8217;s hand-holding. Rather, it was FEMA&#8217;s performance.<br /><br />Charley hit on a Friday. With emergency supply trucks pre-positioned at depots for rapid, post-storm deployment, the agency was able to deliver seven truckloads of ice, water, cots, blankets, baby food and building supplies by Sunday. On Monday, hundreds of federal housing inspectors were on the ground, and FEMA already had opened its first one-stop disaster relief center.</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "The Buck Stops Here"
url_title: the_buck_stops_here
permalink: the_buck_stops_here.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-09-07
summary: 
old_entry_id: 2002
---
<p><strong><a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2005/9/5/225729/7487">Daily Kos: The Buck Stops Here</a></strong><br /><br />Please read the whole thing.  I&#8217;ve taken choice bits, but the explanations are critical to understanding the failure of the executive branch.<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Below, I&#8217;ve excerpted critical parts of the <a href="http://www.dhs.gov/dhspublic/interapp/editorial/editorial_0566.xml">United States National Response Plan</a>, as published in December 2004</blockquote>

<p><br /><br />[&#8230;]<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>First and foremost, let me stress that this document is essentially a contract with American citizens.  &#8220;By signing this letter of agreement, Federal departments and agencies&#8221; commit to implementing the plan.  It is signed by Donald Rumsfeld, Tom Ridge, Tommy Thompson, Porter Gross, John Ashcroft, Colin Powell, Robert Mueller, Michael Powell, and several others.  THIS is the real &#8220;Contract With America.&#8221;  It is the Federal Government&#8217;s promise that it will execute the National Response Plan properly. </blockquote>

<p><br /><br />[&#8230;]<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>While the state and local officials then still have to try and implement their plans and coordinate with the feds, it is crystal clear that the NRP recognizes that when, say, a hurricane comes and wipes your city off the map, <strong>it is the President and his administration which MUST respond proactively.</strong></blockquote>

<p><br /><br />[&#8230;]<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Again, for three days before the hurricane hit, President Bush had the authority to direct Rumsfeld to deploy troops.  <strong>Under the NRP, a formal request by the Governor is not necessary in these conditions.</strong>  For three days before Katrina hit, and for FIVE Days afterwards, the President always had the authority to send in thousands of troops.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br />[&#8230;]<br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Under that section, the plan provides that:<br /><blockquote>&#8221;<strong>Standard procedures regarding requests for assistance</strong> may be expedited, or under extreme circumstances, <strong>suspended</strong> in the immediate aftermath of an event of catastrophic magnitude.&#8221; (NRP, 44)</blockquote><br />Yes, you read that right.  This theory that the Federal Government has to sit on its ass and WAIT for Governors and Mayors to tearfully beg for assistance and issue S.O.S is pure fiction.  The government has signed off on a promise to be PROACTIVE<br /><br />And what does the plan include under the federal proactive response to a catastrophic event? <strong>The &#8220;pre-identification of Federal assets and capabilities&#8221; and the &#8220;strategic location of pre-identified assets for rapid deployment&#8221;</strong> (NRP, 44).</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/119109.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/119109.html</a></em></p>

<p>Thank you, Keith Olbermann, for reminding the nation of what this administration has tried so hard to make us forget: that the buck stops with them.<br /><br /><a href="http://media.putfile.com/OlbermannSwings">http://media.putfile.com/OlbermannSwings</a><br /><br />(thanks <span class='ljuser' style='white-space: nowrap;'><a href='http://www.livejournal.com/userinfo.bml?user=josienutter'><img src='http://stat.livejournal.com/img/userinfo.gif' alt='[info]' width='17' height='17' style='vertical-align: bottom; border: 0;' /></a><a href='http://www.livejournal.com/users/josienutter/'><b>josienutter</b></a></span>)<br /><br />That is the black, poison heart of my disgust with George W Bush, his administration, and his kind: their unwillingness to ever admit fault.  Cowards bask in the glory of their achievements, and find others to blame for their failures.  Honorable men understand that with success comes failure, and accept their role in either with measured response.<br /><br />The halls of government in Washington are infested with cowards, even at the desk of the Oval Office.<br /><br />I don&#8217;t give a damn if our next president is republican, democrat, liberal, conservative, or anything in-between.  I just pray to God that he is an honorable man, because our country has never needed one more.<br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/118841.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/118841.html</a></em></p>

<blockquote>&#8220;In the event of a terrorist attack, natural disaster or other large-scale emergency, the Department of Homeland Security will assume primary responsibility on March 1st for ensuring that emergency response professionals are prepared for any situation. <blockquote><em>Robinette asked the mayor about his conversation with President Bush:</em><br /><br />NAGIN: I told him we had an incredible crisis here and that his flying over in Air Force One does not do it justice. And that I have been all around this city, and I am very frustrated because we are not able to marshal resources and we&#8217;re outmanned in just about every respect.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>WL: Do you believe that the president is seeing this, holding a news conference on it but can&#8217;t do anything until [Louisiana Gov.] Kathleen Blanco requested him to do it? And do you know whether or not she has made that request?<br /><br />NAGIN: I have no idea what they&#8217;re doing. But I will tell you this: You know, <strong>God is looking down on all this, and if they are not doing everything in their power to save people, they are going to pay the price</strong>. Because every day that we delay, people are dying and they&#8217;re dying by the hundreds, I&#8217;m willing to bet you. </blockquote>

<p><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>NAGIN: Well, did the tsunami victims request? Did it go through a formal process to request?<br /><br />You know, did the Iraqi people request that we go in there? Did they ask us to go in there? What is more important?<br /><br />And I&#8217;ll tell you, man, I&#8217;m probably going get in a whole bunch of trouble. I&#8217;m probably going to get in so much trouble it ain&#8217;t even funny. You probably won&#8217;t even want to deal with me after this interview is over.<br /><br />WWL: You and I will be in the funny place together.<br /><br />NAGIN: But we authorized $8 billion to go to Iraq lickety-quick. After 9/11, we gave the president unprecedented powers lickety-quick to take care of New York and other places. </blockquote>

<p><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Don&#8217;t tell me 40,000 people are coming here. They&#8217;re not here. It&#8217;s too doggone late. Now get off your asses and do something, and let&#8217;s fix the biggest goddamn crisis in the history of this country.</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Interview with John Gruber"
url_title: interview_with_john_gruber
permalink: interview_with_john_gruber.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Design
- OS X
date: 2005-08-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1982
---
<p>The interview deals specifically with Gruber&#8217;s opinions on the OS X GUI.  Interesting stuff, esp. some of the info about the original Aqua demos.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.guidebookgallery.org/articles/interviewwithjohngruber">GUIdebook > Articles > Interview with John Gruber</a>:</p>

<blockquote>I believe Jobs is mostly responsible for Apple&rsquo;s almost-entirely-arbitrary use of brushed metal windows. E.g. the decision to use brushed metal in Safari. I could be wrong &#8211; I have no sources or evidence to back that up. But my thinking is that Jobs sees the &ldquo;consistency,&rdquo; so to say, as stemming from his own aesthetic judgement. That&rsquo;s Jobs&rsquo;s gift: his taste, and his ability to motivate teams to meet his standards. So if he feels in his gut that, for example, Safari looks better with brushed metal windows, then he knows he&rsquo;s right, and that&rsquo;s the end of the debate. It doesn&rsquo;t matter if the answer contradicts the Mac OS X Human Interface Guidelines.</blockquote>

<p>(Via <a href="http://ranchero.com/">Ranchero.com</a>.)</p>

<blockquote>Under this scenario, Microsoft pays an engineering fee that is lucrative for both ATI and IBM, but it doesn&#8217;t have to pay high margins to ATI or IBM for making the chips, and it can go directly to a chip contract manufacturer. The goal is to cut costs and to control its destiny. After all, Microsoft remembers it lost $125 on each of the first Xbox machines sold, and it got into a dispute with Nvidia over chip pricing to boot</blockquote>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Update on ATOM support in RSS Viewer for Konfabulator"
url_title: update_on_atom_support_in_rss_viewer_for_konfabulator
permalink: update_on_atom_support_in_rss_viewer_for_konfabulator.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- My Projects
- The Web Problem
- Design
- OS X
- Widgets
date: 2005-07-29
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1971
---
<p>Okay, it looks like <a href="http://www.jeremie.com/Dev/XML/">the parser I am using now</a> just won&#8217;t work &#8212; it doesn&#8217;t appear to retrieve XML node attributes properly, and ATOM feeds seem to use <code>href</code> attributes in their <code>&lt;link&gt;</code> tags  to link to stuff, as opposed to RSS/RDF which uses the contents of the tag.  So I&#8217;m switching to <a href="http://www.gazingus.org/html/XML_Parser_in_JavaScript.html">this much newer and better XML Parser for Javascript</a>, which closely follows the <a href="http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/org/w3c/dom/package-summary.html">org.w3c.dom</a> parser classes in Java.  It means I&#8217;ll have to rewrite the feed parsing, but that&#8217;s really not a huge deal.</p>

url_title: yahoo_acquires_konfabulator_gives_it_away_refunds_paid_customers
permalink: yahoo_acquires_konfabulator_gives_it_away_refunds_paid_customers.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- The Web Problem

- Widgets
date: 2005-07-25
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1965
---
<p>This is really kickass.  I&#8217;m running it on my Windows desktop as we speak, and will probably be putting it on my iBook as well.  I&#8217;m even motivated to fix the compatibility issues in my old RSS Viewer widget that I wrote a couple years back.</p>

<p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/mc/20050725/tc_mc/yahooacquireskonfabulator">Yahoo! acquires Konfabulator - Yahoo! News</a>:</p>

<blockquote>Yahoo! Inc (YHOO.O). on Monday will announce the acquisition of Konfabulator, a Macintosh and Windows application that allows users to run mini files known as Widgets on their desktop &#8212; the same model used by Apple for its Dashboard application. Yahoo! company executives said they would also be giving Konfabulator away for free, completely doing away with the US$19.95 currently charged for the product.</blockquote>

<p>(Via <a href="http://news.yahoo.com/">Yahoo! News</a>.)</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "&#8220;42 percent said they would favor impeachment proceedings&#8230;&#8221;"
url_title: 42_percent_said_they_would_favor_impeachment_proceedings
permalink: 42_percent_said_they_would_favor_impeachment_proceedings.html

<p><a href="http://blog.workhabit.com/?p=68">workhabit: blog &raquo; Blog Archive &raquo; Bryan Buchs has been building web sites for 11 years&#8230;</a>:</p>

<blockquote>I was amused this mornin&rsquo; by Bryan Buchs claim that he has been building websites for about 11 years.

The World Wide Web was released by CERN in 1991. In 1992, surfing the Internet was invented. 1993 Internic comes to life, later to become a royal pain, and we see the first WWW Worm, Spiders, etc. The first Internet Talk Radio. Mosiac. 1994 WWW edged out everybody&rsquo;s favorite service, Telnet, to become the 2nd most popular service on the Net (still lagging ftp). Now, for this guy to make this claim, he would have had to have been building websites commercially in 1994.</blockquote>

<p>A longish post, but really worth reading.  It mirrors my experience very closely (except I started getting paid for it in 97, so Jonathan has a year of old-skool cred on me. 8)</p>

<p>(Via <a href="http://blog.workhabit.com">workhabit: blog</a>.)</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "A very annoying Wordpress bug, and a fix"
url_title: a_very_annoying_wordpress_bug_and_a_fix
permalink: a_very_annoying_wordpress_bug_and_a_fix.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- The Web Problem
- PHP
date: 2005-06-29
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1945
---
<p><a href="http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/1355">#1355 (General category always assigned) - WordPress Trac - Trac</a></p>

<p>So basically, whenever you post with an external client, no matter what categories you select, your default category is ALSO assigned.  This is particularly annoying when you use your category in your nicely formatted URLs, because the default cat is often the one that gets used (I guess because it&#8217;s the first one encountered in the DB query), and pings sent out when you post will reference and URL with the default cat in it.  Removing the default cat from that post will then result in &#8220;not found&#8221; errors.</p>

<p>This problem was <a href="http://wordpress.org/support/topic/9698">first reported in April</a>.  I&#8217;m kind of bummed that a couple releases have gone by with no one taking a couple minutes to patch the code.  For now, I&#8217;m doing it manually, but if another release comes out without it and I have to do some diff/patching shit, I&#8217;ll be very annoyed.</p>

<p>Rarr!</p>

<p><b>Update:</b> The patching directions in the forum thread are a little misleading, as the new 1.5.1.3 version of xmlrpc.php has changed a lot, so line numbers are quite different.  Here&#8217;s what I did to get it working.</p>

<p>Old:</p>

<blockquote><pre>
620   } else {
621     $post_category[] = $post_default_category;
622   }
</pre></blockquote>

<p>New:</p>

<blockquote><pre>
620   } elseif (!$post_category) {
621     $post_category[] = $post_default_category;
622   }
</pre></blockquote>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "WordPress 1.5.1.3 Available"
url_title: wordpress_1513_available
permalink: wordpress_1513_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2005-06-29
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1944
---
<p><a href="http://wordpress.org/development/2005/06/wordpress-1513/">WordPress 1.5.1.3 Available</a>:</p>

<blockquote>&#8230;an important security issue was brought to our attention which required an update for our users. The problem is not yet public but you should update your blog as soon as possible to 1.5.1.3. If you are unable to do upgrade in the short-term you may protect yourself by deleting the xmlrpc.php file from your WordPress directory.</blockquote>

<p>Obviously if you use the XML-RPC interface (for posting from client apps and external services like <a href="http://www.flickr.com">flickr</a>), deleting the xmlrpc.php file is gonna be less than appealing.</p>

<ul><li><a href="http://wordpress.org/download/">Get WP 1.5.1.3</a></li></ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "PHP 5.1&#8217;s Killer Feature?"
url_title: php_51s_killer_feature
permalink: php_51s_killer_feature.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- PHP
date: 2005-06-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1939
---
<p><a href="http://www.sitepoint.com/blog-post-view.php?id=274359">PHP 5.1&#8217;s Killer Feature? - SitePoint PHP Blog</a>:</p>

<blockquote>At this stage, PHP 5.1 is not looking to be quite as spectacular. Some enhancements to Perl regular expressions, a few extra array functions&#8230; nothing to write home about. But there is one significant enhancement to PHP in 5.1: PHP Data Objects (PDO).

The PDO library lets you access any of an extensive selection of supported databases using a signle set of functions. So not only do you only need to learn one set of functions to write for multiple databases, but you can transition an application to another database without having to change all the functions throughout your code.</blockquote>

<p>(Via <a href="http://www.sitepoint.com">Sitepoint</a>.)</p>

<p>Not a ton of detail about PDO, but I&#8217;m curious to check it out.  I&#8217;ve bought heavily into PEAR DB_DataObject on most of my apps from the past year, so I&#8217;ll be interested to see how PDO compares in terms of rapid app dev (the main reason I&#8217;ve used DB_DataObjects).</p>

<p>Check out Wez Furlong&#8217;s blog for <a href="http://netevil.org/node.php?nid=186">more info on PDO</a>.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.akbkhome.com/">Alan Knowles</a> is working on <a href="http://pecl.php.net/package/DBDO">DBDO</a>, what appears to basically be an implementation of DB_DataObject as a PECL extension &#8212; sensible, since he&#8217;s lead on DB_DataObject as well.  It&#8217;s currently quite alpha, but I hope that Alan is able to continue work on this and get it closer to a usable state.</p>

- General
- PHP
date: 2005-06-20

---
<p>This was an interesting article on recursive programming.  I do it infrequently enough that I have to try and remember how to properly structure recursive functions whenever I write one, and this gave me a few basic things to remember that will make it easier next time around.</p>

<p><a href="http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/linux/library/l-recurs.html?ca=dgr-lnxw07Recursion">Mastering recursive programming</a>:</p>

<blockquote>Recursion is a tool not often used by imperative language developers, because it is thought to be slow and to waste space, but as the author demonstrates, there are several techniques that can be used to minimize or eliminate these problems. He introduces the concept of recursion and tackle recursive programming patterns, examining how they can be used to write provably correct programs. Examples are in Scheme and C.</blockquote>
