---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Protect your applications <em>without recoding them???</em>"
url_title: protect_your_applications_without_recoding_them
permalink: protect_your_applications_without_recoding_them.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
date: 2005-06-13
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1933
---
<p><a href="http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2005/06/09/wss_security.html">ONLamp.com: Securing Web Services with mod_security</a></p>

<p>On the front page of <a href="http://onlamp.com">ONLamp.com</a>, this article has the tag line &#8220;Protect your applications without recoding them.&#8221;  In principle and practice, I <strong>strongly</strong> disagree with this statement.</p>

<p>I love <a href="http://www.modsecurity.org/">mod_security</a>.  It&#8217;s a fabulous tool.  But it should <em>never</em> be used as your only line of defense against malicious input. It&#8217;s a bad, bad, bad idea to put all your security eggs in one basket, simply because if we&#8217;ve learned anything in the past 50 years of computing, it&#8217;s that <em>everything</em> is flawed, and people can <em>and will</em> find and exploit that flaw.</p>

<p>Proper security is a multilayered, multi-approach thing.  And I think the author is doing a real disservice to those who are trying to educate the development community about secure practices with statements like:</p>

<blockquote>Solutions can take many different forms, ranging from secure coding practices to proper input validation. One approach is to perform content validation for each incoming request and compare it with predefined rules.</blockquote>

<p>No, no, no!  Solutions (plural) is just plain wrong.  The <strong>solution</strong> (singular) is to implement <em>all</em> of these approaches.  To not do so is either naive (if you&#8217;re relying on something someone else developed), arrogant (if you&#8217;re relying on something you developed), and in either case <em>very</em> dangerous.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="1933" data-url-title="protect_your_applications_without_recoding_them">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1659" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Ben Ramsey</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://benramsey.com</div>
		<div class="comment-date">06/13/2005 11:11:36 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>I&#8217;ve spoken about mod_security in a couple of PHP talks now, and everytime I mention it, I always make it a point to say that it provides a great stopgap to plug up security holes in your existing applications at the Web server level but that this doesn&#8217;t mean you shouldn&#8217;t get rid of those those holes by making the time to find them and recode accordingly.</p>

<h2>So, I agree with you here.</h2>
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>
</div>
<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Game developers react to Intel news"
url_title: game_developers_react_to_intel_news
permalink: game_developers_react_to_intel_news.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
- OS X
date: 2005-06-07
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1931
---
<p>One aspect that&#8217;s not been brought up much in the flurry of excitement over Apple&#8217;s transition to x86 has been the potential impact on the OS X gaming market.  This article on Macworld.com is quite interesting, demonstrating a wide-range of reactions from Mac game devs.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.macworld.com/news/2005/06/07/gamedev/index.php?lsrc=mwrss">Macworld: News: WWDC: Game developers react to Intel news</a>:</p>

<p>First, the optimistic view:</p>

<blockquote>Destineer and MacSoft president Peter Tamte calls Apple&rsquo;s decision to switch to an Intel-based architecture &ldquo;an aggressive move&rdquo; to grow the size of the Macintosh&rsquo;s market. &ldquo;The switch to Intel should also help us narrow the gap between a game&rsquo;s release on Windows and release on Mac.&rdquo;

Aspyr Media director of development Glenda Adams hopes Apple can &ldquo;explode their marketshare&rdquo; with a move to competitively-priced Intel-based hardware. &ldquo;If OS X has a 20 percent market share the revenue possibilities for native games could make things a lot different.&rdquo;</blockquote>

<p>On the other hand, will the potential for dual-booting Windows and OS X on the same box &#8212; or a relatively lightweight system call translator like WINE &#8212; eliminate any demand for OS X-native ports of popular titles?</p>

<blockquote>If that&rsquo;s the case, it&rsquo;s conceivable that serious Mac gamers could create a dual-boot system that would allow them to run Windows versions of games. That could decimate the Mac game business, which is dependent on conversions of PC and console games that take months to release after their original counterparts.

[&#8230;]

&ldquo;Will people dual boot? Will they still prefer a native port, even if they can run Windows? What about a Windows emulation layer like Linux&rsquo;s WINE project &#8230; would that kill native game ports?&rdquo; Gordon asked.

&ldquo;In the end, at least we&rsquo;re going to find out whether it was Linux that made Linux gamers a hard market or Mac OS that made Mac gamers into discerning customers,&rdquo; Gordon told MacCentral.</blockquote>

<p>Linux, of course, being the closest competitor so far in the x86 desktop market, is really the only thing we can look to for some notion of how this might pan out.  I think they sold about 12 copies of Quake II for Linux.  On the other hand, given the facts that:</p>

<ol><li>Linux users aren&#8217;t terribly used to paying for software</li><li>Linux users tend to be savvy nerdo types who would are comfortable dual-booting their systems so they can play Windows games</li></ol>

<p>the Mac x86 gaming market seems unlikely to parallel Linux&#8217;s.</p>

<blockquote>
Aspyr&rsquo;s Adams believes that the switch to Intel may have &ldquo;a negligible change&rdquo; on sales of Mac games, at least to start. While she agrees that a dual-boot Mac might cause hardcore gamers to simply buy Windows and Windows games, she doesn&rsquo;t think that &ldquo;normal&rdquo; Mac users will want to jump through hoops. &ldquo;So the net effect may be a shift in products, but revenue may stay about the same overall,&rdquo; said Adams.
</blockquote>

<p>I tend to agree with this.  Typical Mac users don&#8217;t want to jump through a bunch of hoops to get stuff working (that&#8217;s why they don&#8217;t use Linux).</p>

<p>Brian Greenstone from Pangea is far more pessimistic about the move from PPC to x86 for game devs than The Steve:</p>

<blockquote>&ldquo;This is far, far worse than the switch from 68000 to PowerPC ten years ago,&rdquo; said Greenstone. &ldquo;That was essentially just a recompile. This require a complete recode of data handling.&rdquo;

That opinion is shared by Brad Oliver, who works with Glenda Adams at Aspyr Studios, Aspyr&rsquo;s internal game development house. &ldquo;Byte-swapping bugs are a pain to track down,&rdquo; Oliver told MacCentral.</blockquote>

<p>Greenstone adds that Rosetta, the PPC emu layer for x86, will be almost entirely useless for games, as Altivec code cannot be emulated.  Games are certainly some of the apps most likely to have utilized vector optimizations.</p>

<blockquote>Pangea&rsquo;s Greenstone expects that what&rsquo;s inside a computer will ultimately become less important to even technically-savvy customers than what the computer can do. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s going to be about internet bandwidth and how I can get more data faster,&rdquo; he said.</blockquote>

<p>I think that&#8217;s something that those lamenting this transition might do well to keep in mind.  PPC has done little to set apart the Mac platform in the past 5 years, at least in a positive way.  OS X, and Apple&#8217;s ability to integrate their software with their hardware (no matter what CPU it uses), is the key to the Mac&#8217;s appeal.</p>

<p>(Via <a href="http://www.macworld.com/">Macworld</a>.)</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "No Altivec Emulation in Rosetta"
url_title: no_altivec_emulation_in_rosetta
permalink: no_altivec_emulation_in_rosetta.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2005-06-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1926
---
<p><a href="http://developer.apple.com/documentation/MacOSX/Conceptual/universal_binary/universal_binary.pdf">Universal Binary Programming Guidelines</a>:</p>

<blockquote>Rosetta is designed to translate currently shipping applications that run on a PowerPC with a G3 processor and that are built for Mac OS X. Rosetta does not run the following:

<ul><li>Applications built for Mac OS 8 or 9</li>
<li>Code written specifically for AltiVec</li>
<li>Code that inserts preferences in the System Preferences pane</li>
<li>Applications that require a G4 or G5 processor</li>
<li>Applications that depend on one or more kernel extensions</li>
<li>Kernel extensions</li>
<li>Bundled Java applications</li></ul></blockquote>

<p>(Via <a href="http://www.macintouch.com/">Macintouch</a>.)</p>

<p>I suppose this isn&#8217;t surprising, but not emulating Altivec code puts a bit of a damper on things. Running slow is one thing &#8212; not running at all is entirely another.  On the other hand, what <i>major</i> apps exist that are not either made by Apple or one of the big 3rd parties that will definitely transition their code (or have existing Windows versions that contain vectorized equivalents for x86 processors)?  I can&#8217;t think of any offhand, but I might be missing something.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Macromedia unveils Flash Platform"
url_title: macromedia_unveils_flash_platform
permalink: macromedia_unveils_flash_platform.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- The Web Problem
date: 2005-06-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1924
---
<p><a href="http://www.macworld.com/news/2005/06/06/flash/index.php?lsrc=mwrss">Macworld: News: Macromedia unveils Flash Platform</a>:
<blockquote>San Francisco-based Macromedia Inc. on Monday unveiled the Flash Platform, a complete system that includes everything you need to deliver rich content, according to the company. Macromedia is also previewing the next generation Flash Player, which the company says will dramatically improve Flash&rsquo;s performance.</blockquote>

Blah blah blah Flash works on 98% of internet-enabled devices blah blah blah&#8230;

<blockquote>In addition to improving Flash&rsquo;s performance the new Flash player, code-named Maelstrom, will include a new video codec provided by On2 and will be embedded in Flash, according to Whatcott. A beta will be released to the public later this year.</blockquote>

<img src="http://www.funkatron.com/wp/wp-content/nec-legendaryaxe-thumb.jpg" class="alignright" />Wow, that&#8217;s a really bad name.  It reminds me of those fruity-ass retail boxes you used to see for 3dfx cards.  They&#8217;d have some kid with a flight stick in his hand with his hair getting blown back like in the old Memorex ads, with lots of purple and green lighting.  In some crazy jagged fonts it would say &#8220;TAKE YOUR PC TO THE RADICAL EXTREME!!!!!!!!!oneoneone,&#8221; and the kid&#8217;s eyes would be shooting fire or lightning or whatever.  Just looking at them made me really embarassed.  I couldn&#8217;t find a good picture of one in Google Image Search, though, so I&#8217;ll show you the picture of the Legendary Axe cover art that showed up instead. 

Now on to the only thing that&#8217;s actually interesting:

<blockquote>Macromedia also said it planned to join the Eclipse Foundation to develop a new industry-leading IDE based on Eclipse for building rich Internet applications that run on the Flash Platform.

&lsquo;We intend to ship a rich Internet authoring tool that we believe will be the way to build rich Internet media in the future. We believe building on Eclipse is the way to go.&rsquo;</blockquote>

Last time around, Macromedia put out &#8220;Flash Professional&#8221; and claimed it was an IDE for developing &#8220;rich&#8221; web apps.  Sorry, no &#8212; it still felt like it wanted me to make an episode of Strongbad.  What I wanted was something like OS X&#8217;s Interface Builder or RealBasic&#8217;s IDE.  Flash Pro was a far cry from either.

The announcement of what sounds like an entirely new IDE for app dev makes me think that Macromedia has finally realized that creating gay-ass animations and creating rich web apps require an <i>entirely</i> different development approach.  I don&#8217;t really recall Eclipse having much in terms of visual tools for interface building, but presumably Macromedia can just write that shit and let the Eclipse platform handle the code side of things.</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Macworld: News: Intel&#8217;s Chandrasekher talks Apple"
url_title: macworld_news_intels_chandrasekher_talks_apple
permalink: macworld_news_intels_chandrasekher_talks_apple.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- Gaming
- OS X
date: 2005-06-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1923
---
<p><a href="http://www.macworld.com/news/2005/06/05/chandrasekher/index.php?lsrc=mwrss">Macworld: News: Intel&#8217;s Chandrasekher talks Apple</a>:</p>

<blockquote>&#8220;IDGNS: The Wall Street Journal recently reported that Intel has been trying to get Apple to use its processors. Has Intel been talking with Apple?

Chandrasekher: We always talk to Apple. Apple is a design win that we&rsquo;ve coveted for 20 years and we continue to covet them as a design win. We will never give up on Apple.

IDGNS: What would you be willing to do in order to win Apple&rsquo;s business?

Chandrasekher: Well, nothing unnatural that we wouldn&rsquo;t do for other design wins. It&rsquo;s got to make sense from a business standpoint. We would do what makes economic sense. If we can do that and still get the design win, we&rsquo;d do it.&#8221;</blockquote>

<p>Also discussed is Intel&#8217;s apparent shutout in console CPU wins:</p>

<blockquote>We are not averse to getting a design win in the console space. What we are averse to is getting a design win at an unprofitable price point. If IBM wants to sell the Power PC processor below their cost, they can have that business. We had an opportunity to go bid on it. We did bid on it, but we didn&rsquo;t think it was worth getting that business if it was going to be unprofitable for us, so we backed away. I don&rsquo;t think it hurts us.</blockquote>

<p>And since component providers typically aren&#8217;t huge winners in the console market, you have to wonder if this will be a big payoff for IBM.  On the other hand:</p>

<blockquote>Out of three players, two weren&rsquo;t ever on IA [Intel architecture] and one was on IA and has moved. So, big deal. If you look at the console business overall it&rsquo;s predominantly a replacement market, not a growing market. And if you look at where the excitement is in terms of gaming, it&rsquo;s in online gaming. If you look at online gaming, where is most of the online gaming happening? It&rsquo;s happening on the PC.</blockquote>

<p>Not for long.  The last generation dipped its toes in the water of online gaming, and XBox Live demonstrated what it could be.  This gen of consoles will dive into the online pool once and for all, and the sheer numbers will overwhelm PC-based online gaming.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Fabulous Xbox 360 vs PS3 commentary"
url_title: fabulous_xbox_360_vs_ps3_commentary
permalink: fabulous_xbox_360_vs_ps3_commentary.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-05-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1909
---
<p>from <a href="http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/games/archives/2005/05/18/ps3_and_360_battle_it_out_in_the_specs_department_what_in_the_world_do_they_mean.html">http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/games/</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>I think you are all neiggarz. No one can predict what console will come out on top, becouse it is purelly based on consumer behavior. If anyone can nostradamus this BS, then I have a job for you finding Osama. The consumers might respond to the earlier released console, or just to the most stylish, or cheaper, or most powerful, or most hyped, or who fukn knows&#8230; get the point? One thing is true, the world is a big market enough that there is every flavor of consumer out there. And these niche markets are big enough to support all three competing consoles. Just like in the present. That&#8217;s what will probably happen, all three consoles living together having preety much the same games, and with preety much the same market shares as today. No winners, no loosers. Just big boys and smaller ones. In the future there might be market consolidation (merging between companies, probably Nintendo & MS if Sony comes on top again) to challenge the big player. In this case my friends, we all loose. Less competition = less innovations = higher prices.<br /><br />I typed this in a Pocket PC so you can go f&#8230; yourself about grammar&#8230;<br />Posted by fanboy killa on May 18, 2005 06:28 PM.<br />Offensive? Unsuitable? Report this comment. </blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/100910.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/100910.html</a></em></p>

<p><a href="http://nwanews.com/story.php?paper=nwat&amp;section=News&amp;storyid=28036">From http://nwanews.com/</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>Calvin Milo Alvarez, 30, of 2974 N. Gregg Ave., Fayetteville, was arrested Monday on a charge of distribution/possessing/viewing sexually explicit matter involving a child.<br /><br />Last Wednesday, Officer Chris Denton and Officer Scott Carlton responded to a call from residents of Appleby Apartments at 2974 N. Gregg Ave., according to the police report, and when they arrived, they found Alvarez dressed in a baby diaper and another male subject verbally arguing. The suspect’s computer reportedly was at the bottom of the stairs and he was bleeding from the mouth. Both men had been drinking, police said, and the second man told officers that he had walked in on the suspect, a roommate, and found him viewing child pornography on his computer, according to the police report.<br /><br />Officers reportedly seized the computer, believing it to contain child pornography and submitted it to evidence.<br /><br />On Thursday, Alvarez reportedly came to the police department to talk to Det. Mike Parks about the computer and its contents. During the interview, Parks reported, Alvarez admitted to possessing approximately 500 sexually explicit images of children.<br /><br />On Friday, a search warrant was obtained authorizing the search of the seized computer by the initial responding officers, the police reported stated, and an image of the suspect’s hard drive was obtained by a trained computer forensic examiner using special software and hardware that prevent alteration of the hard drive contents.<br /><br />A preliminary exam of the contents of the drive reportedly revealed approximately 9,000 images depicting children from ages 1 to 12 years old. Alvarez fled police on foot when they attempted to arrest him at his place of employment. He was later located at his mother’s home and was taken into custody, Parks said, adding that the identities of the children depicted are unknown and the investigation is continuing. Pair arrested on drug charge.</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/99427.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/99427.html</a></em></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Marry Me Mini"
url_title: marry_me_mini
permalink: marry_me_mini.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-05-09
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1906
---
<p>Griffin and I took our weekly trip to best buy on Saturday to do a little window shopping.  One of the things that usually catches my eye is the single Mac Mini that they have sitting out amongst the laptops.  I can&#8217;t really say that this would be an extremely <em>useful</em> purchase, but boy, it sure is tiny and cute!<br /><br />I was even further tempted by the sign that was up:<br /></p>

<blockquote>All computers: 0% interest for 12 months</blockquote>

<p><br />Well shit, that&#8217;s less than $50 a month for a Mini.  Swank.<br /><br />So I inquire about whether than deal covers the Mac Mini.  See, Apple likes to not let dealers cut financing deals and such, because hey, that would sell too many Macs.  Homeboy helper dude isn&#8217;t sure, so he goes and checks.  Sure enough, no deal.<br /><br />Oh well.<br /><br />From this, I make a couple conclusions:<br /></p>

<ul><li>Best Buy doesn&#8217;t consider the Mac Mini a &#8220;computer&#8221;</li><li>Apple doesn&#8217;t want me to think of the Mac Mini as a commodity computer.  Even though it is</li></ul>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/99097.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/99097.html</a></em></p>

---
<p>How the <strong>FUCK</strong> did I miss this story?<br /><br /><a href="http://www.adobe.com/aboutadobe/invrelations/adobeandmacromedia.html">Adobe to acquire Macromedia</a><br /><br />Holy shit.  This worries me a lot, because Macromedia makes what I strongly believe is the best design tool for web graphics, <a href="http://www.macromedia.com/software/fireworks/">Fireworks</a>. Fireworks isn&#8217;t hugely popular, though, and I wouldn&#8217;t be surprised to see Adobe kill it in favor of their <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop/main.html">Photoshop/ImageReady</a> combo.  IR is not bad, but isn&#8217;t at a vector-based tool like Fireworks, and that&#8217;s what makes Fireworks such a fucking great product.<br /><br />There is other crossover with Macromedia tools I like, but the main other one I use, <a href="http://www.macromedia.com/software/dreamweaver/">Dreamweaver</a>, is the best of breed in its category, and Adobe would be unlikely to trash it.  <a href="http://www.macromedia.com/software/freehand/">Freehand</a> is actually a very underrated tool, but I usually end up using Adobe&#8217;s <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/illustrator/main.html">Illustrator</a>, if only because I know that stuff done in Illustrator will work fine at the printer (and also because Macromedia has basically abandoned it).<br /><br />Jesus.  This is BIG NEWS.  I am really anxious to hear any more about what&#8217;s planned.<br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/97156.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/97156.html</a></em></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "&#8220;The New Pope is a Disaster for the World and for the Jews&#8221;"
url_title: the_new_pope_is_a_disaster_for_the_world_and_for_the_jews
permalink: the_new_pope_is_a_disaster_for_the_world_and_for_the_jews.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2005-04-20
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1900
---
<p>Obviously, this should be taken with the usual grain of salt &#8212; I don&#8217;t know enough about Ratzinger or Lerner to make a judgement.  <em>If</em> this is accurate, though, this is terribly disappointing, and would seem to only further distance the Roman Catholic Church from what I believe it <em>should</em> be doing: performing and promoting the <em>healing</em> work &#8212; physically, socially, and spiritually &#8212; that Christ taught.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.tikkun.org/rabbi_lerner/news_item.2005-04-19.4230239892">http://www.tikkun.org/rabbi_lerner/news_<wbr />item.2005-04-19.4230239892</a><br /><br /></p>

<blockquote>&#8220;While many of us agree with Ratzinger&#8217;s critique of moral relativism, he extends that critique in illegitimate and dangerous ways, equating secularism with moral relativism and suggesting that secularism is now repressing religion. Ratzinger also publicly critiques all those inside the Church who are tolerant enough to think that other religions may have equal validity as a path to God. This is a slippery slope toward anti-Semitism and a return to the chauvinistic and triumphalist views that led the Church, when it had the power to do so, to develop its infamous crusades and inquisitions. In 1997 Ratzinger called Buddhism an &#8220;autoerotic spirituality&#8221; that offers &#8220;transcendence without imposing concrete religious obligations.&#8221; Hindusim, he said, offers &#8220;false hope,&#8221; in that it guarantees &#8220;purification&#8221; based on a &#8220;morally cruel&#8221; concept of reincarnation resembling &#8220;a continuous circle of hell.&#8221; At the time, Cardinal Ratzinger predicted that Buddhism would replace Marxism as the Catholic church&#8217;s main enemy.<br /><br />&#8220;Ratzinger is being falsely described as a conservative, when in fact he, despite his publicly genteel manner, is a raging reactionary. Unlike many American conservatives who oppose gay sexual practices but not their legal rights, Ratzinger in 1992 argued against human rights for gays, stressing that their civil liberties could be &#8220;legitimately limited.&#8221;</blockquote>

<p><br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/96810.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/96810.html</a></em></p>

<p><a href="http://phaedo.cx/archives/2005/04/11/jason-kottk-updates-us-on-micropatron-funddrive/">Switch-Case / Blog Archive / » Jason Kottke updates us on Micropatron funddrive</a></p>

<p>Does anyone else just not <em>get</em> what the big deal is about Kottke?  He made <a href="http://www.kottke.org/plus/type/silkscreen/index.html">a cool tiny font</a> once, but I&#8217;m not really clear what makes him so fascinating.  Plus, his site is a fucking mess &#8212; a mishmash of links (occasionally with comments), interspersed with longer prose at seemingly random intervals.</p>

<p>I&#8217;m not saying this to knock the guy.  He seems intelligent and thoughtful.  But I don&#8217;t get what exactly he offers over, say, 10,000 other pretty smart dudes online, except perhaps the sheer amount of stuff on his site.  Why are people paying him to do this?</p>

layout: post

<p>Well, my talk proposal for <a href="http://conferences.oreillynet.com/os2005/">OSCon</a> was not accepted.  On the positive side, <a href="http://shiflett.org/">Chris Schiflett</a> said that all the votes I received were positive (which I think means that no one voted <em>against</em> my talk &#8212; I just didn&#8217;t get <em>enough</em> votes), and that even <a href="http://www.schlossnagle.org/~george/blog/">George Schlossnagle</a>&#8217;s tutorial on PHP performance was shot down.  Apparently the number of rooms is smaller this year (despite being in the Convention Center and not the hotel), so there will actually be fewer sessions, and only the super best proposals got accepted.<br /><br />I&#8217;m bummed, because this would have been a nice feather in my cap, and would have made convincing work that this is a business trip a lot easier (they&#8217;ll pay for it as a business trip).  But, all is not lost, and if I can get us more involved in the PHP security community, I think I can still make the case.  We&#8217;ll see.<br /><br /> <em>Original link: <a href="http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/90130.html">http://www.livejournal.com/users/funkatron/90130.html</a></em></p>

<p>Interesting development.  Then again, didn&#8217;t Sun makes some &#8220;partnership&#8221; moves with Zend a while back?  Haven&#8217;t heard much from that lately.</p>

<p>IBM came in and sold Purdue&#8217;s IT department on Websphere, so if this does pan out, it may mean more interest and opportunities for PHP on campups.  That would be nice.</p>

<p>More on this:</p>

<ul>
 <li><a href="http://andigutmans.blogspot.com/2005/02/ibm-to-join-php-community.html">Andi Gutmans</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www.schlitt.info/applications/blog/index.php?/archives/305-PHP-and-IBM.html">Tobias Schlitt</a></li>
 <li><a href="http://www-306.ibm.com/software/data/info/zendcore/pr.html">Press Release at IBM</a>
<blockquote>Zend Core for IBM will be a seamless, out-of-the-box PHP development and production environment, based on PHP 5 technology. The product includes tight integration with IBM Cloudscape database server, DB2 and native support for XML and Web Services - supporting increased adoption of Service Oriented Architectures (SOA). It delivers an unprecedented rapid development and deployment foundation for database driven applications and offers an upgrade path from the easy-to-use, lightweight Cloudscape database to the mission critical DB2, by providing a consistent API to developers.

Zend Core for IBM will be available in the second quarter of 2005 as a free download via the DB2 and Cloudscape product site and IBM&#8217;s developer portal, developerWorks via this easy-to-use package, PHP development or production servers can be setup within minutes. Additionally, a new PHP technology area will be introduced within IBM developerWorks to assist developers as they adopt PHP and IBM technologies for their applications. Zend Core for IBM support and updates will be made available directly from Zend Technologies. This offering will be compatible with existing products such as Zend Platform and Zend Studio. IBM is also planning to support Zend Core for IBM with the latest version of Informix Dynamic Server (IDS).</blockquote></li>
</ul>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "T-Mobile online: Code injection heaven"
url_title: t_mobile_online_code_injection_heaven
permalink: t_mobile_online_code_injection_heaven.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
date: 2005-02-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1861
---
<p><a href="http://www.infosecinstitute.com/blog/ethical_hacking_computer_forensics.html">Ethical Hacking and Computer Forensics - &#8221; Secret Service hacker, how did he do it?&#8221;</a> (thanks <a href="http://www.phaedo.cx">Clint</a>)</p>

<p>Interesting piece that starts off talking about the guy who had broken into a number of T-Mobile accounts, and how he may have done it.  The author tests a number of basic code injection attacks, and finds that even after the fact, T-Mobile has left numerous holes in their system:</p>

<blockquote>To further corraborate that Nick used a web application hack, most likely <a href="http://www.infosecinstitute.com/blog/www.nextgenss.com/papers/advanced_sql_injection.pdf">SQL Injection</a> (a little research shows that the T-Mobile site uses IIS/ASP/SQL Server, which happens to be the easiest and most well documented platform for SQL Injection attacks), we can check out the website and try to put some invalid input into the T-Mobile login page. I was very surprised with the results, we can still put all sorts of crazy input into the login page! It is still vulnerable, even after one of the largest, most well known, and high profile hacks in the last couple of years!</blockquote>

<p>Perplexing and sad that a company with the resources &#8212; and recent embarassment &#8212; of T-Mobile apparently can&#8217;t or won&#8217;t address basic web app security.</p>





<!-- end of post -->

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "New issue of Usability News available"
url_title: new_issue_of_usability_news_available
permalink: new_issue_of_usability_news_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- The Web Problem
- Design
date: 2005-02-18
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1860
---
<p><a href="http://www.usabilitynews.org/">Usability News - Feb 2005</a></p>

<p>Usability News has tons of <em>really</em> useful info for folks who care about usability &#8212; and if you are at all involved in making things that human being interact with, you need to care about it.  From the home page:</p>

<blockquote>Usability News  is a free web newsletter that is produced by the <a href="http://psychology.wichita.edu/surl/">Software Usability Research Laboratory (SURL)</a>. The SURL team specializes in software/website user interface design research, human-computer interaction research, and usability testing and research.</blockquote>

<p>Probably the most significant advantage the SURL stuff has over a lot of other usability info is that it&#8217;s actually based in proper scientific research, rather than the usual &#8220;common sense&#8221; approach.  One of the best examples of that is <em><a href="http://psychology.wichita.edu/surl/usabilitynews/62/web_object_international.htm">Preliminary Examination of Global Expectations of Users&#8217; Mental Models for E-Commerce Web Layouts</a></em>, a really interesting study that examines where people from different parts of the world expect common e-commerce web objects to appear, like the &#8220;Shopping Cart&#8221; icon and &#8220;Home&#8221; link.  Stuff like this gives an interface designer real evidence to back up his or her layout choices.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Chris Shiflett: More on Filtering Input and Escaping Output"
url_title: chris_shiflett_more_on_filtering_input_and_escaping_output
permalink: chris_shiflett_more_on_filtering_input_and_escaping_output.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- PHP
date: 2005-02-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1856
---
<p><a href="http://shiflett.org/archive/98">Chris Shiflett: More on Filtering Input and Escaping Output</a></p>

<p>I found this post quite educational, especially about what items in the various superglobals ($_GET, $_POST, $_SERVER, $_COOKIE, $_SESSION) are tainted.  Basically, the gist is that $_GET, $_POST, and $_COOKIE are always provided from the user, and therefore have to be considered tainted.  $_SESSION is stored by the server, and <em>shouldn&#8217;t</em> be tainted if you did your job right (i.e., you didn&#8217;t store any tainted data in the session).  $_SERVER, though, is more complex, because some of the values in that array come from the web browser, despite the name of the array.  Check the comments for more detail.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "ONLamp.com: Top Ten Tips to Make Attacker&#8217;s Lives Hell"
url_title: onlampcom_top_ten_tips_to_make_attackers_lives_hell
permalink: onlampcom_top_ten_tips_to_make_attackers_lives_hell.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- InfoSec
- The Web Problem
- OS X
date: 2004-03-26
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1845
---
<p><a href="http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/security/2004/03/25/ntwksecurityassess.html">ONLamp.com: Top Ten Tips to Make Attacker&#8217;s Lives Hell</a></p>

<p>Good stuff here. Articles like this often lack practical implementation info, but this gives you some specifics to follow. One app it mentions that I wasn&#8217;t aware of is <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/recommended/urlscan/default.asp">URLScan</a>, a free tool from MS to filter server requests.  Not that I&#8217;d ever use a MS Server for anything that the public could access, but if you <i>must</i>, this seems like a requirement for your IIS box.</p>

old_entry_id: 1844
---
<p>At work we use <a href="http://www.mnogosearch.ru/">mnoGoSearch</a> to handle our sitewide search engine needs.  It&#8217;s a pretty powerful and flexible tool, but has a couple annoyances:</p>

<ol>
 <li>The documentation is uneven at best.</li>
 <li>Out of the box, the app can&#8217;t generate valid XHTML.</li>
</ol>

<p>The second one is what was annoying me today, because even after you clean up the example templates, it <em>still</em> insists on mucking up your code.  mnoGoSearch seems to rewrite some of the &lt;input&gt; tags is displays, making the &#8220;value&#8221; attribute uppercase, and forcing a space after every attribute/value combo inside the tag.  The latter is problematic because it treats the closing &#8220;/&#8221; in the &lt;input&gt; tag as an attribute, forcing a space after it.  Both of these behaviors ruin my finely tuned XHTML 1.1 transitional-valid code.</p>

<p>So, in a fit of open-source excitement, I decided to patch the code myself.  I&#8217;m definitely NOT a C programmer, but finding and patching the appropriate code was pretty straightforward.  The culprit is the TemplateTag function in the file template.c, which I&#8217;ve modified to do the following:</p>

<ol>
 <li>Write the &#8220;value&#8221; attribute as lowercase</li>
 <li>place the separating space <em>before</em> the attribute</li>
</ol>

<p>These changes get it to play nice with XHTML, and shouldn&#8217;t affect the search engine&#8217;s ability to generate valid HTML.</p>

<p>Since I&#8217;m not versed in the ways of diff and patch, I&#8217;ll just upload the whole file.  It gets interesting around line 335.</p>

<p><a href="/downloads/mnogosearch/template.c">Patched template.c</a> | <a href="/downloads/mnogosearch/template.c.html">Pretty coloriffic source</a> <em>generated by <a href="http://www.bedaux.net/cpp2html/">c++2html</a></em></p>

<p><strong>Edit:</strong> That first version didn&#8217;t really work.  This one does, though.</p>





<!-- end of post -->

<p><a href="http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/bsd/2004/03/18/marc_espie.html">ONLamp.com: An Interview with OpenBSD&#8217;s Marc Espie [Mar. 18, 2004]</a></p>

<p>First off, I&#8217;m quote certain that this guy could destroy me with his mind.  I&#8217;m a lowly script/design monkey, and he&#8217;s on a whole &#8216;nother level when it comes to programming. However, I&#8217;m sorta taken aback by catty comments like this:</p>

<div class="pullquote">&#8220;The chief opponent to strlcpy in glibc is most certainly Ulrich Drepper, who argues that good programmers don&#8217;t need strlcpy, since they don&#8217;t make mistakes while copying strings. This is a very mystifying point of view, since bugtraq daily proves that a lot of Linux and free software programmers are not that bright, and need all the help they can get.<p />

(Considering the shining, flaming personality of Drepper, and the fact that he is always Right, this is not that surprising, though).&#8221;</p></div>

<p>Dude.  What the hell?  It&#8217;s one thing to call a guy an asshole when you&#8217;re sitting around the table with your fellow nerds, stuffing your face with gyro meat and complaining about how the inferior Linux gets all the glory and midget-Eminem ads, but it&#8217;s quite another to do it in a public interview.  For fuck&#8217;s sake, show some tact, man.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.zeit.ca/mozie/">Mozie</a> looks like a really useful tool to do side-by-side comparisons of IE and Gecko page renderings.  Windows only, unfortunately, but that&#8217;s to be expected.  It&#8217;s apparently built off of the <a href="http://www.iol.ie/~locka/mozilla/control.htm">Mozilla ActiveX control</a>, which allows windows devs to embed Mozilla in their apps.  I wonder if it would be possible to just serve your page in Mozilla, embedded within IE.  I&#8217;m sure someone will try this shortly.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "RSS Viewer 0.3"
url_title: rss_viewer_03
permalink: rss_viewer_03.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- PHP
date: 2004-01-06
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1833
---
<p>Can you tell what my new favorite project is?</p>

<div class="pullquote"><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss-viewer-0.3.png" onclick="window.open('http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss-viewer-0.3.png','popup','width=985,height=737,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=yes,left=0,top=0');return false"><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss-viewer-0.3-tm.jpg" height="112" width="149" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="screenshot" title="" longdesc="" /></a>New this version:
<ul><li>Combined feeds and items sidebar frames into a single menu system</li><li>Added fancy gradients to make it look more 1337</li></ul></div>

<p>I&#8217;m rather proud of the new menu system.  It dynamically loads the feeds when requested, as opposed to having to build the whole menu tree when the feeds frame loads.  Here&#8217;s how it works:</p>

<ol><li>User clicks on feed title, triggering javascript that loads an url w/ parameters into a hidden frame</li><li>php script takes url parameters, downloads feed, and generates the html along with a javascript command to insert the html into the feeds menu</li><li>when page is loaded into hidden frame, the generated javascript is executed, and the items html is inserted and shown</li></ol>

<p>It&#8217;s convoluted, but it seems to work!</p>

<p><b>Update:</b>  Links would be good.</p>

<ul><li><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/rss_viewer/">Demo</a></li><li><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/apps/funkatron_rss_viewer/rss_viewer-0.3.tgz">Download</a></li></ul>

tags: ""

- OS X
date: 2003-08-22

old_entry_id: 1826
---
<p>Things I discovered tonight:</p>

<ul>
<li>A: .Mac account passwords can be 6-32 characters</li>
<li>B: The .Mac iDisk Utility for XP (which Apple wrote) can only use passwords of 6-8 characters</li>
<li>A+B = God forbid I use a .Mac password over 8 characters and want to upload to my iDisk from XP</li>
</ul>

<p>Also, Appleworks sucks.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "New Widget: dropTar"
url_title: new_widget_droptar
permalink: new_widget_droptar.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-08-20
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1825
---
<p><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/dropTar.png" height="118" width="121" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="dropTar 1.0" title="" longdesc="" /><b>dropTar</b> is a Konfabulator widget I cooked up to quickly handle tarring and zipping of files.  You just drop one or more files or folders on the icon, and <b>dropTar</b> does its thing.  <b>dropTar</b> uses <a href="http://www.metaobject.com/">hfstar</a>, so your resource forks are safe.</p>

<p />

<p><a href="http://homepage.mac.com/coj/.cv/coj/Public/dropTar.tar.bz2-binhex.hqx">Download dropTar now (108k)</a></p></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "RSS Viewer 1.0 Beta 4 now available"
url_title: rss_viewer_10_beta_4_now_available
permalink: rss_viewer_10_beta_4_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-08-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1823
---
<p>RSS Viewer now supports multiple feeds, and is available for download.  From the readme:</p>

<div class="pullquote">
<a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/screenshot_konfab1.0beta4.jpg" onclick="window.open('http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/screenshot_konfab1.0beta4.jpg','popup','width=1152,height=768,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=yes,left=0,top=0');return false"><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/screenshot_konfab1.0beta4-tm.jpg" height="106" width="160" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="RSS Viewer - screenshot with 1.0 Beta 4 running" title="" longdesc="" /></a>
You can enter multiple urls in the &#8220;RSS Feed URL:&#8221; preference, separated
by &#8220;|&#8221; (pipe) characters.  For example:<p></p>

 <span style="padding-left:10px;font-family:monospace"><b>http://slashdot.org/slashdot.rdf|http://www.hardocp.com/hardocp.rdf|http://www.funkatron.com/mt/index.rdf</b></span><p></p>

Items from the feeds are displayed in the same window by their order in
their respective feed: item 1 of feed 1 is shown first, then item 1 of
feed 2, then item 2 of feed 1, etc.
</div>

<p><br /></p>

<p><a href="http://homepage.mac.com/coj/.cv/coj/Public/RSS%20Viewer%201.0b4.dmg-link.dmg">Download it now from my .Mac account (81k)</a></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "RSS Viewer Widget for Konfabulator"
url_title: rss_viewer_widget_for_konfabulator
permalink: rss_viewer_widget_for_konfabulator.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-08-14
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1819
---
<p><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_main.png" onclick="window.open('http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_main.png','popup','width=311,height=156,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=yes,left=0,top=0');return false"><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_main-tm.jpg" height="78" width="155" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="RSS Viewer widget screenshot" title="" longdesc="" /></a></p>

<p>A couple weeks ago I was looking for a basic RSS Viewer widget for <a href="http://www.konfabulator.com">Konfabulator</a>.  Strangely, I couldn&#8217;t find one in their gallery; it was all stuff designed to view one or a handful of feeds.  So I wrote my own.  It has problems with a couple feeds I&#8217;ve run across (most notably the one for <a href="http://www.phaedo.cx">phaedo.cx</a>), but for the most part it seems to function as it should.</p>

<p><br clear="all" /></p>

<p>&lt;</p>

<p>p>If people dig it, I&#8217;ll try and add a couple more features.  The big one I&#8217;d like to do is the ability have a personalized set of feeds to choose from, rather than having to enter a new url each time you want to view a different feed.
<a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_prefs.png" onclick="window.open('http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_prefs.png','popup','width=412,height=404,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=yes,left=0,top=0');return false"><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/rss_viewer_prefs-tm.jpg" height="120" width="123" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="RSS Viewer widget prefs screenshot" title="" longdesc="" /></a></p>

<ul>
<li><b><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/downloads/rss_viewer/RSS%20Viewer.dmg.bz2">Download RSS Viewer for Konfabulator now (51k)</a></b></li>
</ul>

url_title: updates
permalink: updates.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-08-05
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1817
---
<p>Nah, I&#8217;m not dead &#8212; just busy.  We finally moved, and we&#8217;re still kinda trying to get settled.  We also had to buy <a href="http://finklers.com/ed/pics/jetta/">a new car</a>, which wasn&#8217;t bad since the car is BAD-AZZ, but not great since it meant we had a car payment again.</p>

<p></p>

<p>As for development, LameBrain has lately taken a backseat to work on Funkatron Viewer, a simple image viewer intended to sorta emulate the feel of <a href="http://www.irfanview.com/">Irfanview</a>, my favorite Win32 image viewer.  FV should be ready for release sometime in the next couple weeeks.  I do still intend to work on LB, and I have some exciting ideas for it, but I just don&#8217;t have the time right now.</p>

<p></p>

<p>This site may be changing in the next few weeks.  I want to get more consulting business going, so it&#8217;s likely that Funkatron.com will be the address for that.  This blog and the apps will still be available, although you might have to click once or twice to find them.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain 0.6.1a Now Available"
url_title: lamebrain_061a_now_available
permalink: lamebrain_061a_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-06-30
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1816
---
<p>This release re-enables the ability to use LAME to write ID3 tags when using the CD Ripper.  I got requests to put this back in because LAME will use ID3V2 tags if the data exceeds ID3v1&#8217;s 30-character limit.  LameBrain will use LAME by default when ripping a CD, but you can disable it in the preferences if you like.</p>

<p></p>

<p><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/LameBrain.dmg.bz2">Download now</a>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain 0.6.1 Now Available"
url_title: lamebrain_061_now_available
permalink: lamebrain_061_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-06-25
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1815
---
<p><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/LB_061.png" onclick="window.open('http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/LB_061.png','popup','width=678,height=676,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes,toolbar=no,directories=no,location=no,menubar=no,status=yes,left=0,top=0');return false"><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/LB_061-tm.jpg" height="171" width="171" align="right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="LameBrain 0.6.1 screenshot" title="" longdesc="" /></a></p>

<p>Some major bugs fixed, as well as some aesthetic changes. Here are the details:</p>

<ul>
<li>Fixed bug with writing .m3u files during CD Ripping</li>
<li>Fixed issues with loading/saving profiles</li>
<li>Fixed issues with extended ascii chars in id3 tag info</li>
<li>Fixed bug where incorrect encoding settings were sometimes used</li>
<li>DVDs shouldn&#8217;t cause crashes (I hope)</li>
<li>Rewrote all code where duplicate volume names could cause problems</li>
<li>Restored &#8220;Eject&#8221; button on CD Ripper</li>
<li>CDs now use standard ID3v1.1 genres instead of FreeDB genres (FreeDB info is mapped to appropriate ID3 genres)</li>
<li>When a setting in the LAME Settings window is chosen, other settings that don&#8217;t work with it will be disabled</li>
<li>Changed default target directory for CD and Batch encoders to user&#8217;s Music directory</li>
<li>Double-clicking on a FreeDB result option now chooses that option</li>
<li>Preferences cleaned-up into and put into tab panel</li>
<li>Added pref to turn on/off help popups</li>
<li>Added pref to turn on/off LAME Settings control disabling</li>
<li>Added &#8220;fast standard&#8221; and &#8220;fast extreme&#8221; to alt-present menu</li>
<li>Dropped use of MP3info class totally in favor of id3ed</li>
<li>CD Ripper now fills in track number field of id3v1.1 tag</li>
<li>Added new Edit menu options for CD and Batch Encoder: Select All, Select None, Toggle Selected.  Batch Encoder additionally gains Delete Selected and Delete All menu options</li>
<li>Some minor aesthetic changes to LAME Settings window</li>
<li>Added pretty row background colors</li>
<li>Fancier-looking toolbar buttons</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/LameBrain.dmg.bz2">Download now</a>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain 0.6.0 Now Available"
url_title: lamebrain_060_now_available
permalink: lamebrain_060_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-05-17
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1810
---
<p>Here&#8217;s what&#8217;s new in this version:</p>

<ul>
  <li>If you previous installed a preview version of 0.6.0, you should delete your preferences file BEFORE running 0.6.0 final.  It should be &lt;your home directory&gt;:Library:Preferences:LameBrain 0.6 Prefs</li>
  <li>All main encoding windows (single file/batch/cd ripper) have been combined into a single window.  Stats have been moved to the LAME settings window under the Stats tab.  Size of LAME settings window has been reduced. Appropriate changes have been made to the Preferences window</li>
  <li>ID3v1.1 tag viewing and editing is enabled using <a href="http://www.dakotacom.net/~donut/programs/id3ed.html">id3ed</a>.  Only v1.1 tags are currently supported</li>
  <li>FreeDB server preference can now be selected from a dropdown menu.  You can add or remove servers by editing the data/freedb_mirrors.txt file</li>
  <li>LAME executable has been moved to bin/ subdirectory</li>
  <li>Profiles have been moved into &#8220;Profiles&#8221; subdirectory.  You will need to move your custom profiles into this folder for them to be usable</li>
  <li>Extended ASCII chars are now converted to &#8220;_&#8221; in output filenames</li>
  <li>Added debug logging functionality.  Debug info is logged to file in &#8220;logs/&#8221; subdir, and can be turned on or off in Preferences.  Logging can slow LB down and the file can get quite large, so this should only be used if you&#8217;re having problems</li>
  <li>Added ability to view TOC.plist file of currently selected CD. Useful for debugging purposes</li>
  <li>New, fancier About window. Woo!</li>
  <li>Eject button removed since preview versions; will reappear soon</li>
  <li>Experimental: LameBrain will try to copy the ID3 tags from an input mp3 file to the re-encoded version</li>
  <li>Fancy new icons for the control bar by <a href="http://www.transmtt-r.com/">Ken Holewczynski</a></li>
  <li>Clip player will now show artist and title if ID3 info is present</li>
  <li>Fixed bug where LameBrain would crash if it found a mounted DVD</li>
  <li>Fixed bugs with double-quotes in ID3 tags when CD ripping</li>
  <li>Fixed bug where Year info was not retrieved from FreeDB</li>
  <li>fixed issue where colons in CD info tags were causing Nil Object Exceptions when the .m3u file was written</li>
 </ul>

<p><a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/LameBrain.dmg.bz2">Download now</a></p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LAME optimization tests"
url_title: lame_optimization_tests
permalink: lame_optimization_tests.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-05-16
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1809
---
<p>I did some tests last night using &#8212;alt-preset standard on 3.90.2, 3.93.1, and a new compile of 3.93.1 I did with several compiler optimization settings:</p>

<pre>
-faltivec -mcpu=7450 -mdynamic-no-pic -funroll-loops -ffast-math -fstrict-aliasing -O3
</pre>

<p>Here are the results of the tests I did. I wouldn&#8217;t call them scientific, but I did use the same file for each, and didn&#8217;t do anything else while it was encoding.</p>

<h3>3.90.2 (<a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/lame-3.90.2.osx-minimal-binary.bz2">download</a>):</h3>

<pre>
[Funktanium-Powerbook:~]coj% lame --nohist --alt-preset standard ~/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
LAME version 3.90.2  (http://www.mp3dev.org/)
Using polyphase lowpass  filter, transition band: 18671 Hz - 19205 Hz
Encoding /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
     to /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav.mp3
Encoding as 44.1 kHz VBR(q=2) j-stereo MPEG-1 Layer III (ca. 7.3x) qval=2
   Frame          |  CPU time/estim | REAL time/estim | play/CPU |    ETA
12471/12474 (100%)|    0:26/    0:26|    5:20/    5:20|   12.345x|    0:00
average: 232.3 kbps   LR: 4079 (32.70%)   MS: 8395 (67.30%)

Writing LAME Tag...done
</pre>

<h3>3.93.1:</h3>

<pre>
[Funktanium-Powerbook:~]coj% ~/Documents/RealBasic/LameBrain/bin/lame --nohist --alt-preset standard ~/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
LAME version 3.93  (http://www.mp3dev.org/)
Using polyphase lowpass  filter, transition band: 18671 Hz - 19205 Hz
Encoding /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
     to /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav.mp3
Encoding as 44.1 kHz VBR(q=2) j-stereo MPEG-1 Layer III (ca. 7.3x) qval=2
   Frame          |  CPU time/estim | REAL time/estim | play/CPU |    ETA
12471/12474 (100%)|    0:24/    0:24|    4:59/    4:59|   13.254x|    0:00
average: 231.8 kbps   LR: 4075 (32.67%)   MS: 8399 (67.33%)

Writing LAME Tag...done
</pre>

<h3>3.93.1 with optimizations (<a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/lame_binary-g4optimized.gz">download</a>):</h3>

<pre>
[Funktanium-Powerbook:~]coj% /usr/local/lame_optimized/bin/lame --nohist --alt-preset standard ~/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
LAME version 3.93  (http://www.mp3dev.org/)
Using polyphase lowpass  filter, transition band: 18671 Hz - 19205 Hz
Encoding /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav
     to /Users/coj/Desktop/machine_deadagent.wav.mp3
Encoding as 44.1 kHz VBR(q=2) j-stereo MPEG-1 Layer III (ca. 7.3x) qval=2
   Frame          |  CPU time/estim | REAL time/estim | play/CPU |    ETA
12471/12474 (100%)|    0:16/    0:16|    4:32/    4:32|   19.578x|    0:00
average: 231.8 kbps   LR: 4075 (32.67%)   MS: 8399 (67.33%)

Writing LAME Tag...done
</pre>

<p>Note that I did NOT do any listening tests &#8212; this is just comparing speed. It looks to me that the plain 3.93.1 is faster than 3.90.2, and the optimized 3.93.1 is significantly faster than 3.93.1 standard. The optimizations I did might keep the binary from working on G3s and older G4s (&lt; 500Mhz, I think), so I want to run some tests on it before including it as standard in LameBrain.  If you are willing to give it a shot, please <a href="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/files/lame_binary-g4optimized.gz">download the binary and let me know the results.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Remember when Metallica were good?"
url_title: remember_when_metallica_were_good
permalink: remember_when_metallica_were_good.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-04-26
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1808
---
<p>I do.  They put out four albums in the 80s that varied from <a href="http://www.encycmet.com/discography/Kill_em_all.shtml">very good but corny</a> to <a href="http://www.encycmet.com/discography/And_justice_for_all.shtml">fucking amazing</a>.  Then the 90s rolled around, and they did one <a href="http://www.encycmet.com/discography/Metallica.shtml">kinda okay album</a>, and two <a href="http://www.encycmet.com/discography/Load.shtml">which made</a> <a href="http://www.encycmet.com/discography/Re_load.shtml">me cry</a>.</p>

<p></p>

<p>In my opinion, the 90s downslide wasn&#8217;t so much the instrumentation, which varied from kinda okay to occasionally quite good, but the lyrics and vocals.  Let&#8217;s compare the former:</p>

<ul><li>
&#8220;Blackened&#8221;, 1988<br />
<i> Blackened Is the End<br />
Winter it Will Send<br /></i>
<p></p></il>

<li>
&#8220;I Disappear&#8221;, 2000<br />
<i>Hey Hey Hey<br />
Here I go now<br /></i>
<p></p></li>
</ul>

<p><b>What the hell?</b></p>

<p></p>

<p>As for the vocals, Hetfield has certainly increased his singing ability and vocal range, but he also started saying &#8220;oooh&#8221; and &#8220;yeah!&#8221; a lot.  Rob Zombie pulls off &#8220;yeah,&#8221; but James just doesn&#8217;t.  It sounds wimpy, especially when he sings old songs (their perfomance of &#8220;Fade to Black&#8221; at the VH1 Music Awards a couple years ago actually made the <i>original</i> version unlistenable for a few months)</p>

<p></p>

<p>So anyway, the three remaining members of Metallica have a new album coming out soon called <i>St. Anger</i>.  The word on the street is that it&#8217;s supposed to be a return to the pre-suck era.  I first read this on the MTVNews site, and was fairly suspicious, since the guy who wrote the article probably thought the last Limp Bizkit album had &#8220;killer riffs.&#8221;  <a href="http://www.encycmet.biz/news/2003-04-02.shtml">But this review</a> translated from <a href="http://www.closeupmagazine.net/metallica.php">a Swedish mag called Close-Up</a> was also very positive about the album, and I&#8217;m about a trillion times more likely to trust a Swede &#8212; any Swede &#8212; about metal than I am a guy whose career ambition is to follow in the footsteps of Gideon Yago.  I do find it odd that they did this after the only guy in the band who seemed to remember what was cool about Metallilca left, but hey, maybe they&#8217;re doing coke again.</p>

<p></p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain discussion list"
url_title: lamebrain_discussion_list
permalink: lamebrain_discussion_list.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-04-13
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1807
---
<p>I&#8217;ve set up a mailing list for discussing LameBrain.  Feature requests, bug reports, and general discussion of mp3 encoding on the Mac are all game.  I&#8217;ll also make announcements of new versions on this list, including &#8220;private&#8221; beta and debug builds.  To subscribe, just send a blank message to:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="mailto:lamebrain-discuss-subscribe@funkatron.com">lamebrain-discuss-subscribe@funkatron.com</a></li>
</ul>

<p>I am a total idiot.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Mozilla screws me again"
url_title: mozilla_screws_me_again
permalink: mozilla_screws_me_again.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-04-03
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1805
---
<p>So I&#8217;ve been using Mozilla mail again, since it&#8217;s a little more powerful than Mail.app.  Plus, this way I&#8217;m using the same client on Mac and PC (no way in hell I&#8217;m using Outlook Express, especially after my friend&#8217;s PC got a virus just from <b>reading a message</b> in OE).</p>

<p></p>

<p>Now on the PC version of Moz Mail, SHIFT+ALT+Enter sends the message you&#8217;re composing.  I&#8217;ve gotten quite in the habit of using this, since I&#8217;m all about the keyboard shortcuts, dontcha know?  So naturally, when I start using Moz mail on OS X, I attempt to do something similar with SHIFT+CMD+Return.  Everything looks fine, although I do find it odd that if I hit CMD+Return, it appears to also send, except it asks me first if I <i>really</i> wanna send a message.  I don&#8217;t like ther computer second-guessing me, so I avoid using that shortcut and stick to my tried-and-true triple keypress.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Lately, a few people who I sent email to said they haven&#8217;t been getting it.  I poke around in my Sent folder, and sure enough, the messages aren&#8217;t there.  I check my preferences to make sure sent mail is getting copied to the Sent folder, and everything looks okay.  I decide to send myself some email; it never arrives.  What the hell?</p>

<p></p>

<p>So I get all scientific and send two messages.  One I send with the SHIFT+CMD+Return command, the other with the CMD+Return command.  Guess which one shows up?</p>

<p></p>

<p>So now I realize that probably the last 30 emails I &#8220;sent&#8221; didn&#8217;t actually go anywhere.  But they&#8217;re not saved in my drafts folder or anything like that.  As far as I can tell, SHIFT+CMD+Return is a shortcut for a hidden &#8220;fuck this noise&#8221; command that immediately destroys your message.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Then I notice this option under the File menu called &#8220;Send Later.&#8221;  Now there isn&#8217;t a key shortcut listed next to this command, so one would think that there wasn&#8217;t a shortcut for it.  One apparently would be wrong for thinking this, because once I hit &#8220;Send Unsent Messages,&#8221; Mozilla starts sending about 3000 messages, all the while saying over and over &#8220;damn, you <i>are</i> a dumbass, aren&#8217;t you?&#8221;  Because God forbid Mozilla <i>ask me</i> if I really want to instantly hide my message deep inside its poop chute where I&#8217;ll never find it, instead of sending it immediately.</p>

<p></p>

<p>So if you just got 10 messages from me, now you know why.</p>

<p></p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="1805" data-url-title="mozilla_screws_me_again">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1575" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Ed</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url"></div>
		<div class="comment-date">04/26/2003 03:49:57 PM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>You know, while you&#8217;re on the mac, you might want to get down with the menu system.  I&#8217;d been reading up on it and the whole &#8220;menu vs. keyboard shortcut&#8221; issue is really interesting.  Those top-of-screen mac menus gain about a zillion usability points over windows menus cause of the increased screen real estate, and they did a ton of tests back in the day that showed that&#8230;</p>

<p>1) using menus feels slower than using keyboard shortcuts</p>

<p>2) using menus is virtually always actually faster than using keyboard shorcuts</p>

<p>They eventually figured out that it takes more brainpower to remember a key combo than to look through a menu, and therefore you concentrate harder when using your keyboard shortcut, and you actually are amnesic for the time it took to remember the shortcut.  You think it was instantaneous, but it wasn&#8217;t,a nd the time it took was longer than the time it would have taken you to hit the menu item.</p>

<p>Those little half-seconds of concentration can hose you.</p>

<p>I&#8217;ve been trying going with the menus rather than key combos lately and it&#8217;s been working well for me &#8212; feels slightly slower but my work flow is still smooth.</p>

<p>And you never get hosed by the old &#8220;what are the keyboard shortcuts for THIS app?&#8221; phenomenon.</p>

<h2>Just an idea.</h2>
</div>
	</li>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1574" class="comment-id anchor"></a>

<p>My initial thoughts are that it&#8217;s definitely the case that menu systems are faster if we&#8217;re talking about exclusively using either menus or keystrokes.  My personal experience, though, is that it is definitely worth the time investment to learn keyboard shortcuts for things you do a lot.  A couple examples:</p>

<ul>
<li>Switching to the object or point selection tool in Illustrator</li>
<li>Inserting a &#8220;&#8221; tag in BBEdit</li>
</ul>

<p>I end up doing those things SO frequently that I&#8217;ve found that it really pays off.</p>
</div>

<p><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/mt/images/biteme.gif" height=105 width=150 align="Right" border="1" hspace="5" vspace="5" alt="">
I have a <a href="http://www.phpwebhosting.com">new web host</a>.  Why?  Because Hostrocket left an exploit on their servers which was exploited to <a href="http://www.webhostingtalk.com/showthread.php?s=&threadid=124584">deface many of their customers&#8217; sites</a>, including my site and 2 of my clients&#8217; sites.  When I inquired about a refund for this massive screwup (a free month&#8217;s hosting seemed not unreasonable), they told me they won&#8217;t be giving refunds.</p>

<p></p>

<p>This isn&#8217;t the first time I&#8217;ve had problems with HR, but it&#8217;s gonna be the last.  If they can&#8217;t throw their customers a bone after totally dropping the ball security-wise (<a href="http://security-archive.merton.ox.ac.uk/archive-200111/0352.html">again</a>), they clearly don&#8217;t deserve my business.  Frankly, I don&#8217;t think they deserve your business.  So screw &#8216;em.</p>

<p></p>

<p>PS: One more cool thing about the switch: MT actually functions correctly.  No more 500 errors.  Hooray!</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Stepping outside the static"
url_title: stepping_outside_the_static
permalink: stepping_outside_the_static.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- General
date: 2003-03-15
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1801
---
<p>Today I walked outside.</p>

<p></p>

<p>This isn&#8217;t noteworthy for that fact alone, but because I wasn&#8217;t going anywhere. I very, very rarely leave my apartment without the intention of going somewhere; usually work, but occasionally to run an errand.  The time spent outside is very rarely any more than necessary to walk the 15 paces to my car.</p>

<p></p>

<p>In the car, the radio is always on.  Sometime music; more often sports talk radio.  At home, the TV is always on.  Griffin is always playing with a toy or being fussy or needing attention.  I always have the laptop nearby, and I spend probably 70% of my time looking at the same websites over and over.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Since I was a little kid, my ears have rung.  I have a constant high-pitched ringing 24/7/365, and I have since I was 8 or 9.  I very rarely notice it anymore, because it&#8217;s with me all the time.  The constant din of media and activity is like that ringing. It&#8217;s a perpetual white noise that follows me everywhere.  It&#8217;s there all the time, so I just tune it out.  It&#8217;s &#8220;normal,&#8221; so I don&#8217;t perceive it.</p>

<p></p>

<p>The problem is, even though I don&#8217;t notice it, it still affects me.  I know this because when I stepped outside, set my white plastic lawn chair on the grass and sat down, I felt much more at ease than I had in a long time.  My anxiety about pratically everything dissipated.  I felt the world moving around me, and I knew that it would be&#8230; <i>okay</i>.</p>

<p></p>

<p>I&#8217;ve acquired many things.  I own tons of DVDs and games and computer junk.  But none of them ever make me feel as right with the world as sitting outside did today.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "OS X browser fun"
url_title: os_x_browser_fun
permalink: os_x_browser_fun.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-03-07
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1799
---
<p>So in the past couple days we&#8217;ve gotten two new browser releases for OS X: <a href="http://www.mozilla.org/projects/camino/">Camino (ex-Chimera) 0.7</a>, and Safari 1.0 b64.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Camino 0.7 doesn&#8217;t make any groundbreaking improvements, but it does seem to be a little faster.  It has a kinda swank download manager, but I&#8217;ve almost always found those things a waste of time.  It apparently can do auto-discovery of local web and ftp servers via Rendezvous, but I haven&#8217;t actually seen it work yet (I&#8217;m probably missing something though).  And I still can&#8217;t seem to do type ahead find with it, which I take advantage of with Phoenix on Win32.  Still, Camino remains my main browser.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Safari 1.0 b64 isn&#8217;t a public release, so no linking to it will be done here (I&#8217;m purely a leech), but if you look around on <a href="http://arstechnica.infopop.net/OpenTopic/page?a=frm&s=50009562&f=8300945231">message boards</a> you&#8217;ll find it without too much trouble.  The major new thing is tabbed browsing, which first appeared in b62 (also not a public release), and has been refined a bit here.  Tabs were really the main reason I wasn&#8217;t using Safari, and their appearance here makes it much more competitive with Camino.  Plus, I have to admit that I&#8217;m something of a brushed metal whore.</p>

<p></p>

<p>Personally, I would like to see Camino focus more on new and cool features, kind of the way Opera brings a lot of unique features to the platforms it supports.  It seems unlikely that Camino will overcome Safari in terms of market share, and the features that initially brought it popularity &#8212; looking and feeling like a true Aqua app, having a very solid rendering engine, etc &#8212; are being duplicated or improved upon in Safari.  But if it offers some features that appeal to power/niche users &#8212; ones that Apple is less likely to explore because they don&#8217;t appeal to Joe Switcher &#8212; it&#8217;s likely to shore up a dedicated user base.</p>

<p></p>





<!-- end of post -->

- OS X
date: 2003-03-07

---
<p>It&#8217;s taken a while to get out, but LameBrain 0.5.1 is finally available.  Goodies include:</p>

<ul>
<li>New feature: &#8220;Expert&#8221; tab allowing manual entry of command-line parameters</li>
<li>New feature: Customizable naming schemes for ripped files</li>
<li>New feature: Preference to delete source files after encoding finishes</li>
<li>Fix: Encoding Settings window control states are saved when window is closed</li>
<li>More progress on docs (still not finished)</li>
<li>Some other stuff I forgot</li>
</ul>

<p>Also, I&#8217;ve decided to start asking for donations for LameBrain.  LB is still <b>free</b>, but a little bit of coin will help defray development costs (stuff like Coke and <a href="http://www.jimmyjohns.com">Jimmy John&#8217;s</a>).  If you&#8217;d like to donate, just click the button on the maIn page of my blog.</p>

title: "Used CD Rampage"

<p><img src="http://www.funkatron.com/blog/images/tommy.gif" height=163 width=143 align="right" border=1 alt="ROCK AND ROLL!!!!">
I buy CDs a lot less now, but every once in a while I binge a little.   On our way back from lunch today, we stopped in this college student convenience store; one of those places that has everything a young learner needs:</p>

<ul>
<li>Cigarettes</lI>
<li>Cheap soda</li>
<li>Incense</li>
<li>3000 different types of Purdue shirts (to remind you where you are)</li>
<li>Maxim magazine</li>
<li>Really cheap used CDs</li>
</ul>

<p>It&#8217;s the last item that I was particularly interested in.  The average price of a used CD there is about $5.50, whereas most places would charge $10.  It&#8217;s not like they&#8217;re all winners (there were about 30 copies of <a href="http://www.coolio.com/" title="this is the shittiest web site in the world">Coolio&#8217;s</a>  <i>It Takes a Thief</i>), but there are usually a few gems to be found.  Here&#8217;s what I picked up during this expedition:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.remhq.com/">R.E.M.</a> - <i>Green</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=B8bknu3l5an1k">GTR</a> - <i>GTR</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.epitonic.com/artists/nullset.html">Nullset</a> - <i>Nullset</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.creation-records.com/ride/carnival.html">Ride</a> - <i>Carnival of Light</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.izzy-stradlin.com/jujuhounds.htm">Izzy Stradlin and the Ju Ju Hounds</a> - <i>Izzy Stradlin and the Ju Ju Hounds</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.officialtomwaits.com/">Tom Waits</a> - <i>Rain Dogs</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.soundgarden.fan.pl/">Soundgarden</a> - <i>Superunknown</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.lit-up.com/">Buckcherry</a> - <i>Buckcherry</i></li>
<li><a href="http://www.mygnr.com/">Guns n&#8217; Roses</a> - <i>Live Era &#8216;87-&#8216;93</i></li>
</ul>

<p>Some of these were nostalgia pickups (GTR, for example), and some were taking a chance because I liked a song I heard (Buckcherry, Ride).</p>

<p style="text-align: left; text-indent: 24px; line-height: 110%; margin-bottom: 4px; margin-top: 4px;" title="TITLE"></p>

<p>Now, the ripping begins&#8230;</p>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain 0.5.0 Now Available"
url_title: lamebrain_050_now_available
permalink: lamebrain_050_now_available.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-02-23
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1793
---
<p>LB, the <a href="http://home.swipnet.se/~w-12947/Sound/boomstic.wav">BOOMSTICK</a> of LAME front-ends, is now ready and waiting.</p>

<ul>
<li>GUI change: Encoding Settings now have their own window, as does the Single File Encoder.</li>
<li>GUI change: New Control Bar window.</li>
<li>GUI change: Minor changes to menubar.</li>
<li>GUI change: New keyboard shortcuts for all windows (CMD+0&#8230;5).  Using a keyboard shortcut now brings a currently open-window to the front.</li>
<li>Change: Single File Encoder and CD Ripper both get their encoding settings from the Encoding Settings window.  This offers significantly more flexibility.</li>
<li>Help: Popup Help now available on all controls.</li>
<li>Docs: Documentation started (nowhere near finished).  See the &#8220;docs&#8221; directory.</li>
<li>Preferences: User can now choose which windows are opened on startup.</li>
<li>Bug fix: Timeout on new version check on startup reduced to 7 seconds; limits startup delay if cannot connect to server.</li>
<li>Bug fix: Preferences are now only saved when &#8220;Save&#8221; is clicked.</li>
<li>Probably more minor stuff I can&#8217;t remember.</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="files/LameBrain.dmg.gz">Come get some</a>.</p>

---
layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "Color terminal for OS X"
url_title: color_terminal_for_os_x
permalink: color_terminal_for_os_x.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-02-22
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1792
---
<p>I&#8217;ve often been frustrated with the fact that OS X&#8217;s Terminal doesn&#8217;t by default support proper text coloring.  The main issue has been with supporting syntax coloring in <a href="http://www.nano-editor.org/">Nano</a>, which I use to edit files at work when I&#8217;m at home and outside work&#8217;s firewall/behind my NAT router.  I&#8217;ve gotten to the point where not having syntax coloring sends me into fits of rage, so for the sake of my family, it was important that I find a solution.</p>

<p>(It <i>is</i> true that you can <a href="http://www.macosxhints.com/article.php?story=20020408225741777">change your term emu to vt100-color</a>, but then you have to do this on all the machines you ssh to as well, which isn&#8217;t really a good idea when you&#8217;re using a shared account like I am.)</p>

<p>Anyway, somebody mentioned a Terminal replacement for OS X called <a href="http://www.pollet.net/GLterm/">GLterm</a>.  On a practical level, GLterm is cool because it supports ANSI color right out of the chute.  On a nerd level, GLterm is cool because it uses OpenGL to display everything.  It&#8217;s super fast &#8212; a lot faster than Terminal &#8212; and it feels more like a traditional UNIX terminal because it uses those old-skool fonts.</p>

<p>There are a couple less cool things about it.  It doesn&#8217;t support transparency, which I actually sometimes find practical when I&#8217;m transcribing something from a window behind Terminal.  It also costs $10, which isn&#8217;t a lot, but it feels a little pricey considering it doesn&#8217;t really offer a lot of new features.  So I haven&#8217;t bought it yet, but I&#8217;m thinking about it.  If you&#8217;re a bigtime CLI jockey, though, you might find this just the ticket.</p>




	 

<div id="comments" data-entry-id="1792" data-url-title="color_terminal_for_os_x">
	<ul>
	
	<li class="comment">
		<a name="1545" class="comment-id anchor"></a>
		<div class="comment-author">Eli Sarver</div>
		<div class="comment-author-url">http://lowmag.net</div>
		<div class="comment-date">03/03/2003 07:24:03 AM</date>
		<div class="comment-body"><p>I prefer iTerm, mainly because it is free+open software. &lt;a href=&#8221;http://iterm.sf.net&#8221;&gt;http://iterm.sf.net&lt;/a&gt; is its homepage. It has decent colour support, but it <em>is</em> a work in progress, so YMMV, of course.</p>

<hr />
</div>
	</li>
	 
	</ul>
</div>

layout: post
author: funkatron
title: "LameBrain 0.4.2"
url_title: lamebrain_042
permalink: lamebrain_042.html
tags: ""
published: true
category:
- OS X
date: 2003-02-19
summary: 
old_entry_id: 1791
---
<p>The front-end that <i>kicks ass</i> and <i>takes names</i> is back:</p>

<ul>
<li>New Feature: preview an input track by CTRL+clicking/right-clicking on the input file and selecting &#8220;Play File.&#8221;  This works in the main window, batch encoder, and CD ripper.</li>
<li>New Feature: CD ripper generates a .m3u playlist file.  Turn this on or off in Preferences.</li>
<li>Bug fix: App should no longer crash if the CD ripper is opened while a network drive is mounted</li>
<li>Encoding profile for tracks in batch queue can be changed by highlighting one or more tracks and picking a new profile in the Encoding Profile popup menu.</li>
<li>Stats window opens automatically upon encoding start.  Turn this on or off in Preferences.</li>
<li>Log field in stats window now automatically scrolls to the end when a new entry is added</li>
<li>Most windows can now be closed with CMD+W</li>
</ul>

<p><a href="files/LameBrain.dmg.gz">Get this bastard</a>.</p>
